DOC.HEAD: City Officials Beg For Calm Amidst Football Feud
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 6 grafs to UPDATE with game over, no immediate reports of violence; DELETES outdated quote from cheerleader; minor editing to conform. Pick up 7th graf, `Taylor's accusation ...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto staffing
DOC.TEXT: In the land where high school football is as important as oil, cattle and chili, a traditional cross-town rivalry is hotter than ever after a stinging expose, a tattling coach, a lawsuit and death threats. Police patrols were more than doubled for the game between state powerhouse Permian High School and longtime rival Odessa High School on Friday night and city leaders urged rabid fans to keep their cool. ``There was a lot of concern that, because of anger, there could be vandalism, even violence, if we did not pull together as a community,'' Mayor Lorraine Bonner said. Permian won 24-6 and there were no incidents reported immediately after the game. Players from both teams hugged each other at midfield after the game as 20,000 fans stood in ovation. Before the game, a student read a prayer and the schools' bands played ``America the Beautiful'' together. Contributing to the pre-game tension was action by Odessa football coach Jerry Taylor. He ended Permian's chances of defendingits state title when he told University Interscholastic League officials he saw the Permian team holding an organized practice before the Aug. 20 starting date. Taylor's accusation resulted in Permian's ban from the 1990 playoffs and several anonymous death threats against Taylor. Attorneys for the Permian football coaching staff filed a lawsuit against the league Friday in hopes of reversing the sanctions, which included a two-game suspension for Coach Tam Hollingshead and a year of probation for the team. The Permian Panthers, widely known as ``Mojo,'' have won five state titles and finished second four times. Permian fans also were angered by H.G. Bissinger's book, ``Friday Night Lights.'' It depicts a city where racism is rampant, football gets more attention than English class and school district lines are drawn to guarantee the best athletes play for Permian. Book-signing appearances by Bissinger in this west Texas city of 108,000 were canceled last week by bookstore owners after they received threats on the Pulitzer Prize-winning author's life. Some residents claimed Bissinger duped them into cooperating with assurances he was writing a positive account of local prep football, along the lines of ``Hoosiers,'' a heroic tale of an Indiana high school basketball team. To keep tensions at a low boil, Odessa High canceled its yearly mock funeral procession of Permian's mascot. ``This rivalry was bad enough before all the sanctions came down,'' said Candy Dennis, a Permian graduate who works at Odessa High. ``They canceled the panther funeral because they don't want any more trouble between the two schools.'' The mayor and 14 students from both schools on Wednesday videotaped a public service message they hoped will reduce animosity. ``With this appeal ... we are asking that everyone who goes to the game Friday night show the real stuff that Odessa is made of,'' Ms. Bonner said. ``Let's show everyone watching, and that's going to be a lot of people, that Odessa has a lot of strengths, too.'' Odessa High, which has not beaten Permian since 1964, was given its best chance in many years to beat Permian this year. The game at Odessa's 20,000-seat Ratliff Stadium has been sold out for days. The city's police department assigned about 50 officers to the game, ``where normally we would have no more than 20,'' said Sgt. Jim McKown. ``Tensions run high for this game even when there isn't all the added conflict, so there is a real potential for trouble.''

DOC.HEAD: Budget Negotiators Near Deadline, Talking Social Security, Capital Gains
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Inserts new 5th graf, The negotiators, to update with talks over for evening
DOC.TEXT: Negotiators for Congress and the White House opened a final-weekend search on Friday for tax increases and spending cuts acceptable to enough lawmakers to avert disruption of major government services on Monday. By most accounts, the negotiators were hung up over two perennially tough issues: Whether and how to tamper with Social Security benefits and whether and how to reuce taxes on capital gains. They were working through the Yom Kippur holiday on Saturday, and the House and Senate scheduled sessions Sunday to deal with the emergency. Differences were said to be narrowing but nobody was about to guarantee agreement before the new budget year begins Monday. ``There are some remaining issues that are very difficult that remain to be resolved,'' said House Speaker Thomas S. Foley. The negotiators quit for the day just before midnight. ``Lots of issues are left,'' Senate Republican Leader Bob Dole told reporters. ``I'm optimistic,'' Members of both parties agreed it will be no easy job getting support among rank-and-file lawmakers for whatever agreement is reached by the leaders. ``Obviously, everybody wants something to pass but very few people want to vote for it,'' Sen. Phil Gramm, R-Texas, said after briefing other GOP senators on what negotiators are doing. ``We've got a lot of heavy lifting to do'' to get any agreement enacted into law, he said. ``The best news we could get would be that the negotiators had reached an agreement,'' said Rep. Byron Dorgan, D-N.D. ``But the big question is whether it can pass Congress.'' Delaying cost-of-living increases in Social Security benefits or increasing the portion of benefits subject to tax - both options are being considered - could weaken support for the package, especially among Democrats. On the other hand, if Republicans are unhappy with the capital-gains provision or whatever offsetting tax increase on the wealthy is proposed to pay for it, they might walk away from the whole package. Sources in both parties said a recent proposal to exclude from taxation any capital gain - profit from the sale of an investment - caused solely by inflation apparently was finding little favor among negotiators. So, Republicans and Democrats exchanged new capital-gains proposals on Friday. Democrats proposed to exclude from taxation 30 percent of capital gains. In turn, the current maximum 28 percent income-tax rate on the wealthiest Americans would be raised to 32 percent. Republicans pressed instead for excluding 40 percent of capital gains while raising the maximum income-tax rate on the wealthy to 31 percent. Capital gains are taxed at the same rates as apply to wages and other income. President Bush is demanding that they be given preferential treatment as a spur to investment. Democrats, noting nearly 80 percent of such a cut would go to those with incomes over $100,000, are insisting that any capital-gains reduction be offset by raising other taxes on high-income Americans. Unless Congress and Bush can agree before Monday on a deficit-reduction package, $85 billion worth of arbitrary spending cuts will be triggered, affecting hundreds of programs though sparing others, including Social Security benefits and military pay. More than 1 million federal workers have been told to expect furloughs. Although Bush raised the specter of Social Security checks being delayed, the Social Security Administration says there is no chance of that happening immediately. October Social Security checks already have been handed over to Post Offices and should be delivered by Wednesday, said Social Security spokesman Campbell Gardett. The deficit crisis is heightened by the fact that Congress has not enacted any of the 13 annual appropriations bills. Although Congress is planning to pass stopgap legislation continuing spending authority until Oct. 20, Bush has said he will veto the measure because it also would postpone the across-the-board spending cuts. Democrats, who control the House, devised a fallback plan in case the four-month-old deficit negotiators fail to produce results by Sunday. Over opposition of Republicans, the committee cleared the way for House action on an alternative budget reflecting Democratic positions. Rep. Bill Frenzel, R-Minn., said that fallback, which envisions removing the threat of the $85 billion worth of automatic cuts, would encourage Democrats to ``bob and weave and quote Jefferson and come to no conclusion.'' Negotiators are working on a package that would cut the deficit $50 billion during the 12 months that begin Monday and an additional $450 billion in the following four years. Any agreement is expected to include higher taxes on alcoholic beverages, gasoline, cigarettes, airline tickets and such luxuries as high-priced cars and electronic equipment. Tentative agreement also has been reached on Medicare cuts totaling $60 billion over five years, federal workers' retirement benefits, farm support payments and major reductions in the defense budget.

DOC.HEAD: Magazine: Pricey Marcos Collection Not Worth the Money
DOC.TEXT: Seventy-six paintings seized from Imelda and Ferdinand Marcos are not worth the multimillion dollar price tag placed on them for auction, an arts magazine says. Experts quoted in the October issue of ARTNews said the artwork is not worth the $8.6 million to $12.5 million Christies auction house estimated they will bring at a January auction. Manhattan conservator Marco Grassi told the magazine that galleries sold Mrs. Marcos ``inferior art at superior prices.'' Ian Kennedy, vice president of Christies' Old Master paintings department, stood by the estimates. ``Of course anybody can disagree with estimates, but I am perfectly satisfied,'' he said. ``You can tell it's not garbage. A lot of these pictures have been published.'' The 76 paintings were seized by the Philippine government after Marcos was ousted and the couple fled to Hawaii in 1986. Marcos died last year. Mrs. Marcos was acquitted in July of fraud charges. Prosecutors had contended she helped her husband loot their country's treasury of more than $220 million and spent elaborately on art and other luxuries. Among the paintings scheduled for auction at Christies is one of the Madonna and child for which Mrs. Marcos paid $700,000. She was reportedly told that it was by the Renaissance master Fra Filippo Lippi, but ARTNews said it was really done by Zenobi Machiavelli, a lesser-known artist. Christies' estimate for the painting was $40,000 to $60,000. ARTNews said the most valuable artworks Mrs. Marcos owned are missing, including works by Monet, Renoir, Degas, Gauguin, Cezanne, van Gogh, Picasso, Chagall and Magritte.

DOC.HEAD: First Sex Change Operation Reported in China
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Contents may be objectionable to some readers
DOC.TEXT: Doctors in Shanghai have performed what is believed to be the first sex-change operation in China, the official Xinhua News Agency said. Xinhua reported Friday that Qin Huirong wanted to become a woman and began mutilating himself, twice cutting his genitalia. Without the sex-change operation, Qin might have died, said He Qinglian, the doctor who performed the operations. The 27-year-old graduate of Shanghai's prestigious Fudan University underwent two operations in July and August at Shanghai's Changzheng Hospital. Qin's father, a farmer, was so angry that he broke off all relations between them, the report said.Qin planned to start a new life elsewhere. ``I wish to set up a family and look for a gentleman with a background in higher education as my husband,'' Qin was quoted as saying. The sex-change operations cost about $200, the news agency said.

DOC.HEAD: EC Opens Talks With China On Restoring Relations
DOC.TEXT: China and the European Community have opened talks on restoring diplomatic relations, which were severed after the crackdown on pro-democracy demonstrators in Beijing in June 1989. Italian Foreign Minister Gianni de Michelis, current head of the 12-nation European Community, announced the development Friday after meeting with China's foreign minister, Qian Qichen. De Michelis indicated the move was linked to China's cooperation with the U.N. economic embargo on Iraq and occupied Kuwait. ``China's foreign minister has repeated to us that China will participate fully in the international effort, the international political solidarity for the application of the United Nations resolution,'' he said. De Michelis said that when the EC Council of Ministers meets in October, ``I will recommend to my colleagues to take the decision to renormalize relations with China.''

DOC.HEAD: Bahrain and Soviet Union Open Diplomatic Relations
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet Union and Bahrain re-established diplomatic relations and will exchange ambassadors soon, the Soviet Mission to the United Nations announced. Moscow has been reaching out recently to various Middle East nations. Last week, during a visit to Moscow by the Saudi foreign minister, it renewed relations broken off 52 years ago with Saui Arabia. Ties with Bahrain were announced Friday. The Soviets also have been working to restore relations with Israel and establish them with South Korea. Bahrain is an oil-rich monarchy with about 350,000 people, occupying an archipelago in the Persian Gulf. Its government is allied with Saudi Arabia and backs the U.N. sanctions against Iraq for its Aug. 2 occupation of Kuwait.

DOC.HEAD: Couple Finally Makes Wedding Portrait - Underwater
LaserPhoto HK1 of Sept. 28
DOC.TEXT: Freddie Lo and Susanna Mok finally have their wedding portrait - taken underwater in a swimming pool. The couple was married last month but city officials scuttled their plans to have their portrait taken in a municipal pool because the couple failed to apply for permission. Undaunted by the red tape and the loss of $3,800 organizing the picture session, Lo re-applied for permission, spent $5,000 more and the couple took the plunge Thursday. Lo, a foreign exchange manager and former diving coach, wore a tuxedo and his bride a white wedding gown. Both wore goggles and she had a bouquet of flowers. The bottom of the pool was carpeted with gauze and a poolside jet-sprayer created a wall of bubbles in the water. His bride spent six months taking swimming lessons to prepare for the photo session.

DOC.HEAD: Iraqi Atrocities in Kuwait May Spur Military Action, Bush Aide Says
LaserPhoto WX6
DOC.TEXT: Iraqi atrocities in occupied Kuwait could prompt the United States to return to the United Nations to seek tougher sanctions against Saddam Hussein, possibly even military action, the White House says. On Friday, Kuwait's exiled emir, Sheik Jabir al-Ahmed al-Sabah, gave President Bush a harrowing account of what the president called a ``population assaulted, incarcerated, intimidated and even murdered.'' The narrative included tales of babies being removed from incubators and critically ill patients being taken off life-support systems so that the hospital machinery could be sent back to Iraq, said national security adviser Brent Scowcroft. ``It was a pretty devastating account, especially in the face of Saddam Hussein saying he is the defender of the Arabs against the outside,'' Scowcroft said. As a result of these reports and other accounts of violence and pillaging, Bush is reviewing the possibility of seeking additional United Nations action beyond the existing trade embargo and naval and air blockades, Scowcroft said. The White House official also mentioned Iraqi threats to cut off food supplies to Westerners trapped inside Kuwait and Iraq after the Aug. 2 invasion. ``The whole element of what the Iraqis are doing inside Kuwait to a whole people could conceivably be the subject of another U.N. action,'' Scowcroft said. Asked if the United States might seek a resolution that specifically sought military action to force Iraq out of Kuwait, Scowcroft said, ``That's one of those things which is conceivable.'' Meanwhile, Rep. Les Aspin, D-Wis., chairman of the House Armed Services Committee, said he believes the administration ``is looking more favorably on an early war option.'' Aspin told reporters he based this assessment on four factors: The diminishing chances of Kuwait regaining its independence; cooler weather; Moslems' January pilgrimage to Mecca, which would make fighting then more difficult; and a more hawkish tone to recent administration remarks. Scowcroft noted that one provision of the United Nations charter that might be ``called into operation'' already establishes procedures for assembling a multinational military force under the U.N. flag. The presidential adviser noted that the charter allows the Security Council to organize military actions against a nation if other sanctions ``prove to be inadequate.'' Scowcroft said, however, that Bush did not plan to include an appeal for further United Nations action against Iraq during his visit to the world body this weekend. The president was flying to New York today for a U.N. conference on children's diseases and hunger. He will address the General Assembly on Monday. After his luncheon meeting with the exiled Kuwaiti ruler on Friday, Bush told a departure ceremony on the White House lawn, ``What normally would be a pleasurable occasion instead is a time for sobriety and sorrow.'' Bush reiterated his commitment to seek to isolate Saddam, the Iraqi president, and force withdrawal of Iraqi troops from Kuwait. ``His highness and I agreed that we must keep all our options open to ensure that Iraq's unlawful occupation of Kuwait is ended and Kuwait's legitimate government restored,'' Bush said. ``Iraq will fail,'' he declared. For his part, the exiled emir praised Bush for showing a ``principled, courageous and decisive position in the face of Iraqi aggression'' and said he hoped the president would one day be able to visit him in ``liberated, independent Kuwait.'' The White House meeting was intended as a clear sign that the United States still regards the 64-year-old emir as the legitimate ruler of Kuwait. Bush has consistently insisted that not only must Iraq withdraw its invasion troops from Kuwait but that the emir must be restored to the power he has wielded since 1977. Several hundred pro-Kuwaiti demonstrators across Pennsylvania Avenue from the White House erupted into excited cheers as Bush and the emir briefly waved to them from the front portico. Briefing reporters on the meeting, Scowcroft said a peaceful resolution to the Persian Gulf crisis remained in everyone's best interest. ``The sanctions have not been in place very long,'' he said. But, he added, ``there is no question that what's happening inside Kuwait affect the timetable. There is no question about that. But I think we need to at least come to a sincere judgment as to whether or not there's a peaceful way to resolve this.'' An administration official, speaking on condition of anonymity, said a request might come before the United Nations within a week or so, likely at the request of Kuwait, for a resolution condemning Iraq's treatment of Kuwait.

DOC.HEAD: Administration Sticking With 5 Million Barrel Sale of Stockpiled Oil
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration is moving ahead with a test sale of 5 million barrels of stockpiled oil, despite contentions by lawmakers and its own energy secretary that the amount is too small. The Energy Department sent out formal notices of the sale Friday as the House voted to give President Bush authority to triple its size, as recommended a day earlier by Energy Secretary James Watkins. The White House stopped short of disavowing Watkins' suggestion that the 5-million-barrel sale announced by Bush on Wednesday was too small to even test how the 590-million-barrel Strategic Petroleum Reserve might work in an oil emergency. ``We'd have to look at'' any proposal to expand it, said Steven Hart, a White House spokesman. But Watkins' testimony and the House's prompt response to it amid a doubling of crude oil prices since July left the administration scrambling to find a single policy voice on using the reserve. Although the embargo against Iraq and Kuwait removed 4.3 million barrels of oil daily from the world market, large inventories and shipments already on the ocean have prevented any actual shortages from developing so far. But the anticipation of shortages as winter approaches and commercial stocks begin to decline has sent prices from about $21 a barrel when Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2 to $39 this week. The administration contended for nearly two months that the reserve, built at a cost of $20 billion to taxpayers after the 1973 Arab oil embargo, was never intended to counter escalating oil prices. However, White House press secretary Marlin Fitzwater said Wednesday that one of the purposes of the test is ``acting against what we believe is speculation in terms of unwarranted price increases.'' Lawmakers have embraced claims by market analysts that Bush could have stopped the price spiral at $25 to $27 per barrel by tapping the reserve last month at a rate of 500,000 barrels a day. ``Since Aug. 2, $4 billion more in energy prices have been paid by American consumers than should have been,'' Rep. Edward Markey, D-Mass., said Friday. ``Businesses are being driven into recession by this head-in-the-sand energy policy the administration has adopted.'' The Energy Department has the capability to pump up to 3.5 million barrels of oil a day from the stockpile, which is stored in salt deposits along the Louisiana-Texas coast. Rep. W.J. Tauzin, D-La., who guided a bill authorizing a 15-million-barrel test sale through the House on Friday, said the administration had vowed just two weeks ago that Bush would veto legislation with a test sale above 5 million barrels. Watkins, however, told the House Energy and Commerce Committee on Thursday that a 15-million-barrel test was needed. ``It's our belief the secretary of energy was correct,'' Tauzin said. ``There are no shortages. But fears of shortages are allowing speculators on Wall Street to drive up prices and take advantage of consumers.'' Sens. Joseph Lieberman, D-Conn., and Carl Levin, D-Mich., introduced a Senate bill Friday for a 15-million-barrel sale. ``The road in the Senate may not be so smooth,'' said an administration source, who acknowledged efforts under way there to prevent a vote on the proposal. Meanwhile, the Energy Department said it will open bids on the 5-million-barrel sale Oct. 5 and sign the first contracts with the successful bidders a week later for an average daily release of 167,000 barrels. ``If a buyer can arrange for a tanker to be at the dock, we could load oil the next day,'' said DOE spokesman Bob Porter. ``But we expect most of these deliveries to occur in November.'' Potential buyers will have to bid for minimum quantities of 200,000 barrels if delivery is to be by tanker, 75,000 barrels by pipeline and 40,000 barrels by barge.

DOC.HEAD: Backers of Cable Controls Vow Tougher Bill Next Year
DOC.TEXT: Backers of legislation to re-regulate cable television prices and services say that despite a Senate defeat, they'll be back next year with an even tougher bill. Sen. Timothy Wirth, D-Colo., on Friday objected to bringing the bill to the floor for debate or a vote, where it was expected to pass easily. Faced with a possible filibuster, a sponsor of the bill, Sen. Daniel Inouye, D-Hawaii, declared the measure ``dead and buried'' for the 101st Congress. Congress is expected to adjourn as early as the middle of October. Backers of the bill said the cable industry's victory may be short-lived and that it would only strengthen the hand of would-be competitors. Home satellite companies are itching to compete with cable and are expected to push provisions of the Senate bill that guarantee them access to cable programming. Broadcasters also want cable to pay for the programming it now takes virtually for free. ``There may come a time when the cable industry will devoutly wish they had taken today's deal,'' said Edward O. Fritts, president of the National Association of Broadcasters. ``This bill was like inpatient surgery on the cable industry dealing with surface wounds,'' said Gene Kimmelman, legislative director of the Consumer Federation of America. ``My guess is that next year's bill is going to be like heart and brain surgery combined.'' The Office of Management and Budget had issued a veto warning on the bill, which would have restored some of the government oversight of cable that Congress lifted in 1984. OMB said the bill imposed too many restrictions on cable and that increased competition - perhaps from the telephone industry - was the answer to any problems in the cable industry. Basic cable prices on average have risen 43 percent in the past three years. Wirth said service and prices had been the driving forces behind the bill, ``but we have gone far beyond that. ... There are some provisions in there that don't have anything to do with rates or service.'' Cable executives had said they could live with some form of rate re-regulation, but they bitterly opposed provisions that would have imposed strict business restrictions on their industry, including banning exclusive programming contracts. Nonetheless, the bill had been expected to pass by a wide margin. A similar version sailed through the House on a voice vote earlier this month. ``Consumers are outraged and we have the opportunity to do something about it. And we will do something about it next year,'' said Sen. John Danforth, R-Mo., one of the bill's architects. ``But as for now, the cable companies have won. They get to increase the price of service and allow the quality of service to deteriorate until the Congress acts.'' The legislation would require cable systems to provide a ``basic tier'' of local broadcast and public TV channels and require the FCC to monitor rates for cable-owned programming such as MTV. The House bill would prohibit programmers owned by cable operators from ``unreasonably refusing to deal'' with competitors and require them to provide their signals to backyard satellite users.

DOC.HEAD: $150,000 To Feinstein In Wake Of Court Ruling
DOC.TEXT: A highway patrolmen's group gave Democratic gubernatorial nominee Dianne Feinstein a $150,000 contribution, a donation made possible by a federal judge's ruling overturning contribution limits for statewide candidates. U.S. District Judge Lawrence Karlton of Sacramento was asked Friday to delay his ruling while the initiative's backers appeal it. He later rejected the request. The decision six weeks before the Nov. 6 election has turned campaign funding into chaos. Meanwhile, Republican Pete Wilson began television ads claiming overwhelming police support. Wilson was endorsed by the California Narcotics Officers Association, which represents 5,000 federal, state and local anti-drug officers.
DOC.HEAD: Lieutenant Governor TV - Positive So Far
DOC.TEXT: In a campaign year splattered by mudslinging television ads, there's a little good humor in the lieutenant governor's race between Bob Bullock and Rob Moosebacker, er Meesebecker, er whatshisname. Neither candidate so far is using a TV ad attacking the other. Democrat Bullock touts his record in state government, and GOP candidate Rob Mosbacher Jr. pokes fun at his lack of name identification. The Republican's 30-second spot features a line of folks mispronouncing his name - ``Messbacker ... Mossmacker ... Mossbicker ... Muckbacker.'' Interrupting now and then are the candidate and his children, chuckling and explaining: ``No, Mosbacher.'' ``Because of the nasty, negative natureof the campaigns through the summer on television by many of the candidates, we decided to try to do something a little different,'' said Mark Sanders, Mosbacher's press secretary. The Mosbacher ad was the candidate's own idea, although some advisers initially were skeptical, Sanders said. Bullock, meanwhile, is emphasizing his accomplishments at the comptroller's office, where he has served for five terms. His commercials end by calling him ``an independent voice for Texas.'' ``He shakes up the bureaucrats, says no to special interests, no to high insurance rates and forces out-of-state corporations to pay billions in taxes,'' the ad says.
DOC.HEAD: Rinfret Continues To Shake Up GOP
DOC.TEXT: Republican candidate for governor Pierre Rinfret's campaign claims that state GOP Chairman J. Patrick Barrett had offered to resign. A top aide to Barrett quickly denied Friday that any such offer had been made. Rinfret strategist Eddie Mahe and campaign spokesman Ted Kavanau both insisted that Barrett had offered to step down earlier this week, but was asked to stay on by Rinfret. ``That is not true,'' said Barrett aide Elizabeth DelTorto angrily. ``Pat did not offer to resign.'' Rinfret, whose campaign tactics of late have been termed ``bizarre'' by one former state GOP chairman, first mentioned the Barrett resignation offer during a flight to the Utica area Thursday. During that flight, Rinfret also said he might seek the state chairmanship if he lost his bid to unseat Democratic Gov. Mario Cuomo. A recent independent statewide poll showed Cuomo with a massive lead over Rinfret, a millionaire economist making his first run for public office. ``I'm sure Pat Barrett will step aside for me,'' said Rinfret, adding later that Barrett ``hasn't been a leader.'' Barrett, a former head of the Avis car rental company, has said previously that he has no intention of leaving the party chairmanship.
DOC.HEAD: Environmental Group Says Helms Ad a Distortion
DOC.TEXT: A new Jesse Helms television ad touting his support for environmental legislation ``is a calculated distortion of his disgraceful record,'' the North Carolina Sierra Club chapter says. The Helms campaign said the Sierra Club was distorting the Republican senator's record. ``If you believe that Jesse Helms is a friend of the environment, then you'd believe that Saddam Hussein is a peace-loving man and a friend to motorists everywhere,'' said Randy Schenck, the state Sierra Club conservation chairman. The 30-second television commercial for Helms' Senate campaign says Democratic challenger Harvey Gantt, while mayor of Charlotte, asked to have his city exempted from the Clean Air Act. It also says that Helms has supported bills to make oil companies clean up spills and to protect the New River from being dammed.

DOC.HEAD: Forest Service Says Logging Ban Will Affect 3 Million Acres
DOC.TEXT: The Forest Service says saving the northern spotted owl from extinction will require banning logging next year on 3 million acres of the Northwest's oldest forests. And some lawmakers, while fearful of the impact on timber jobs, say they are optimistic that adoption of a credible protection plan will help avert environmental lawsuits that threaten to bring the region's logging to a standstill. Concerned that its current protection plan may violate the Endangered Species Act, the Forest Service announced Friday it will follow instead the recommendations offered in April by one of its biologists, Jack Ward Thomas, and a panel of government scientists. Congressmen said the move will mean greater cuts in logging than the White House predicted last week. The Forest Service estimated last spring that the Thomas plan would cause federal timber harvests in the Northwest to fall by nearly 50 percent and result in the loss of more than 20,000 logging jobs. However, President Bush last week endorsed a finding by a White House task force that the owl could be saved from extinction by reducing next year's harvests by only about 20 percent - from this year's 3.85 billion board feet to about 3 billion board feet. Rep. Denny Smith, R-Ore., said Friday's announcement by the Forest Service means that harvests will tumble to about 2.6 billion board feet. ``This is just a further cave-in to the folks that are trying to put us out of business,'' said Smith, a strong supporter of the timber industry. The action came as environmentalists were preparing to return to federal court in Seattle to try to force the Forest Service to accept a scientifically sound plan to protect the spotted owl's habitat in the Northwest's old-growth forests. The Fish and Wildlife Service on June 22 declared the rare owl a threatened species under the Endangered Species Act. An estimated 3,000 pair live in the Pacific Northwest, their only habitat. Lawmakers said the Thomas proposal would be the most sweeping protection of wildlife in the history of the act, banning logging on 3 million acres of national forests currently open to harvests - an area larger than the state of Maryland. Rep. Norm Dicks, D-Wash., said implementation of the Thomas plan should help prevent an onslaught of environmental lawsuits that could block the sale of much greater amounts of timber. Todd True, an attorney for the Sierra Club Legal Defense Fund, said the action was overdue. ``Certainly it is appropriate that the old (plan) has been thrown out and recognized as the poor job it has always been,'' the environmental lawyer said. But Evelyn Badger of the pro-industry Oregon Lands Coalition said the announcement means that Forest Service Chief Dale Robertson ``has just signed eviction notices for tens of thousands of families in the Northwest.'' The Thomas plan will remain in force until Congress adopts another plan or the Fish and Wildlife Service adopts a permanent recovery plan for the owl.

DOC.HEAD: Tanker, Barge Collide in Houston Ship Channel
DOC.TEXT: Darkness hampered a Coast Guard effort to determine the extent of a petroleum spill from a collision Friday between a tanker and a barge, authorities said. A tanker struck one of two barges being towed by a tugboat in the Houston Ship Channel, where about 700,000 gallons of oil spilled in a July accident, the Coast Guard said. The leaking barge contained reformate, a volatile, colorless liquid product of petroleum distillation that is used as a manufacturing solvent, a dry-cleaning fluid and a gasoline-blending stock. The Coast Guard's marine safety office in Galveston said the collision occurred at 9 p.m. about 3 miles east of a Galveston Bay beach. Details remained sketchy early today. No injuries were reported. Coast Guard Cmdr. Frank Whipple said darkness prevented authorities from determining the extent of the spill. The 538-foot-long Norwegian tanker, designed to carry a chemical cargo of undetermined size, was not damaged, Whipple said. A slick formed from the leaking barge and a spill response team from contractor Garner Environmental Co. of Houston was sent to the spill, he said. The collision occurred as the tanker was leaving Houston and the 297-foot-long barges, both loaded with reformate, were coming in, Whipple said. ``The tug was able to push the barges out of the channel and up onto the bank,'' Whipple said. ``They are resting on the bank.'' The July 28 collision between the Greek tanker Shinoussa and two barges in the ship channel spewed crude oil into the environmentally sensitive bay. On June 8, the Norwegian tanker Mega Borg was rocked by an explosion about 58 miles offshore from Galveston, dumping more than 3.9 million gallons of oil.

DOC.HEAD: GAO Doubts Ability of Anti-Tank Apache Helicopters to Fight
DOC.TEXT: The Army's Apache anti-tank helicopter needs repairs after an average 2{ hours in the air during peacetime and may be useless in war, say congressional investigators. The Apache's see-in-the-dark electronics, 30mm cannon, guided missiles and rockets make it a powerful tank killer when in operation. It has been deployed to Saudi Arabia in Operation Desert Shield. The Army has ordered all but 66 of 807 Apaches it planned to purchase from McDonnel-Douglas Corp. for $12 billion. But the General Accounting Office, in a report issued Friday, said rather than buy more of the helicopters, the Army should beef up the maintenance organization devoted to the aircraft. A similar GAO recommendation was made in April, when the Army had 132 choppers to go, but another 66 helicopters were bought anyway. Investigators said the Army has too few Apache mechanics. About 100 maintenance personnel assigned to an Apache battalion take care of 39 helicopters, including 18 Apaches. The Marine Corps, however, achieves far more flying hours with 225 technicians taking care of 24 simpler helicopters. The GAO said in April that Apaches were ``fully mission capable'' only about half the time, far short of the Army's 70 percent goal. The figure was repeated in Friday's report. ``Why buy more headaches?'' Richard Davis, director of the GAO's Army Issues Group, asked in an April appearance before Congress. ``Use the money to operate and fix existing Apaches.'' ``Given that the Apache has not been able to attain availability goals in peacetime despite favorable conditions, it is questionable whether it can meet the far more strenuous demands of high-intensity combat,'' the GAO said in the Friday report. The GAO said the aircraft's electronics fault detection system about 40 percent of the time detects a fault that does not actually exist. In addition, soldiers maintaining the Apache spend only about 30 percent of their time repairing the aircraft. They spend the rest of their time on required assignments such as guard duty, physical training, motor pool detail, marksmanship testing and other such tasks. For this reason, re-enlistment rates are low and experienced mechanics rare in Apache battalions. Components fail at rates far higher than expected when the aircraft was designed - for instance, the main rotors must be replaced every 164 hours instead of lasting 1,500 hours, GAO said. According to the GAO, the Army's commander in Europe has said ``as much as 50 percent of the time Apaches spend in the hangars for maintenance is devoted to troubleshooting and that this time was increasing.'' In an Aug. 31 letter to the GAO, David J. Berteau, principal deputy assistant secretary of defense for production and logistics, said the agency's findings ``mostly portray the readiness and support problems of the Apache helicopter of about 18-24 months ago and were not new to the Army.'' Maj. Nancy Burt said Friday that the Army and McDonnell Douglas had identified 173 problems, resolved 106 and are fixing 67. Burt also said that Apaches sent to the Persian Gulf have exceed the service's goals for capability. In April, GAO officials testified that the Army handpicked six of its best Apaches for the invasion of Panama last December. One helicopter never took off because of a hydraulic failure, the fuel cell failed in another and still another was forced to return to the base when its target detection system didn't work, the GAO said. Complicating matters were the helicopters' sensitive electronic components that failed to work when rain and humidity caused a build up of moisture. Army officials were forced to dry the parts in kitchen ovens, the GAO said. The GAO report was requested by Rep. Les Aspin, D-Wis., chairman of the House Armed Services Committee, and Rep. John Dingell, D-Mich., chairman of the House Energy and Commerce Committee and its panel on oversight and investigations.

DOC.HEAD: Iranians Condemn U.S.; Iraq Warns of War; British Troops Head For Gulf
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 2 grafs to UPDATE with British ground troops on their way to gulf. Pickup 2nd graf `President Bush...'; SUBS 18th graf `Iraq's army...' with 3 grafs of details. Pickup 19th graf `The main...'; EDITS to trim and conform
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos MOSB2, MLA11, WX20, AMM1
DOC.TEXT: Millions of Iranians on Friday protested the U.S.-led forces in the Persian Gulf with chants of ``Death to America!'' and Iraq warned that war in the region would ravage other Arab states and Israel. Also Friday, Britain began sending some of the 6,000 ground troops it promised to add to the forces in the Saudi Desert, the Defense Ministry in London said. President Bush promised the exiled leader of Kuwait that his country will not remain under Iraqi control. ``Kuwait's sovereignty and territorial integrity will be restored,'' Bush said after meeting with Sheik Jaber al-Ahmed al-Sabah. The White House meeting was intended as a sign that the United States still regards the emir as the legitimate ruler of Kuwait, which Iraq invaded Aug. 2. A Bush aide said the graphic account of the Iraqi occupation that the exiled ruler gave Bush could lead the president to push for tougher U.N. action against Saddam Hussein, including U.N.-backed military action. ``That's one of those things that's conceivable,'' said Brent Scowcroft, the president's national security adviser. Al-Sabah described ``terrifying conditions'' in Kuwait, including soldiers taking patients off life support systems and removing babies from incubators so the equipment could be shipped back to Iraq, Scowcroft said. Rep. Les Aspin, the chairman of the House Armed Services Committee, said he feels the administration ``is looking more favorably on an early war option.'' The Wisconsin Democrat said he based this assessment on four factors: The diminishing chances of Kuwait regaining its independence, cooler weather, Moslems' January pilgrimage to Mecca, which would make fighting then more difficult, and a more hawkish tone to Bush administration remarks. Tehran radio, monitored in Nicosia, said millions of Iranians staged demonstrations nationwide, denouncing the United States and Israel. ``We have seen how they have defiled our sacred lands, the land of divine revelations, just as they did in Jerusalem, by bringing corruption, devastation, godlessness and debauchery to that hallowed region,'' a reporter said in a live report from the Tehran rally. Iran has condemned Iraq's invasion of Kuwait, but it also has deplored the U.S.-led forces sent to protect Saudi Arabia and enforce a U.N.-imposed embargo against Baghdad. It says it is honoring the blockade, however. The protests capped a week of celebrations marking the anniversary of the beginning of the 1980-88 Iran-Iraq war. Iran sees cause for celebration because last month Baghdad caved in to its demands for peace, ending two years of deadlocked talks. Some observers say that in return Baghdad expects Iran to circumvent the embargo and deliver food to Iraq. Iraq's government newspaper Al-Jomhouriya again warned about widespread devastation if war broke out. ``The battle arenas would be multiple and the fires would devour all oil fields, the Zionist entity and agents of America in the region,'' it said in an editorial. The newspaper was referring to Israel and Egypt, Syria, Morocco, and Arab Gulf states cooperating with the United States in the multinational buildup following the invasion of Kuwait. British ground forces bound for the gulf began leaving ports in Britain and Germany, the Defense Ministry said in London. Initial estimates put the number of troops of the 7th Armored Brigade and support units being sent to the gulf at between 6,000 and 8,000. But The Times of London said Saturday that the number could reach 9,000. Three thousand British military personnel aboard ships or with air force fighter units are already in the gulf. The main weapon of Iraq's opponents in the gulf standoff has been the economic embargo imposed by the United Nations. The world body this week extended the land and sea blockade to the air. Foreign ministers from the United States, Britain, China, France and the Soviet Union met with U.N. Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar, and released another statement condemning the Iraqi invasion, while emphasizing their commitment to seeking a peaceful solution. Chinese Foreign Minister Qian Qichen addressed the issue in a speech to the U.N. General Assembly in which he omitted China's standard opposition to ``big power'' involvement in the gulf. Western diplomats said the omission could reflect greater Chinese acceptance of, and possibly support for, the U.S. military buildup in Saudi Arabia. The commander of the American battle group patrolling outside the gulf said Friday he doubted that ships were evading it by hugging the Iranian coast. ``Personally I feel that we are being 100 percent effective,'' said Rear Adm. Jerry Unruh. ``Iraq may be loading their ships with oil, but their ships are not coming out.'' Turkey enforced the air embargo by searching Indian, Soviet and Polish planes bound for Baghdad. In Paris, representatives of the United States and 20 industrialized nations met to discuss how to replenish oil supplies if they are depleted by the crisis. The nations are members of the International Energy Agency, which issued a communique that said it was preparing to protect the West from an oil supply crisis but that there was no immediate need to use strategic reserves to offset embargoed oil from Iraq and Kuwait. If a significant oil shortfall develops, the board will hold an emergency session, the communique said. Investor fears sent some stock markets plunging. Stock prices dropped to the lowest point in 3{ years in Tokyo, and analysts blamed fear of war in the Middle East, high interest rates and climbing oil prices. The U.S. government said its main economic forecasting gauge - the Index of Leading Economic Indicators - declined 1.2 percent in August following the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait, the steepest drop in three years. In other developments: -The Iraqi News Agency said radical Palestinian leader Mohammed Abbas vowed to strike American interests if any Iraqi aircraft were attacked to enforce the air embargo. -A grenade attack killed the 9-year-old son of a French soldier and wounded 17 other people in the Red Sea nation of Djibouti, which has served as a staging ground for French forces in the Persian Gulf, officials said. No one immediately claimed responsibility for the attack Thursday night and it was unknown wether it was linked to the gulf crisis. -Spain and South Korea joined other nations in pulling envoys from embassies besieged by Iraqi troops in Kuwait. -Bulgaria has offered to send 400 troops to the gulf, the U.S. State Department said. The Poles, Czechs and Romanians have offered medical facilities.

DOC.HEAD: Environmental Group Seeks to Block Discovery Launch
DOC.TEXT: An environmental activist group is seeking a federal court order to stop the scheduled launch next week of the space shuttle Discovery with the nuclear-powered Ulysses sun probe in its cargo bay. ``We have an extraordinary risk here from an agency whose competency in the last year has been abysmal,'' said Andrew C. Kimbrell, a lawyer for the Foundation on Economic Trends, which asked Friday for a preliminary injunction. The organization's motion is the latest round in a legal battle begun last year when the National Aeronautics and Space Administration dispatched the Galileo probe to Jupiter from shuttle Atlantis. At that time, U.S. District Judge Oliver Gasch refused to stop the launch and Galileo was sent on its way. The foundation's Friday motion was made part of that earlier suit, brought by the Florida Coalition on Peace and Justice. The coalition staged a demonstration last Saturday at the Kennedy Space Center. ``It was not unexpected,'' said NASA general counsel Edward Frankle. ``It's basically similar to the one that was done last year in Galileo and I hope it has the same result.'' Both planetary probes use electricity generated by decaying radioactive pellets of plutonium-238, which causes cancer and death in humans if inhaled. The United States has launched 23 missions with nuclear power sources; three have had accidents, including one that released radioactive materials. NASA said the risk with Ulysses is minimal. Galileo carried 49.6 pounds of plutonium to provide power for the $1.5 million probe on its six-year journey, during which it will twice fly close to Earth for added momentum. The Ulysses probe, which is to be ejected from Discovery's cargo bay hours after the shuttle launch Oct. 6, carries just under 23.7 pounds of plutonium-238, which Kimbrell called ``one of the most toxic substances known to man.'' The current complaint restates the risk of a Challenger-like explosion on launch and introduces an element not present last year: the fuel leaks that three times have stopped the launch of shuttle Columbia since May. NASA has grounded the shuttle until an investigative team solves the problems. ``Until NASA shows it can become competent again, it should not be in the business of putting nuclear fuel in space,'' Kimbrell said. The motion to Gasch says the challenged launch ``comes at a time of crisis and confusion at NASA.'' It said the agency is being criticized in Congress and elsewhere ``for unreliability in predicting mission goals and risks and lack of quality control.'' ``Basically, we are saying where are their studies on where the hydrogen leaks are coming from,'' Kimbrell said. ``Where are the hard numbers on radiation risks on actual risks of a shuttle explosion?'' The government has until Tuesday to respond.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Rules Chicago Tribune Violated Labor Law
DOC.TEXT: The Chicago Tribune violated federal labor law by not signing a new contract with 427 striking mailers and must pay any wages or benefits lost, an administrative law judge has ruled. A union official said the cost could run as high as $10 million. Robert A. Giannasi, an administrative law judge with the National Labor Relations Board, said the newspaper should pay the 1985 strikers for any loss of wages or benefits since July 27, 1987, when the Chicago Mailers Union Local 2 accepted a Tribune-offered contract that the newspaper then refused to sign. The Tribune held that the union no longer was the workers' bargaining representative, the newspaper reported Friday. The story added that the newspaper planned to appeal the decision, which was released Thursday. Giannasi's order also requires that the newspaper pay back wages at the higher, negotiated rate to about 200 workers who replaced striking mailers. ``We're just guessing, but this could cost the Tribune better than $10 million,'' said Robert C. Maida, secretary-treasurer of Chicago Mailers Local 2.

DOC.HEAD: Strange Bedfellows in Gulf Crisis: King Hussein And Old PLO Foes
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: One of the most intriguing political realignments triggered by the Persian Gulf crisis is the one between King Hussein of Jordan and radical PLO factions he has feuded with for 20 years. George Habash of the Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine and Nayef Hawatmeh of the Marxist Democratic Front for the Liberation of Palestine were feted as heroes when they returned to Jordan last week for the first time in two decades. They left as the sworn enemies of Hussein but returned to Amman as allies, thrown into his arms by political fallout in the wake of the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait. Hussein has pledged to honor the U.N. sanctions against Iraq, but the king steered clear of a confrontation with Saddam Hussein. Jordan is heavily reliant on Iraq for trade and cheap oil. Jordan's 3 million Palestinian residents - half its population - strongly back Saddam, who has positioned himself as the champion of Palestinians in the territories occupied by Israel. Meanwhile, the Palestine Liberation Organization led by Yasser Arafat has turned away from Syrian President Hafez Assad, a traditional foe of Saddam who has sent troops to bolster the multinational force in Saudi Arabia. The warm reception for Habash and Hawatmeh in Amman last week appalled the U.S. State Department. Habash described his meeting with the monarch at his palace Sept. 18 as cordial. ``We came out with the impression that we share the same political ground ... We're facing a common danger,'' he told reporters. Habash and Hawatmeh were received by the king ``more as old friends, rather than former deadly enemies,'' a senior Jordanian official said. ``You wouldn't have thought that 20 years ago the two Palestinians were fighting to topple the king or have him assassinated,'' said the official, speaking on condition of anonymity. Many Palestinians had moved into Jordan after the 1967 war in which Israel occupied the West Bank and Gaza. In 1970, Habash's guerrillas hijacked three airliners and blew them up in the Jordanian desert, after evacuating the passengers. Hussein, fearing that the growing power of the PLO threatened his Hashemite throne and was drawing punitive Israeli military strikes against Jordan, decided to move against them. Habash and Hawatmeh fled Amman on Sept. 30, 1970, after 13 days of fierce house-to-house fighting between Palestinian guerrillas and King Hussein's tough Bedouin troopers. The Palestinians suffered close to 10,000 casualties during ``Black September'' and began referring to the king as the ``Butcher of Amman.'' Government forces lost more than 600 dead and 1,500 wounded. Many of the Palestinians leaders dispersed to Damascus or Lebanon, where their heavily armed presence and alliance with leftist Moslems contributed to the outbreak of the Lebanese civil war, which continues today. Ironically, King Hussein could yet find his throne in danger again. He has already paid a high price for his support for Iraq. Saudi Arabia last week cut off financial aid worth $300 million a year to the economically strapped kingdom and blocked oil deliveries. Political and diplomatic sources in Amman believe that any attempt by the king to adopt a more pro-American stand would spark off massive protests that could endanger the throne. Crown Prince Hassan, the king's brother, complained Friday of a lack of understanding from the West. Jordan was respecting sanctions, he said, even though it has meant a 50 percent decline in the gross national product. ``Is it expected that Jordan commit economic hari kari?'' he said during a conference in Washington. ``Are we expected to commit economic suicide?''

DOC.HEAD: Names in the News
LaserPhoto NY14
DOC.TEXT: It won't happen next season, but there might still be a move in store for Roseanne Barr's hit television show. Tom Arnold, Barr's husband, said earlier this week they plan to buy a house in the Twin Cities and bring with them production of ``Roseanne,'' possibly as early as next season. David Brokaw, a spokesman for the company that produces the ABC series, said Friday the move is too expensive and will not happen any time soon. ``But we will definitely take a look at it in the future,'' Brokaw said in a statement he issued jointly with Barr and Arnold. Arnold said he and Barr want out of the ``loony bin'' that passes for their life in Los Angeles. --- SOUTH ORANGE, N.J. (AP) - Archbishop Desmond Tutu says the United States is vacillating on the value of sanctions against South Africa's apartheid government. Tutu spoke Friday at Seton Hall University, where he was honored for his civil rights work on behalf of blacks in South Africa. He told a crowd of about 500 people that sanctions should be maintained until apartheid is dismantled. ``We hope your government is not going to lift sanctions prematurely,'' Tutu said. Tutu, who won the Nobel Peace Prize in 1984, heads the 2.6 million-member Anglican Church of the Province of Southern Africa. --- LINCOLN, Neb. (AP) - Arnold Schwarzenegger wants to pump up Nebraska and the rest of the United States. The actor and bodybuilder told a crowd of more than 4,000 people Friday he plans to visit every state to promote fitness as chairman of the President's Council on Physical Fitness. He told the crowd at the University of Nebraska Coliseum that he'll return to the state to check on the progress of physical education and fitness programs in schools. --- EAST LANSING, Mich. (AP) - Zimbabwe President Robert G. Mugabe, at a ceremony in which Michigan State University gave him an honorary doctor of laws degree, said there are new signs of hope for democracy in South Africa. Mugabe, Zimbabwe's first president elected under majority rule, said at Friday's ceremony he hopes current peace initiatives in South Africa will lead to elimination of apartheid and ``create a non-racial democratic order as a new political reality.'' ``Hence encouragement should be given to all forces fighting to dismantle apartheid and to replace it with the desired just social and political order,'' Mugabe said. --- CHICAGO (AP) - A South Side street that was once a hub for jazz and blues will be renamed after the late Sammy Davis Jr. Davis, who died this summer of cancer, performed in Chicago throughout his career, beginning in the early 1940s. ``Legendary artists of the '30s, '40s and '50s were showcased in clubs and theaters and even private homes that lined 31st Street, which was once the hub of jazz and blues,'' Mayor Richard M. Daley said. ``Thus it's only fitting that this street is chosen to honor one of the greatest performers in show business, the late Sammy Davis Jr,'' he said. City officials planned a ceremony Thursday to change the street's name. -- NASHVILLE, Tenn. (AP) - Former President Reagan renewed his friendship with country-music king Roy Acuff during a visit to the Music City to address a bottlers convention. Acuff and Reagan spent about 15 minutes together Friday night, discussing sports, retirement and other topics, said Grand Ole Opry spokesman Jerry Strobel. ``Mr. Acuff wanted to thank him for coming to Nashville for his 81st birthday celebration in 1984,'' Strobel said. ``And President Reagan said, `Glad to do it - it's always a treat to see Roy Acuff.' '' The men have been friends since the 1940s, when Reagan was president of the Screen Actors Guild and Acuff was in Hollywood making movies. Reagan also served as honorary chairman of a May 1984 tribute to Acuff at the Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts in Washington.

DOC.HEAD: Negotiators Continue Working for Budget Accord
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Talks resume noon EDT; lead prospects uncertain.
DOC.TEXT: Weary congressional and Bush administration officials headed today into what could be a last-ditch attempt to fashion a deficit reduction agreement and avoid massive cuts in federal services Monday morning. ``Lots of issues are left,'' Senate Republican leader Bob Dole of Kansas told reporters after a lengthy session ended late Friday night. Dole added, ``I'm optimistic. We are committed to getting it done.'' A source familiar with the negotiations said Republicans indicated they might be ready to give up their insistence on a capital gains tax cut demanded by President Bush - the issue that has been the source of most of the debate during the more than four months of budget talks. Democrats have claimed that the tax, which is charged against the profits on property sales, is of primary benefit to the rich. The source, who spoke only on condition of anonymity, said the bargainers tentatively agreed to scale back a planned increase in taxes on beer, wine and liquor and to impose some new limitations on the total amount of itemized deductions allowed for high income couples and individuals. The House and Senate scheduled rare Sunday sessions in anticipation of an agreement that would cut the deficit by about $50 billion during the budget year that begins Monday and by another $450 billion in the following four years. Monday could be chaotic for federal workers and for users of many government services unless a deficit reduction package is produced. If no agreement is in place, $85 billion in arbitrary spending reductions will be forced on hundreds of government programs ranging from meat inspection to air traffic control. Social Security, military and congressional salaries, and many initiatives for the poor are exempt from the cuts. But more than 1 million of the 2.1 million civilian federal workers already have received notices that they will be furloughed up to 22 days during the next year. The office of Management and Budget told agency heads Friday that all employees should report to work on Monday and those considered nonessential would be sent home. The situation is made worse by the fact that Congress has failed to enact any of the 13 annual appropriation bills for the new budget year. Lawmakers are ready to approve stopgap legislation to extend spending authority for another 20 days, but Bush has promised to veto the measure unless it is striped of a provision postponing the mandatory $85 billion in cuts until Oct. 20. The president insists that the pressure of mandatory cuts is necessary to force agreement on a package of targeted spending reductions and tax increases. Among the most contentious issues still to be resolved is whether Social Security beneficiaries should be made to pay a greater share of the deficit reduction cost. One proposal under consideration would increase from 50 percent to 85 percent the share of Social Security benefits on which higher income recipients could be taxed. Another would delay for two or three months the Jan. 19, 1991 cost of living increase in benefits.

DOC.HEAD: Gridlock, Protests, Security Sweeps. It's General Assembly Time
With PM-UN-Children, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: World-class gridlock, protests galore and security sweeps at Bergdorf Goodman before the arrival of important shoppers make it General Assembly time again in the Big Apple. And this year the ranks of world leaders at the United Nations are swollen by the pull of the World Summit for Children. Earlybirds zipped around at various events Friday - President Patricio Aylwin of Chile speaking at a foreign affairs forum; Japanese Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu picking up an honorary degree at New York University; Queen Fabiola of Belgium visiting the Covenant House shelter for runaways. Some of the 160 expected leaders, including heads of state and foreign ministers, are staying at their nation's embassies. For the rest, Manhattan hotels readied a welcome. ``Our Indianapolis 500,'' said Jim Mastrangelo, sales manager of the United Nations Plaza Hotel. There will be no speedway, however. ``This will be the largest number of world dignitaries assembled in New York at one time,'' said city Transportation Commissioner Lucius Riccio. ``There is the potential for a very large international gridlock.'' Only President Bush, expected to arrive today, gets traffic frozen. Police planned to immobilize cars and pedestrians along the president's route. On past visits, the freezes have lasted an hour. Bush was scheduled to address the United Nations Monday. Various groups have scheduled a score of demonstrations around U.N. events, and the dignitaries may also run into other protests. For example, should any of them pop into a fast food joint for a snack, they might encounter members of the Coalition to Liberate Animals Worldwide. The coalition promised to make dining uncomfortable for meat-eaters at various chain diners in midtown. Shoppers at the swank Bergdorf Goodman witnessed a sweep Thursday by phalanxes of security men in advance of a browse by a foreign bigwig. ``They're big shoppers,'' said Elizabeth Maguire, speaking for the Plaza hotel, where Suzan Mubarak, wife of Egypt's president, and a number of other international guests are staying. ``But the rumor is that they've all been clued into Secaucus,'' she added, referring to a bustling discount center across the Hudson River in New Jersey.

DOC.HEAD: 89-Year-Old Twins Shutting Landmark Diner
DOC.TEXT: Business is booming at the Twins Cafe since the 89-year sisters who own it decided to close up after 37 years. Twins Hassie Seivers and Lassie Disney have had enough of their grueling 4 a.m. to 4 p.m., six-day-a-week, cooking-to-cleaning schedule. On Oct. 6, the day this East Tennessee town celebrates its 100th birthday, the twins will dish up food and conversation for the last time. ``It's not retirement. We're just quitting work,'' Lassie said. ``We're not exactly quitting,'' Hassie added. ``We're changing.'' Their cafe is a four-booth, six-table, five-stools-at-the-lunch-counter operation with a small neon sign outside and an open invitation to a bottomless cup of coffee you can get yourself. The menu jokingly offers ``ham an tue aigs an gravie or grits'' for $2.75. The customers are mostly Clinton residents - everyone from workmen to lawyers. But the guest list has grown since the twins delivered a pie, some lard-baked biscuits and several one-liners on ``The Tonight Show'' show in March. After a newspaper reported the twins planned to close the restaurant, the cafe became standing-room-only. ``One more time, they say,'' Hassie said. The sisters are widows with lots of family. They say they'll help out the Salvation Army, go to church socials and attend meetings of their American Association of Retired Persons group. ``There'll be plenty for them to do,'' said Wayne Seivers, Hassie's 34-year-old grandson. ``But they are going to miss this. If they've ever taken a week's vacation, it's been a rare occurrence.'' The twins grew up ``about eight miles down the road in the country,'' Hassie said. They've always dressed alike, ``even going to the bathroom.'' They came to Clinton at age 15 to work in a hosiery mill. The pay was 5 cents an hour, 10 hours a day. They worked there for more than 30 years. Two years after leaving the mill, they started the Twins Cafe with $800 borrowed from Hassie's husband's stepmother's brother. It was Sept. 7, 1953. Over the years, the cafe moved from one side of Clinton's block-long business district to another. The sisters also sold the restaurant a time or two. ``And we wanted it back, every time,'' Hassie said. The shortest time anyone else owned the cafe was four days. ``They just didn't keep it long enough to get to know our guests,'' Lassie said. The twins were enjoying the diner's final moments. ``A lady says not long ago, `Well, how much longer you going to stay?' I said, `All day,''' Lassie said. ``Then I went over to another booth and a lady says, `Have you been back there cooking all day?' I said, `No, the day's not gone yet.''' When customers ask, ``Have you been here all your life?'' Lassie responds. ``No, I'm not dead yet.''

DOC.HEAD: Teen-Age Peace Advocate Plans Airlift to Persian Gulf
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Stands for PM-Gulf-Lynn's Lift listed on PM-News Digest.
DOC.TEXT: A 15-year-old girl whose song promoting peace captivated Ronald Reagan and Mikhail Gorbachev is organizing an airlift of granola bars and lip balm for U.S. soldiers in the Persian Gulf. Sherry Lynn Biedrzycki said she got the idea from news reports on mail and meal times being the most important parts of the soldiers' long, hot days in the desert. ``I saw on `Good Morning America' a soldier who looked into the camera at mail time and he said `looks like there's no mail for me,' '' Sherry said. ``I felt really bad for him.'' Sherry gained international attention in 1987 when her song ``We Can Walk in Peace'' caught the eyes of Soviet and U.S. leaders during the height of nuclear arms reduction talks. The tune earned her a visit from then-President Reagan and a trip to the Soviet Union to meet Gorbachev. The latest effort of the suburban Milwaukee girl began two weeks ago at St. Francis High School. ``She was going to start a letter writing campaign at school and then she decided that she could do better than that,'' said Sherry's mother, Judy. The Milwaukee office of the Vietnam Veterans Foundation has agreed to send Sherry's care packages of granola bars, other snacks, packaged drink mixes and lip balm to the Persian Gulf. ``Sherry's a very busy little girl,'' said Michael Pepp, special events coordinator for the group. Pepp said the items likely would be on their way next week. ``My teacher is also helping me,'' Sherry said. ``She's giving extra credits for people who do this.'' Sherry managed to persuade the parent company of the Pick 'N Save food store chain in Wisconsin to donate items, a feat that amazed her mother. ``I said Sherry, you're never going to get anywhere with Pick 'N Save, that's a big grocery store,'' Mrs. Biedrzycki said. ``But the manager said `Well, of course.' I was real surprised.'' Sherry wants teen-agers all over the United States to join in her effort. ``I want this to be a teen project and show that teens care about soldiers,'' she said. ``I know that teens care about this and I want to put our caring into action.'' Elsewhere, homemade cookies flowed into Memphis for transport overseas to the troops, according to participants in Operation Cookie Drop. Guaranteed Air Freight and Forwarding of Memphis volunteered to transport the estimated 500,000 cookies by truck to New York today, where they will be inspected by the government and shipped. ``This has really taken on a national type awareness,'' said Ken Veneklase, regional manager of Guaranteed Air Freight. Kathy Young, who organized the operation, said the tins full of cookies must be labeled with the name and address of the person sending them. Ms. Young, who sent home-baked cookies to soldiers during the Vietnam War, said response to the three-week local drive was overwhelming. ``Citizens called me and asked to help,'' Ms. Young said. ``I have never had to ask anyone to help.''

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Refused $100 Million Offer From Taiwan, Newspaper Says
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Lead prospects uncertain.
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration, not wanting to alienate China, refused Taiwan's offer of about $100 million to help pay for the military buildup in the Persian Gulf, a newspaper reported today. The United States wants to remain on good terms with China, which has one of five permanent seats on the United Nations Security Council, the Los Angeles Times reported in today's editions. The United States has depended on China in the Security Council to support sanctions against Iraq for its Aug. 2 invasion and subsequent annexation of Kuwait. Taiwan made its $100 million offer through its Vice Foreign Minister C.J. Chen during his recent visit to Washington, the Times quoted unidentified diplomatic sources as saying. U.S. officials have sought donations from other countries to pay for the deployment of thousands of American troops to Saudi Arabia and the Persian Gulf region. But the administration refused the Taiwanese offer not wanting to upset Beijing, which has always opposed any official recognition of the Taipei government, the newspaper said. There was no immediate administration response to the report. A spokesman at the Taiwanese Coordination Council for North American Affairs in Washington would neither confirm nor deny the offer. ``Speaking hypothetically, even if we did make an offer and it was turned down, we would be understanding,'' the unidentified spokesman said. ``If the sanctions fail to take effect, the Administration will still need the Communist regime's cooperation.'' However, the Times said some sources indicated the Taiwanese government was angered by the rebuff. U.S. officials apparently told Taiwan to give the money instead to Egypt, Jordan and Turkey, but Vice Foreign Minister Chen did not want to do this, the Times said. Taiwan recently announced it would give $30 million to those countries. President Bush and National Security Advisor Brent Scowcroft met with former Chinese ambassador to the United States Han Xu two weeks ago. Han, a friend of Bush's, came seeking a renewal of high-level contacts between the two countries that were broken after Chinese soldiers attacked pro-democracy demonstrators in Beijing's Tiananmen Square in June 1989. Hundreds were left dead.

DOC.HEAD: Bomb Explodes Outside U.S. Drug Firm ^LaserPhoto MLA1
DOC.TEXT: Assailants threw a bomb that exploded outside a U.S. drug firm this morning, slightly injuring a bystander and causing little damage, police said. The attack on Vicks International was the seventh in four days against American companies, including Squibb, Coca-Cola and Pepsi. It was also one of at least 32 explosions in the capital since Aug. 13 when the spate of bombings allegedly committed by renegade soldiers began. Police Sgt. Mario Tolentino said officials were unable to identify today's attackers. The explosion took place outside the compound of Vicks International, a pharmaceutical division of Proctor and Gamble, an American company. Tolentino said one of the assailants hurled the homemade explosive device from one of the two cars that drove by. The bomb hit the company's wire fence and bounced off the street where it exploded, injuring a bystander. On Thursday, U.S. Ambassador Nicholas Platt said his government was worried about the rash of bombings which have hit American companies since Wednesday. He told Americans in Manila to ``hang in there and be careful.'' Early Thursday, bombs were exploded outside the Squibb drug company and Wyeth-Suaco Laboratories also in Makati. The explosions in the two U.S. drug companies caused little damage and no injuries, police said. Minutes earlier, police also defused a bomb at the Boston Bank of the Philippines in suburban Kalookan City. On Wednesday, small bombs also were exploded at the Coca-Cola and Pepsi Cola bottling plants and another was defused at a factory operated by Motorola, a U.S. electronics and communications firm.

DOC.HEAD: Recommissioned U.S. Battleship Again Makes Navy Proud
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: This 60,000-ton battleship, built in 1961, was sprouting grass from its desk just a few years ago. Today, its 16-inch guns, the largest of their kind in the world, are poised for any battle with Iraq, and the U.S. Navy is again proud of this recommissioned vessel. At a change of command ceremony in the Persian Gulf, Rear Adm. William M. Fogarty said Friday this ship provides ``a visible reminder'' of the firepower facing Iraq. Fogarty, commander of the Middle East naval force that patrols inside the gulf, was addressing 800 sailors grouped on the deck of the USS Wisconsin. During the ceremony, Capt. David S. Bill III relieved Captain Jerry M. Blesch as commanding officer of the ship. The change of command is a routine procedure aboard U.S. warships, usually taking place once every two years. ``The Wisconsin performs its mission today on the doorstep of an aggressor. It is a constant, highly visible reminder of the peril facing those who would ignore good faith efforts to resolve the present crisis through peaceful means,'' Fogarty said. ``But should that warning not be heeded, and it becomes necessary to actively translate our resolve into action, your presence offers the naval component commander unparalleled firepower,'' he said. Blesch, of Fort Thomas, Ky., was the Wisconsin's first commanding officer after it was recommissioned in 1988. During the ceremony Friday, he said, ``I was not impressed with her condition when I first took her over.'' He said there was grass growing on her deck, and he rememberd saying at the time, ``I'd hate to be the guy to bring this thing back to life.'' Today the battleship is considered a force commander's dream. Its 16-inch guns can hit targets beyond 20 miles. The ship is also equipped with 32 long-range Tomahawk cruise missles, 16 Harpoon anti-ship missiles, and 12 5-inch guns. The new commander, Bill, of Norfolk, Va., is a 1966 graduate of the U.S. Naval Academy. His tours of duty have included commands in Vietnam, the North Atlantic, the Mediterranean and the Indian Ocean. ``I am humbled by this awesome responsibility to take command of one of the world's most impressive warships,'' he said Friday. ``But I hasten to add, I wouldn't trade places with anybody I know.''

DOC.HEAD: Whitney's Invention to Teach Children Importance of Manufacturing
DOC.TEXT: The musket factory in which Eli Whitney introduced mass production to the world has been reborn as a working museum where children can learn the importance of manufacturing by making toy soldiers. At the site where in 1798 the inventor began to beat his competitors with the revolutionary production concept that helped arm the federal government, the goal now is 25 toy soldiers produced by 25 youngsters in 25 minutes. ``Ask me in a couple of weeks if we can do it,'' said William Brown, director of the Eli Whitney Museum. The exhibit opened Sunday. Whitney, fresh from a disappointing attempt to profit from his cotton gin, set up the musket factory in a small barn along the Mill River just north of New Haven. The museum thought a working exhibit would be the best way to demonstrate Whitney's genius. ``Kids are taught that `factory' is a dirty word,'' Brown said. ``We wrongly equate factory work with degrading, repetitive labor. Our goal is to help kids realize that this is a good and noble tradition.'' Twenty-two antique lathes, drill presses and other machines cut and shape the 3-inch-tall toy soldiers. The machines were collected from other museums, factories and machine shops throughout the state. Whitney's mass production system - based on interchangeable parts, the use of machine tools and the division of labor - made possible levels of precision and productivity unheard of in his day. Whitney's work paved the way for Connecticut's rise as a hub of precision manufacturing, a legacy most children know little about, Brown said. ``The experience of producing something collectively has become as foreign to these children as ballet or opera,'' Brown said. ``In the last 20 or 30 years, we've moved away from teaching anything about manufacturing. That's a horrible mistake.'' Whitney's muskets were followed by Colt's revolvers - the legendary ``gun that won the West'' - and locks, clocks, typewriters and sewing machines. Today, jet engines, nuclear submarines and helicopters are made in Connecticut, along with Colt guns. But manufacturing has tapered off since 1943, when 507,000 workers in the state - 63 percent of the Connecticut work force - were employed. Now only 22 percent of the work force, or 350,000 out of 1.6 million jobs, are in manufacturing. Over the next nine months, the museum hopes to send as many as 25,000 students and other visitors home with toy soldiers - and even more importantly, with a better understanding and new appreciation of manufacturing. Peter Moanfeldt, a professor of mechanical engineering at Greater New Haven State Technical College, said the project addresses what he sees as a fundamental problem that threatens the health of the U.S. economy. ``We need people who are willing to go into plants and do work,'' he said. ``And we're not turning out people who have that mind set. We're turning out people who want to sit in glassed-in offices and run the plants. ``We can't become a nation of bosses,'' Moanfeldt said.

DOC.HEAD: Ship With Refugees From Jordan Docks in Colombo
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Hundreds of Sri Lankans who fled the Persian Gulf crisis sang traditional songs and waved as a chartered ship bringing them from Jordan docked at Colombo today. The Safina E-Arab, a Pakistani vessel, sailed from Aqaba, Jordan on Sept. 17 with 1,756 Sri Lankans on board. They had fled Iraq and Kuwait after Baghdad invaded the desert emirate on Aug. 2 and reached Jordan after journeying across the desert. ``In my life, it was the worst suffering I ever had to undergo,'' said Mohamed Uvaisa Hammed, a 24-year-old driver who was working in Kuwait. He said he left Kuwait on Aug. 31 on a bus along with 54 other Sri Lankans. They traveled to Baghdad and then to Jordan, where they stayed at a refugee camp before leaving for Aqaba and boarding the ship, he said. The ship was chartered by International Organization Migration, a United Nations-funded refugee agency. The refugees sang Sinhalese songs and waved and were given a ceremonial welcome near the port. Names of those who returned were announced on loudspeakers for the throngs of waiting relatives and friends. An old woman burst into tears when she realized her two daughters, who were working in Kuwait, were not among the evacuees.
