At least 100,000 Sri Lankans were employed in Kuwait at the time of the Iraqi invasion. About 60,000 remain, another 20,000 have returned home and the rest are on their way, foreign office officials say. Hundreds of Americans are trapped in Iraq and Kuwait. ``We hope to evacuate all Sri Lankans before the end of the month,'' said Labor Minister Gamalath Premachandra. He said the Sri Lankan government was trying to organize daily flights from Jordan and would request Iraq permit flights from Kuwait.

DOC.HEAD: Current Quotations
DOC.TEXT: ``It is important to say we care enough to come to New York, to meet with our peers, to converse about the future of children, to see what we can do together.'' - Canadian Ambassador Yves Fortier, an organizer of the World Summit for Children. --- ``This board of trustees is prepared to open this institution on Monday morning.'' - Rev. A. Knighton Stanley, a trustee at the University of the District of Columbia, of a student occupation of campus buildings that has kept the school closed since Wednesday. --- ``It's not retirement. We're just quitting work,'' Lassie Disney, one of two 89-year-old sisters who will close their small Twins Cafe in Tennessee after 37 years.

DOC.HEAD: Two Naval Academy Midshipmen Charged With Rape
DOC.TEXT: Rape charges against two Naval Academy midshipmen come at a time when the male-dominated institution is trying to rid the campus of sexual harassment. Academy students Melvyn Malcolm Davis and Gordon Scott Wilson, both 21, were charged Friday with rape and related charges after a woman told police she met them at an Annapolis bar and accepted their offer of a ride home, Annapolis police spokesman Dermott Hickey said. ``They took her to an unknown location in the city and she was taken inside where she was raped and then they took her back to whatever street she lived on,'' Hickey said. The midshipmen also allegedly forced the woman to perform oral sex, Hickey said. Lt. Commander Michael John, an academy spokesman, said the charges are criminal charges rather than military charges. The academy will take no immediate action against the midshipmen, he said. Naval and congressional inquiries into sexual harassment and student hazing at the academy began earlier this year after the resignation of second-year midshipmen Gwen Marie Dreyer. She told authorities male midshipmen dragged her from her room, handcuffed her to a urinal and snapped photographs. Other women midshipmen later said they also had been subjected to abuse by male officers and male students. In May, the academy toughened its rules, increasing the penalty for midshipman found guilty of physical abuse of a plebe to expulsion. Previously, midshipmen were expelled for the more narrowly defined offense of hazing. A Navy survey found 46 percent of female midshipmen and 31 percent of male midshipmen thought the 4,500-student academy had a problem with sexual harassment. Dreyer quit the academy in April to protest the punishment meted out to two male midshipmen. They were penalized with loss of leave time and demerits and six others were issued written reprimands.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Announces First Cambodian Aid in 15 Years
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration has signed agreements to provide $2 million to meet child health care needs in Cambodia, the first U.S. aid to that country in 15 years. Friday's announcement by the U.S. Agency for International Development came on the eve of a meeting today between Secretary of State James A. Baker III and Vietnam's Foreign Minister Nguyen Co Thach. It was a further signal of the improving relations between the United States and Cambodia's Vietnamese-backed government. The United Nations Children's Fund (UNICEF) and World Vision Relief and Development will administer the funds. A.I.D. said the UNICEF program involves immunizations, oral re-hydration, nutrition and health education. World Vision will receive an $800,000 grant to upgrade a pediatric hospital in Phnom Penh, the Cambodian capital. U.S. aid to Cambodia was suspended after the communist Khmer Rouge triumph there in 1975. Congress recently lifted a legal prohibition on such aid. Administration officials have recently expanded diplomatic contacts with both Hanoi and Phnom Penh out of concern that the Khmer Rouge rebel group might force its way back into power. The Khmer Rouge is widely accused of killing hundreds of thousands during its 3{-year rule in the 1970's. Also Friday, a $9.8 million humanitarian aid agreement was signed with the president of the Soviet Republic of Armenia. It was described as the first A.I.D. program in the Soviet Union. But the United States provided substantial assistance to Armenia following the December 1988 earthquake there.
DOC.HEAD: House-Adopted NASA Bill Includes Money for Moon, Mars Trips
DOC.TEXT: President Bush's proposal to place a settlement on the Moon and begin work on a manned expedition to Mars was included in a House-passed $44 billion, three-year spending authorization bill for NASA. The measure, adopted Friday, would allow the National Aeronautics and Space Administration to spend no money for the Moon and Mars programs in the next fiscal year, but the agency could spend $444 million to begin the efforts in fiscal 1992 and $649 million in fiscal 1993. The bill, approved on a voice vote after a brief debate, now goes to a conference committee to work out differences with the Senate. The bill's three-year spending authorization is designed to allow NASA to make longer-range plans, including space shuttle missions, space exploration and development of expendable launch vehicles and an experimental high-speed aerospace plane. A multi-year authorization bill was adopted by the House last year, but the Senate never took action. President Bush proposed last year that NASA establish a permanent settlement on the Moon and begin a 30-year project to send a manned expedition to Mars by the year 2019. The bill authorizes the Bush administration's request for the project's start.
DOC.HEAD: Kemp Applauds First Public Housing Sale Accolade
DOC.TEXT: Residents of a public housing project here are the first residents of federally subsidized housing units in the nation to purchase their complex. The Kenilworth-Parkside development in the city's northeast quadrant was transferred to the residents on Friday for $1. The transaction capped a five-year process in which the residents successfully managed the complex and qualified to purchase the property under a program boosted by Housing Secretary Jack Kemp. ``The residents have worked so hard over the past five years to make this possible. This can open the door for residents of other public housing complexes across the country who'd like to have a definite say about their living conditions,'' said Kimi Gray, head of the Kenilworth-Parkside Resident Management Corp. The first phase of the changeover included the transfer of 132 housing units to the management corporation. The remaining 332 units are to be exchanged as renovations are completed. A study by an independent accounting firm showed the program would save the government $6 million over 10 years and $26 million over 40 years. The sale was made possible in part by amendments to the 1987 Housing Act, which gave resident councils the right to manage their own developments.

DOC.HEAD: Jews Thinking of Gulf Crisis on Their Holiest Day
DOC.TEXT: Jews celebrated their holiest day today after a televised message from their chief rabbi, who told them to pray and fear no enemy - ``not even the ruler of Baghdad.'' Israel shut itself off from the outside world Friday as Jews began observances of the Yom Kippur holiday with fasting and prayers of penitence. Although most Israelis are non-observant Jews, Yom Kippur is widely observed. Holiday services were held at the nation's 7,000 synagogues from sundown Friday until sundown today. With tensions high as a result of the Persian Gulf crisis, many Israelis were mindful that Friday also marked the 17th anniversary of the 1973 Middle East war, which began with attacks by the Egyptian and Syrian armies during Yom Kippur. In a holiday address on television Friday, Chief Rabbi Mordechai Eliyahu made a reference to Iraqi President Saddam Hussein, who has threatened to attack Israel with chemical weapons. Eliayahu said Israelis should pray to God, for ``then we have nothing to fear from any enemy ... even the ruler of Baghdad,'' whose capture of Kuwait last month caused a massive buildup of U.S. and other forces in Saudi Arabia. For some of the 90,000 Soviet immigrants who have arrived in the past year, this will be the first Yom Kippur they will be allowed to observe with prayers. All traffic halted at dusk Friday, airports closed and border crossing points were shut until tonight. Even the non-observant Jews refrain from driving for fear of being stoned by religious zealots. The nation's chief rabbis appealed to the public not to stone ambulances or cars that may be on the road for an emergency. By midafternoon Friday, the state-run Israel radio and television and army radio ceased broadcasts to follow the tradition of silence and reflection during the holiday. Jews traditionally fast during the 24 hours; restaurants in Israel must shut down by law. Observant Jews beat their chests and ask forgiveness for sins committed during the past year. This year, as in the past, the army has barred Palestinians in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip from entering Israel during the holiday. The Palestinians have been waging a 34-month-long uprising against Israeli rule in the occupied lands. Israeli newspapers printed reminiscences and commentaries about the 1973 war, and many families placed notices in newspapers memorializing some of the nearly 2,700 soldiers who died. Early Friday, some Orthodox Jews went to the markets to carry out the ancient rite of kapparot. Waving live chickens over their heads, they prayed that their sins would be transferred to the sacrificial chicken. Afterwards, the chickens were slaughtered and given to the poor. Yom Kippur ends the 10-day ``days of awe'' that begin on Rosh Hashana, the Jewish New Year.

DOC.HEAD: Teachers Continue Nation's Longest School Strike
DOC.TEXT: Teachers in the year's longest school strike voted overwhelmingly to defy a judge's order to report to work Monday. ``If we give in now we'll lose our collective bargaining rights, not only in this district but in surrounding districts and all over the state,'' union leader Judith Prinz said after teachers decided Friday to continue their strike. Only 65 of 387 Mukilteo teachers who voted were in favor of returning to work, said John Cahill, a spokesman for the Washington Education Association, a statewide teacher's union. Today was the 31st day of the contract dispute, making it the longest teachers' strike in Washington history and the longest in the nation this year. Teachers walked out Aug. 30. Classes were originally scheduled to begin Sept. 5 for the district's 9,100 students. Bargaining was set to resume Sunday. Superior Court Judge Stuart C. French ruled the strike illegal Thursday. He said teachers could be fined $100 and the Mukilteo Education Association $500 for each day the walkout continues. Under the ruling, the school board directed teachers to return to work Monday and set Tuesday as the first day of classes. ``We want to be there for the kids. We would like to be there for the parents, but we have our rights,'' teacher Elsie Miller said. Another Washington teacher strike ended Friday with a vote by teachers to ratify a contract in the University Place School District, which has about 4,600 students in the Tacoma suburbs. That strike began Sept. 19. Classes were to resume Monday. Teacher strikes have been scattered around the country. The nation's largest continues in New Orleans. Some 4,420 teachers and 1,100 teachers' aides and secretaries walked out Sept. 17, but schools have been kept open with substitutes and more than 1,600 regular teachers who crossed picket lines. About 470 teachers work in the predominantly white, working-class Mukilteo School District. The district includes the town of Mukilteo, much of southwest Everett and the suburbs around the Boeing 747 and 767 assembly plant. Major issues include: class size; assignment, transfer and vacancy policies; teacher involvement in decision-making at the schoolhouse level, and pay for extra time, responsibility and incentives. Fairmount PTA president Marilyn Cole said her fourth-grade son was following the strike closely. ``Andrew has asked some really penetrating questions ... `Why wouldn't the teachers go back to school if the court orders them to?' ``I told him, `They feel very strongly about what they're doing,' '' she said. ``He came back and said, `Well, if a bank robber said he felt very strongly about what he was doing, the judge wouldn't let him off the hook.' ``I just said, `We'll talk about that a little more some other time.' ''

DOC.HEAD: Police Catch 14-foot, 165-pound Python
DOC.TEXT: No one needed to tell Travis he had the right to remain silent. Travis is a 14-foot, 165-pound python nabbed Friday for settling under a ``No Parking, Tow Away'' sign near his owner's home in this small town southwest of San Jose. Police officer Charles Adams caught the snake with a little help from other officers and turned him over to Santa Clara County animal control officials. Investigators would not release the name of the errant serpent's owner but said he faces a possible life sentence in a zoo.

DOC.HEAD: Facts on German Unification
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS final graf to UPDATE with court ruling against election procedure.
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Germany-Promised Land
DOC.TEXT: Here are some facts about the united Germany that will be created when West Germany and East Germany unite on Oct. 3.

NAME: Federal Republic of Germany. POPULATION: 61 million in West Germany plus 16.6 million in East Germany, for a total of 77.6 million people. SIZE: West Germany's 95,975 square miles plus East Germany's 41,768 square miles. Total: 137,743 square miles, or more than half the size of Texas. NATIONAL FLAG: The West German flag, with broad horizontal black, red, and gold stripes, with no emblem. NATIONAL ANTHEM: West Germany's current national hymn, which is part of a poem called ``Deutschlandlied,'' or ``German Song.'' It uses a melody written by Franz Josef Haydn in 1797. Its opening words are ``Unity, and justice and freedom...'' CURRENCY: The two Germanys joined their economies on July 1. Since then West Germany's deutsche mark has been the official currency across Germany, as will be the case after unity. STATES: Five East German states added to West Germany's 11. CAPITAL: Berlin becomes the capital of all Germany on unity day. Bonn will remain the seat of government, with an all-German Parliament to decide whether the government will be moved to Berlin. GOVERNMENT: Helmut Kohl, West Germany's chancellor, becomes leader of all Germany on unity day and remains in power until elections to choose a new government and Parliament. The balloting was set for Dec. 2 but a West German court today struck down the election law, which excludes smaller parties. The action could force postponement of the election until a new plan is agreed on. Kohl is being challenged by Social Democrat Oskar Lafontaine in the Dec. 2 elections.

DOC.HEAD: First Of 9,000 British Ground Forces Leave For Gulf
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ADDS more background on other forces in gulf.
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The first of thousands of British ground troops and military hardware were on their way to Saudi Arabia today to join U.S. and other forces facing the Iraqi army in the Arabian desert. Several hundred troops left by air Friday from bases in southern England and Germany. The 5,800-ton logistical landing ship Sir Tristram sailed Friday night from Marchwood military port in southern England with 80 soldiers and equipment. The airborne troops were mostly advance parties from engineer units, the Defense Ministry said in a statement Friday that detailed the monthlong operation. The statement Friday said today's schedule included movement of Challenger tanks by road transporters from the 7th Armored Brigade's base at Fallingbostel in northern Germany to the North Sea German port of Bremerhaven 65 miles away. Initial estimates put the number of troops of the 7th Armored Brigade and support units being sent to the Persian Gulf at between 6,000 and 8,000. But The Times of London today said the number could reach 9,000. Three thousand other British armed service personnel aboard ships or with Royal Air Force fighter units are already in the gulf following Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. The United States has sent about 165,000 soldiers to the Persian Gulf region to ward off any Iraqi southern advance into Saudi Arabia. Thousands of Arab and French troops also are dug into the Saudi desert. The Pentagon said this week that Iraq had boosted its forces to 430,000 in and around Kuwait. Scores of U.S., British and other warships have assembled in the region to enforce a U.N.-ordered embargo against Iraq. The British Foreign Ministry has chartered 15 civilian ships and several civilian jumbo jets to assist British military ships and aircraft involved in the new deployment. Britain's shipments of military hardware, expected to arrive in the Persian Gulf in about three weeks, are to include 500 British combat vehicles and of more than 2,000 support vehicles, 10,000 tons of ammunition and 22,000 tons of other stores, spares, rations and medical supplies. Transportation of the entire 7th Armored Brigade is scheduled to be completed by the end of October and the brigade will be ready for action by mid-November, the ministry said.

DOC.HEAD: Larry F. O'Brien, Former Democratic Strategist, NBA Chief, dies
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS lead to DELETE reference to O'Brien as free agent advocate; SUBS 8th graf, `O'Brien left ...' to ADD year of retirement. Pick up 9th graf, `Born in ...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto BX11 of Sept. 28.
DOC.TEXT: Lawrence F. O'Brien, an architect of John F. Kennedy's New Frontier and later commissioner of the National Basketball Association at the dawn of free agency, has died at age 73. O'Brien, who influenced Democratic politics for two decades, died Thursday of cancer at New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center. The Kennedy family confidant was a ``founding father of post-war politics,'' Sen. Edward M. Kennedy, D-Mass, said Friday. ``He was the organizational genius of my brother's presidential campaign and the architect of much of the New Frontier.'' O'Brien served as congressional liaison for President Kennedy and President Lyndon B. Johnson, was postmaster general under Johnson for three years and twice served as chairman of the Democratic National Committee. O'Brien's Democratic Party office was broken into in Washington's Watergate complex in 1972, setting off a scandal that toppled President Nixon. ``Larry was one of the last of the old-time political leaders who had no factional or philosophical disputes with any member of the party and was interested primarily in winning elections,'' said Theodore Sorensen, former special counsel to President Kennedy. O'Brien was with Kennedy when the president was assassinated in Dallas in 1963. O'Brien also was with Sen. Robert F. Kennedy when he was assassinated in Los Angeles in 1968 during his Democratic primary bid for president. O'Brien left politics in 1972 for Wall Street, then was named NBA commissioner in 1975, a year when free agency and big money were reshaping professional sports. He retired as commissioner in 1984. Born in Springfield, Mass., O'Brien thought as a boy about running for office but became more interested in behind-the-scenes politics. ``All I wanted to do was get more votes than the other guy,'' O'Brien once said. O'Brien directed John F. Kennedy's presidential campaign and his earlier U.S. Senate upset of Henry Cabot Lodge, who was the symbol of Protestant Republicanism in Massachusetts. At the 1960 Democratic convention in Los Angeles, O'Brien's delegate count was so accurate that he predicted within a half-vote the final tally in favor of Kennedy. It was O'Brien's greatest triumph. Survivors include his wife, Elva Brassard O'Brien; a son, Lawrence F. O'Brien III of Washington; two grandsons, and a sister, Mary Placzek of Wilbraham, Mass. Wakes were scheduled for Sunday in New York and Monday in Springfield. The funeral was set for Tuesday at St. Michael's Cathedral in Springfield.

DOC.HEAD: German Government Raises Borrowing for Unity
With PM-Germany-Election, PM-Germany-Promised Land
DOC.TEXT: The government has indicated it may have to raise taxes because of the Persian Gulf crisis, and it unveiled a $16.4 billion borrowing plan to help finance the growing costs of German unity. Finance Minister Theo Waigel also presented a new $12.8 billion supplementary budget Friday. Most was earmarked for helping East Germany. Chancellor Helmut Kohl has doggedly rejected opposition claims that he will eventually have to raise taxes to finance unification, scheduled for Wednesday. But government officials have been hinting taxes may go up. Waigel told reporters, ``Through strict spending discipline, we will do everything to avoid raising taxes.'' Asked how Germany will pay for its contributions to help ease the gulf crisis, he replied that ``the exclusion'' of a possible tax increase is ``limited to German unity.'' Kohl has pledged $2.1 billion to help the anti-Iraqi effort. The sum includes equipment for U.S. forces deployed in Saudi Arabia and assistance for nations like Jordan that are suffering from a loss of trade. Raising taxes for gulf assistance would let Kohl technically keep his word that Germans won't face a tax increase because of unity. Kohl's political rivals have charged the chancellor is trying to hide the true costs of unification so voters won't turn against him in all-German elections. The vote had been set for Dec. 2, but West Germany's constitutional court ruled today that the plan is illegal because it keeps smaller parties off the ballot. That could force postponement of the balloting unless political leaders agree on a new procedure. Waigel called the news conference Friday to unveil the supplementary budget, which would raise total outlays for this year to $252 billion. The extra borrowing that he announced increases 1990 total to about $42 billion. The added borrowing would cover new outlays earmarked for helping rebuild what is now East Germany after unification. Higher-than-expected unity costs have already forced Kohl's government to adopt two previous supplementary budgets. The latest budget addition includes extra money for the creation of new jobs in East Germany, which is suffering from heavy unemployment as antiquated businesses collapse in the new free-market system. It also provides more funds for housing, jobless benefits, pensions and health insurance.

DOC.HEAD: Israeli Legislators Say Russian Republic Wants Close Ties
DOC.TEXT: Sidestepping Soviet leader Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Russian Republic has asked Israel to form direct economic ties, Russian and Israeli legislators say. The Israelis said Friday they would consider the request but don't want to jeopardize the big prize - eventual renewal of ties with the Soviet Union. Gorbachev is seeking better relations with Israel and more investment in the troubled Soviet economy. But he would probably be angered by a special deal between Jerusalem and the Russian Republic led by his chief rival, Boris Yeltsin. ``We will act carefully, and I emphasize that,'' said Eliyahu Ben-Elissar, chairman of the Defense and Foreign Affairs Committee in Israel's Parliament. ``We can't endanger all that is going on between us and the central authorities of the Soviet Union,'' he told Israel radio. He was referring to the warming of ties between the two countries in the past three years. There are growing indications that diplomatic relations could be restored in the near future. The offer of direct ties with the Russian Republic came from Vladimir Lukin, chairman of the Foreign Affairs Committee in the republic's Parliament. In a message to his Israeli counterpart, Ben-Elissar, Lukin said he was interestd in forming close working relations between the two committees, the Israeli legislator said. But Lukin suggested in an interview with Israel radio broadcast Friday that the real objective would be economic cooperation. ``The idea of exchanging delegations between the foreign affairs committees of the two parliaments is in the works. But the most important area is economics,'' Lukin said. Russia, the Soviet Union's wealthiest, largest and most populous republic, has adopted a radical economic reform plan. It is scheduled to go into effect Oct. 1. The central Soviet government, meanwhile, is working out details of a somewhat more conservative plan for leading to nation toward a free-market system. ``The Russian Republic has something to offer to Israel, and we are interested in your technologies,'' Lukin told the radio, speaking in Russian. ``Based on our radical economic program, all are invited to trade, to establish joint factories. But many Israelis would have a competitive edge because they know Russia and its language,'' he said. Lukin assured the Israelis that they wouldn't harm their chances with Gorbachev by developing ties with the Russian Republic, which has been seeking greater independence from the central government. Ben-Elissar said several months ago he asked the Foreign Affairs Committee of the Supreme Soviet, the Soviet Union's Parliament, to establish working ties, but that he didn't receive an answer. The Soviet Union cut diplomatic relations with Israel after the Jewish state conquered territory of Moscow's Arab allies during the 1967 Middle East War.

DOC.HEAD: Hundreds Still Prisoner After Chinese Crackdown
DOC.TEXT: China is still holding hundreds of prisoners detained during last year's crackdown on the pro-democracy movement, a U.S.-based human rights group says, The group, Asia Watch, on Friday issued the most comprehensive list to date of prisoners of conscience held in Chinese jails. Most of the 1,000 prisoners profiled in the report were arrested after the military crackdown on pro-democracy demonstrators on June 4, 1989. Sidney Jones, executive director of the New York-based organization, said the aim of the report was to keep the prisoners from being forgotten. ``We are concerned that human rights in China as an issue is going to fade from public view. ... We want to make sure that these names become very much in the public eye,'' she said in a telephone interview. Asia Watch also hopes the report will help gain the release of those listed, she said. The group planned to try to give a copy to Chinese Foreign Minister Qian Qichen when he attends the United Nations General Assembly in New York. The Chinese government did not immediately respond to the report. It generally rejects criticism of its rights record as interference in its internal affairs. Thousands of Chinese nationwide were detained or arrested immediately after last year's student-led democracy movement was put down. The Asia Watch report lists the names and backgrounds of those whose cases are known. It also enumerates other arrests and executions reported by the official Chinese media without giving names. Only 226 of the 1,000 prisoners in the report have been tried. Sixty-seven were sentenced to death or executed. Called ``Repression in China Since June 4, 1989,'' the report is far more comprehensive than those issued previously by Asia Watch and other international rights groups. It includes people from every segment of society - students, intellectuals, peasants, workers, and government officials - from all 29 of China's provinces and regions. ``The focus has been on Beijing when people think about (the crackdown), but it's been widespread throughout China,'' Jones said. The government has announced the release of 881 people in Beijing and Shanghai the past year, but it has refused to say how many remain in jail nationwide for political offenses. Among those named in the report are such well-known figures as Liu Xiaobo. He is a literary critic who was on a fellowship at Columbia University when the democracy movement began, and he rushed back to China to take part. The report mentions Wang Dan, the bookish student who became one of the main protest leaders. He has been held in solitary confinement in a maximum-security prison outside Beijing. The report also includes hundreds of other people who were caught up in the pro-democracy protests that spread to more than 80 cities throughout China. The report also includes dozens of Tibetans and Moslems imprisoned for separatist activities, and Christians arrested for conducting religious activities outside the state-run churches. Asia Watch plans to present the report to Congress next week during a hearing on a bill that would link future renewal of China's most-favored-nation trade status to its rights record, Jones said. President Bush extended China's preferential status for one year in June. Some legislators criticized his decision, but it is not expected to be overturned.

DOC.HEAD: East German Prisoners Protest Amnesty Plan; Youths Rampage
DOC.TEXT: Protesting inmates today seized prison rooftops nationwide and rioters clashed with police in the capital as East Germany braced for growing unrest in its final days as a nation. About 60 inmates occupied the roof of a prison in Dresden to demonstrate against a plan passed by the Parliament late Friday that would trim their sentences by a third. A 19-year-old man made good on a threat to jump and leaped from a 9-foot ledge, East Germany's ADN news agency said. The inmate was slightly injured. ADN said inmates also occupied rooftops in Buetzow and Leipzig. Prisoners have been mounting periodic protests for weeks over the amnesty plan. Exempt from the prisoner amnesty plan are people convicted of murer, war crimes, sex offenses and other violent crimes. The convicts want a broader amnesty program. Many claim they were falsely imprisoned under the former Communist regime. The amnesty plan passed by Parliament was one of the legislature's last official acts before it formally disbands on Tuesday, one day before East Germany is absorbed by West Germany. Interior Minister Peter-Michael Diestel spoke to the Dresden inmates for several hours early this morning, ADN said. In East Berlin, authorities arrested 15 people after hundreds of young people rampaged Friday night through East Berlin's main square, Alexanderplatz, following a soccer match between Berlin and Leipzig teams. The rioters attacked passersby, hurled rocks in a train station and clashed with club-wielding police. But no injuries were reported. The rampage was the latest of several in East Berlin, which has become increasingly violent since the borders to the West were opened. Neo-Nazi skinheads, leftist radicals from West Berlin and bands of self-proclaimed toughs with no political loyalties except to soccer teams routinely stage rampages in the city center. Police have been preparing for organized attacks by leftist radicals who have promised to mount protests this weekend over Wednesday's unification of Germany. Also Friday night, a group of club-wielding skinheads in the city of Saalfeld rampaged through a youth clubhouse and injured two people, ADN said.

DOC.HEAD: West German Court Rules United Election Procedure Illegal
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS thruout to UPDATE with reax from justice minister, Greens; MINOR EDITING thruout; no pickup
DOC.TEXT: West Germany's constitutional court ruled today that plans for united German elections in December are illegal because they keep smaller parties off the ballot. The ruling does not affect the unification of East Germany and West Germany that comes on Wednesday. But it will force political leaders to seek a new election plan or perhaps postpone the united elections planned for Dec 2. West German Justice Minister Hans Engelhard said today his government will try to keep the Dec. 2 election date in place but also respect the decision of the constitutional court. West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl will be in charge of a united Germany until the common elections are held. The constitutional court acted on a complaint brought by East Germany's former Communist Party, the environmental Greens coalition, and the far-right Republicans. Hans Christian Stroebele, spokesman for the Greens, hailed the court's decision. He called it ``sweet success against the arrogance of the cocky dominant parties.'' The smaller parties have opposed the election agreement between mainstream political groups because it required a party to win 5 percent of the vote across a united Germany in order to win a seat in Parliament. The election treaty would allow smaller parties to form alliances with larger parties and share ballot space with them, allowing them to get the necessary 5 percent. But the former Communists and the rightist Republicans have virtually no chance of finding mainstream parties that would share the ballot with them. The court's decision was announced by Ernst Gottfried Mahrenholz, vice president of the constitutional court in Karlsruhe, near the French border 80 miles south of Frankfurt. He said the 5 percent clause in the election agreement would infringe on the rights of the parties that brought the complaint. The court also struck down the mechanism that would allow smaller parties to be listed with larger, allied parties. The agreement rejected by the court represented a compromise between the Kohl's Christian Democrats, which is the leading party in both Germanys, and the main opposition group - the left-of-center Social Democrats. The Social Democrats wanted the 5 percent limit to keep smaller, left-of-center parties from getting in Parliament and diluting the Social Democrats' clout in a united Germany. The Christian Democrats wanted the agreement that would allow bigger parties to form alliances with smaller parties because Kohl's power base is comprised of coalitions with other conservative parties, such as the powerful Christian Social Union in Germany's biggest state, Bavaria.

DOC.HEAD: Political Figure Killed in Flareup of Rebel Violence
DOC.TEXT: Leftist rebels killed a rural activist for President Alberto Fujimori's party during a flurry of guerrilla violence around the nation, police said. At least four police and eight Maoist Shining Path guerrillas also died Friday in clashes. In Pucura, an Andean town 120 miles east of Lima, about 10 Shining Path rebels stormed the home ofHugo Hidalgo, a local representative of Fujimori's Change 90 party. Hidalgo was shot twice in the head during the attack late Thursday, police said. Early Friday, four police and six rebels were killed when guerrillas ambushed a police patrol in a mountainous area about 525 miles southeast of Lima. Police said about 70 rebels attacked a 25-man patrol traveling in two vehicles. Two officers were wounded. In addition, two leftist guerrillas were killed by police in a dawn gun battle in the Lima suburb of Surco, police said. They said they recovered dynamite, fuses, revolvers and ammunition from a stolen car used by the rebels. The guerrillas were planning to use the stolen vehicle as a car bomb, police said. Guerrillas also bombed three state electricity company branches in Lima early Friday morning, police said. The outbreak of violence follows the Shining Path's assassination of former Labor Minister Orestes Rodriguez in Lima one week ago. Members of the pro-Cuban Tupac Amaru Revolutionary Movement, a smaller group, kidnapped Congressman Gerardo Lopez in Lima on Sunday. Lopez is still being held. Nearly 20,000 people, most of them civilians, have died in political violence since the Shining Path took up arms in 1980. The Tupac Amaru band began operating in 1984.

DOC.HEAD: Shuttle Pad to be Converted for Titan 4-Centaur Launches
DOC.TEXT: The Air Force has decided to convert a mothballed $3.5 billion space shuttle dock into a backup pad for launches of the Titan 4-Centaur rocket. The Pentagon said Friday the multimillion dollar conversion of Space Launch Complex-6 at Vandenberg Air Force Base will start after Oct. 1. The first launch of Titan 4 rockets equipped with Centaur upper-stage boosters at the pad is expected in 1996, the Pentagon said. The Air Force believes the pad is needed in case an accident ever cripples Vandenberg's Space Launch Complex-4 East, which will be used early next year for the first West Coast launch of a Titan 4 without a Centaur upper stage, Col. Charles F. Sterling, Titan 4 program director, said in a statement. Sterling cited the 1985 explosion of a Titan 34D rocket that temporarily halted use of another launch pad. But a critic predicted the pad will never be used because Congress will refuse to pay for the costly military communications and surveillance satellites meant to be launched on Titan 4-Centaurs. ``They've been working on this launch pad for more than two decades and it still hasn't launched anything,'' space policy analyst John Pike said Friday by telephone from the Federation of American Scientists, a public interest group in Washington. ``They just want to keep pouring concrete.'' The conversion of SLC-6 will cost $300 million to $500 million, and will be faster, cheaper and environmently safer than building a new launch complex for up to $800 million, said Maj. Tom Worsdale, a Vandenberg spokesman. Pike said he believed the conversion will cost far more. He said the decision ``effectively forecloses ever flying the shuttle from California.'' The cost of Titan 4 and Titan 4-Centaurs ranges from $173 million to $265 million each, according to various Air Force and General Accounting Office estimates.

DOC.HEAD: Patriarch of Zoo's Gorilla Clan Dies
DOC.TEXT: Bongo, an African gorilla who played a major role in breeding gorillas in captivity, has died of a lung infection at Columbus Zoo, officials say. Bongo's keepers found the 33-year-old silverback dead Friday in his quarters. ``If there was ever a gentle giant, it was Bongo,'' zoo Director Jack Hanna said. ``He was a major factor in helping us bring this zoo to where it is and an important contributor to the North American captive gorilla population.'' For 26 years, Bongo romanced Colo, the world's first captive-born gorilla. Bongo sired Oscar and Toni, who live in the zoo. In 1986, Bongo became the oldest breeding male in captivity with the birth of his son, Fossey, zoo officials said. When Fossey's mother, Bridgette, died 14 months after the birth, Bongo took on the rearing of the young gorilla, often cradling it in his arms. Bongo was about a year old when he was brought to America from Africa, where he was captured in the wild.

DOC.HEAD: Britain Sending Ground Forces to Gulf; Iraq Issues Warning
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 9 grafs to UPDATE with Iraqi foreign minister arriving in Jordan, Egyptian troops leaving for gulf region. Pick up 6th graf pvs, `The first of...'; EDITS to trim.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto NY7
DOC.TEXT: Britain today sent ground forces to the Persian Gulf, and Iraq's foreign minister arrived in Jordan carrying a message from President Saddam Hussein. Baghdad's government threatened to spread any war across the region, and talk of war also came from Washington. Following a meeting Friday between President Bush and Kuwait's deposed emir, a presidential aide suggested Bush might push for tougher U.N. action against Iraqi leader Saddam Hussein, including a military operation. Rep. Les Aspin, chairman of the House Armed Services Committee, said he feels the Bush administration ``is looking more favorably on an early war option'' to end Saddam's 8-week-old occupation of oil-rich Kuwait. So far, tough U.N. sanctions and a naval blockade that has choked off virtually all of Iraq's oil exports and food imports have failed to break Saddam's resolve to absorb the emirate. The Iraqi foreign minister, Tariq Aziz, was meeting today with Jordan's King Hussein. The message he brought from Saddam dealt with the ``tense situation'' in the region, a senior Jordanian Foreign Ministry official said. Jordan has also condemned the invasion of Kuwait, but Saddam has widespread popular support in Jordan, and the Jordanian government has spoken out strongly against foreign military intervention in the region. The pace of the multinational deployment picked up today. Egyptian military sources said about 1,000 Egyptian soldiers left by ship for Saudi Arabia. The reinforcements will bring to about 12,500 the number of Egyptian troops in the region. Meanwhile, British ground forces were to begin leaving Britain and Germany today for the Persian Gulf, the Defense Ministry said in London. The first of 500 British combat vehicles and of more than 2,000 support vehicles, 10,000 tons of ammunition and 22,000 tons of other stores, spares, rations and medical supplies left the North Sea German port of Bremerhaven on two ships on Friday, the ministry said. The 5,800-ton logistical landing ship Sir Tristram, meanwhile, sailed Friday night from Marchwood military port in southern England carrying 80 soldiers, equipment, spares and food, the ministry said. Advanced parties of several hundred men, mostly belonging to army engineering units, set off by air on Friday from bases in southern England and West Germany, the British Defense Ministry said. The ministry said that loading of equipment on to ships in Germany and Britain began Friday and will last a week. The cargo is to arrive in the gulf in three weeks. Initial estimates put the number of troops from the 7th Armored Brigade and support units at between 6,000 and 8,000. But The Times of London said today the number could reach 9,000. About 3,000 British forces are already serving aboard ships or with Royal Air Force fighter units as part of the international military buildup opposing Iraq. The United States has led the international forces with more than 150,000 soldiers on ships and on the ground in Saudi Arabia, facing an estimated 430,000 Iraqi troops in and around Kuwait. Iraq invaded its southern neighbor Aug. 2 after a dispute over land, oil and money, and increased its share of world crude reserves to 20 percent. Iraq's government newspaper Al-Jomhouriya again warned about widespread devastation if war broke out. ``The battle arenas would be multiple and the fires would devour all oil fields, the Zionist entity and agents of America in the region,'' it said in an editorial. The newspaer was referring to Israel as well as Egypt, Syria, Morocco, and Arab gulf states cooperating with the United States in the multinational buildup. The Iraqi News Agency said radical Palestinian leader Mohammed Abbas vowed to launch terrorist attacks on U.S. interests if any Iraqi aircraft were attacked to enforce a new U.N. air embargo on Iraq. In Irbid, Jordan, about 50,000 people rallied Friday in support of Iraq. During the demonstration, the fundamentalist Moslem Brotherhood Party vowed to fight all the Western troops in Saudi Arabia if Iraq was attacked. ``Moslems will kill all American and Western troops who are dirtying our Holy land, and their corpses will be sent home in black bags addressed to Bush,'' party member Sheik Abdul Munem Abu Zant declared. In Tehran, millions of Iranians on Friday protested the multinational force in the Persian Gulf with chants of ``Death to America!'' according to Tehran radio. In Washington, Bush promised the exiled leader of Kuwait that the oil-rich kingdom will not remain under Iraqi control. ``Kuwait's sovereignty and territorial integrity will be restored,'' Bush said after meeting with Sheik Jaber al-Ahmed al-Sabah. A Bush aide said the account of the Iraqi occupation that the exiled ruler gave Bush could lead the president to push for tougher U.N. action against Saddam, including U.N.-backed military action. ``That's one of those things that's conceivable,'' said Brent Scowcroft, the president's national security adviser. More than 1,700 Sri Lankans who fled Iraq and Kuwait sang traditional songs and waved as a chartered ship arrived home today via Jordan, where thousands of Asian refugees have been stranded in camps. The ship was chartered by International Organization Migration, a United Nations-funded refugee agency. Thousands of Westerners, including hundreds of Americans, remained trapped in the Iraq and Kuwait. Scores of men are being held at potential military targets as human shields. In other developments: -Turkish customs officials at the southern port of Mersin have refused to unload Iraqi-bound chemicals from a Polish ship after receiving a tip they constitute raw materials for mustard gas, the semi-official Anatolia news agency reported Friday. U.S. forces in Saudi Arabia have been preparing for possible chemical attacks by Iraq. -Four East European countries have offered help in countering Iraq, the U.S. State Department said Friday. Poland, Czechoslovakia and Romania have offered medical facilities, and Bulgaria pledged 400 soldiers, the department said.

DOC.HEAD: United Way Changes Mind on Funding Boy Scouts
DOC.TEXT: The local United Way has decided to resume funding of the Boy Scouts of America, reversing a decision to cut off funds because of allegations that the scouts' oath discriminated against atheists. The board voted 8-1 late Friday to resume the $1,250 contribution it had voted down Aug. 29, said Joan Hendricks, a board member for the Genoa-Kingston United Way and a member of American Atheists Inc. ``The accusation of discrimination has yet to be fully decided by the courts,'' board Chairman Jim Ferris said in a statement late Friday. Hendricks cast the only dissenting vote but denied that the cutoff of funds had originally been her idea. The decision to withhold 1991 funding from two local Boy Scout troops and a Cub Scout pack made it the only United Way among 1,400 agencies nationwide to take such action, the national association said Wednesday. A lawsuit filed in May in U.S. District Court in Chicago challenged the requirement that scouts take an oath to do their duy ``to God and my country.'' United Way of America officials have said the organization would not change its policy of funding the scouts until their was a legal decision.

DOC.HEAD: Museum Gets Famous Checkpoint Charlie Building
DOC.TEXT: The Berlin Wall guard post at Checkpoint Charlie was handed over to a German museum today for future exhibition to the public, and it was lauded as a ``symbol of the American support for a free life.'' ``In the course of its 29-year existence, Checkpoint Charlie witnessed acts of courage and acts of desperation,'' said Maj. Gen. Raymond E. Haddock, the commander of U.S. forces in West Berlin. The post, which stood between the American and Soviet sectors of Berlin, ``provided constant, visible proof of Allied determination to maintain their freedom of movement in all of Berlin and to defend the freedom of Berlin,'' Haddock said. Decorated with American, British and French flags, the small one-story building was given to the German Historical Museum at a ceremony attended by Allied military chiefs, diplomats and notables from Berlin. The guard post had stood at the Friedrich Street crossing between West and East Berlin since 1961 when East Germany erected the Berlin Wall to keep its citizens from moving to the West. Last November, after a popular revolution, the wall was opened, and in June the guard building - actually the fourth in a series of temporary structures - was lifted by a crane and put in storage. ``Checkpoint Charlie stood as a symbol of the American support for a free life,'' said Anke Martiny, a member of the West Berlin city council responsible for cultural affairs. She also recalled the Berlin airlift in which U.S. and British planes kept Berlin alive in 1948-49, when the Soviet blockade tried to starve the outpost city in the middle of Communist East Germany. ``Without the help of the Allies, Berlin would not have survived,'' she said. Museum Director Christoph Stoelzl said the building would be stored while a place is found to display it safely. Stoelzl said the same souvenir-hunters who are hammering constantly on the remains of the Berlin Wall would probably attack Checkpoint Charlie, too. ``They want to take it away in pieces,'' he said. The mundane function of the checkpoint was to serve as a place to register American, British and French military people traveling into the Soviet sector. It was usually manned by two American military police and one French and one British MP, though in 1961, after the wall went up, U.S. and Soviet tanks faced each other across the checkpoint in a tense dispute over the right of Allied soldiers to travel unhindered in the eastern sector. ``I've seen it all here,'' said U.S. Army Staff Sgt. Nathaniel Brown, 39, a veteran of three years with the Checkpoint Charlie unit. Brown, of St. Louis, said he had been on duty last Nov. 9 when the wall was opened ``and a three-day party started.'' Brown said he also had seen two unsuccessful escape attempts in the summer of 1987.

DOC.HEAD: Serbs Attack Police Station, Seize Arms
DOC.TEXT: About 1,000 Serbs claiming harassment by authorities in the republic of Croatia attacked a police station overnight, seizing arms and ammunition, the Yugoslav news agency Tanjug reported today. Hours later, special police units took control of the police station and began confiscating the weapons, Tanjug said. The incident was the latest in a series of increasingly fierce confrontations between the Croatian authorities and the Serb minority in the republic. Tanjug said an angry crowd of Serbs from Dvor, a Croatian town about 200 miles west of Belgrade, and from nearby Bosanski Novi, located in the republic of Bosnia-Hercegovina, attacked Dvor police station Friday night. The crowd overpowered police - who refrained from using their firearms during the attack - and occupied the police station, Tanjug said. Members of Croatia's special police units arrived in Dvor shortly after midnight Friday to help local police, Tanjug said. All approaches to the police station and to the town hall were blocked, with police checking vehicles and their passengers on access roads, it said. Serbs and Croats have been rivals since Yugoslavia was created in 1918. This traditional rivalry has intensified markelly since free elections in Croatia resulted in the election of a center-right government in the republic last spring. In Serbia, by contrast, President Slobodan Milosevic has stuck to rigid communist-style policies. Serbia, the largest of Yugoslavia's six republics, also wants Yugoslavia to stay a centralized federation with its capital in the current Serbian and federal capital of Belgrade. Croatia and its northern neighbor Slovenia, where the Communists also lost power to a center-right coalition in elections last spring, seek a much looser confederation of republics. On Friday, Serbia approved a new constitution emphasizing centralized control, while the Slovenian parliament adopted amendments edging that republic closer to full independence.

DOC.HEAD: Ousted Prime Minister Says She'll Appear Before Tribunal
DOC.TEXT: Ousted Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto said today she would appear before a tribunal that will decide her political future. Ms. Bhutto has been ordered to stand trial before the special one-judge court Sunday on charges of misconduct and abuse of power during her 20 months in office. ``I don't recognize the tribunals,'' Ms. Bhutto said after a speech. ``But I will go there and my lawyer will present my objections.'' The 37-year-old former prime minister also was expected to appear before another tribunal in the eastern city of Lahore on Tuesday on two similar charges. If she is convicted of any of the four charges, she could be disqualified as a candidate in the Oct. 24 elections and barred from politics for seven years. Ms. Bhutto's husband also has been summoned before the Sindh High Court on Sunday for allegedly failing to cooperate in police investigations into high-level corruption. Ms. Bhutto won election in November 1988 and became the first woman to lead a modern Moslem nation. President Ghulam Ishaq Khan, using his constitutional power, dismissed Ms. Bhutto's government on Aug. 6 and installed a caretaker government comprised largely of her opponents. Ishaq Khan accused Ms. Bhutto's government of corruption, incompetence and abuse of power. Ms. Bhutto has denied any wrongdoing and accused the president and the caretaker government of launching a witch hunt against her, her government and her left-leaning Pakistan People's Party. The charges to be weighed by the Karachi tribunal accuse Ms. Bhutto of illegally using an Asia Development Bank loan to hire a foreign consulting firm to oversee a Karachi power project and of allowing a British-based firm to export cotton at rates far below the international market rate. The caretaker government has tried to portray Ms. Bhutto's administration as the most corrupt in Pakistan's 43-year history. But many Pakistanis believe the way she has been treated has generated a wave of sympathy for Ms. Bhutto. Analysts say she and her party appear to be gaining strength and could emerge from next month's election as the single largest party.

DOC.HEAD: Vietnam Offers to Withdraw Advisers From Cambodia
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 7 grafs to UPDATE with Vietnam promising to withdraw military advisers from Cambodia, Baker quote; Picks up 3rd graf pvs, `President Bush's ...'
DOC.HEAD: With PM-UN-Children, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Vietnam's foreign minister today promised that his country would withdraw all its military advisers from Cambodia, but he provided no timetable for the withdrawal. The pledge by Foreign Minister Nguyen Co Thach came before his meeting with Secretary of State James A. Baker III for the highest-level talks between the two countries since the Vietnam War. Vietnam, which invaded Cambodia in 1978, has withdrawn all or most of its 140,000 troops from Cambodia, western intelligence officials believe. It was not immediately known how many military advisers remain in Cambodia. ``We have withdrawn our forces and we will withdraw all our advisers,'' the foreign minister said, adding that Vietnam had agreed to international monitoring in Cambodia. The private meeting with Baker followed a series of sessions this summer between Vietnam's U.N. ambassador and State Department officials. Vietnam has been seeking to forge diplomatic ties with the United States. Baker said that the two countries would have to resolve such issues as American prisoners of war and those missing in action during the Vietnam War. ``The minister knows that the pace and the scope of our ability to move toward normalization with Vietnam is going to depend on further progress on the POW-MIA issue,'' Baker told reporters. President Bush's administration has been expanding diplomatic contacts with both Hanoi and the Vietnamese-installed government in Cambodia. The United States had supported the rebel resistance, but officials in Washington are now worried that a Communist rebel faction that once ruled Cambodia will force its way back to power. Vietnam installed the Cambodian government when it invaded that country in 1978 to oust the Communist faction, the Khmer Rouge. During its rule from 1975-79, the Khmer Rouge killed hundreds of thousands of Cambodians directly through purges and executions and indirectly through starvation and the hardship of a radical agrarian relocation program. Washington has said improved diplomatic ties with Vietnam depend on Vietnam's cooperation with a U.N. peace plan for Cambodia. Under that plan, the United Nations would administer most of Cambodia's government until new elections are held. The plan was worked out by the five permanent U.N. Security Council members: the United States, Britain, France, China and the Soviet Union. If carried out, it would be an unprecedented U.N. operation to settle a regional conflict, costing up to $5 billion over one or two years. It would involve up to 10,000 peacekeeping troops and 10,000 civilian personnel. On Friday, President Bush's administration signed agreements providing $2 million to meet health needs of Cambodian children. It is the first U.S. government aid earmarked for that country in 15 years. The aid will be administered by World Vision Relief and Development and UNICEF, the U.N. agency to help children.

DOC.HEAD: Senate Race Focuses on Duke's Past as Cross-Burning Ex-Klansman
With AM-Senate Rdp Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Republican David Duke's past as a cross-burning Ku Klux Klansman is under attack as Democratic Sen. J. Bennett Johnston tries to deal him a knockout blow in Louisiana's open primary. Johnston, who is seeking a fourth term in Washington, is out to capture 50 percent of the vote in the Oct 6 primary to avoid a November runoff against Duke. The senator has gone on the offensive against Duke after earlier seeking to stress his own experience and influence in Congress. One of Johnston's latest TV spots features old footage of Duke saluting a burning Klan cross and quotes him as saying, ``There is no more truly representative symbol of the white race than the fiery cross.'' The narrator then warns: ``David Duke is lying about his past. Don't trust him with our future.'' Another ad, financed by an independent anti-Duke group, features a ``Jeopardy''-type game show that asks what politician hired ex-Nazis to work on his campaign, failed to file state income taxes for four years and lied about serving in the military. Contestants correctly answer, ``Who was David Duke?'' in each case. The ad closes with the caption: ``Who IS David Duke?'' Duke, who was elected to the state House in 1989 and remains the head of the National Association for the Advancement of White People, insists too much is made of his past. He said he plans to go on television this week with a 30-minute fireside chat explaining his stand on the issues. Duke says he is opposed to affirmative action plans for minorities and favors ``civil rights for everybody.'' ``Every elected official is going to find out there is a majority out there in favor of equal rights, not affirmative action, and against further tax increases,'' he says. The presence of a third major Senate candidate, state Sen. Ben Bagert of New Orleans, increases the possibility of a runoff between Johnston and Duke. Although Bagert has the official blessing of the Republican Party, his campaign has been hampered by a lack of money and support. A recent poll by the University of New Orleans showed Johnston with 46 percent of the vote, Duke with 21 percent and Bagert with 8 percent. Twenty percent were undecided and 5 percent would not reveal who they planned to vote for. Under Louisiana's open primary system, all candidates, regardless of party, run on the same ballot. If no candidate wins a majority, the top two finishers meet in a runoff. Based on heavy absentee voting, which ended at noon Saturday, the secretary of state's office predicted that up to 70 percent of the state's registered voters would cast ballots. Johnston said Duke can't win the state, but can damage Louisiana's reputation if he forces his way into a November runoff. Wayne Parent, a political science professor at Louisiana State University, said a runoff involving Duke could be devastating to Republicans in other races across the nation. ``Republicans have been haunted by the perception that they are anti-black,'' Parent said. ``Given David Duke's history, his candidacy is reinforcing the concept of Republicanism and racism.'' Although the national Republican Party has repudiated Duke, Parent said, a runoff would give Duke the opportunity to be ``the Republican Senate candidate for a month.'' National Republican officials have echoed Parent's view, saying they do not want Duke to make a runoff. Sen. Ted Stevens, R-Alaska, campaigned recently with Johnston and said Bagert should drop out of the race. Until early 1989, the Ku Klux Klan's telephone number and that of Duke were the same. Duke also has been criticized for selling neo-Nazi literature out of his office and has admitted he wrote a book showing blacks how to attack ``whitey.'' Research into Duke's past last week brought to light a 1987 letter in which he advocated separating blood banks by race to fight the spread of AIDS. Duke responded that he now would favor segregating the blood supply only if AIDS presented a greater threat to one race or social group. He said he is no longer sure that AIDS is more prevalent among blacks than whites. Duke, a former imperial wizard of the Klan, first attracted attention in the early 1970s when he showed up at Louisiana State University's ``Free Speech Alley'' in a Nazi uniform. Johnston said that if Duke is elected, Louisiana faces the loss of federal projects and military installations. Duke has accused Johnston of using ``scare tactics'' and says he would be effective in Washington because of a changing national political climate.

DOC.HEAD: Voices of Germany's Next Generation: Most are Optimistic
DOC.TEXT: EDITOR'S NOTE: This report is one of a series on the German countdown to unity on Oct. 3. --- EAST BERLIN (AP) - East Germany's children will grow up in a nation that is vastly different from the one in which their parents lived. The Associated Press asked German literature teacher Ingeborg Knirsch to assign an essay to students at Grammar School No. 18 in East Berlin. Forty students were asked to describe how they felt about the end of East Germany and their future in the new land. Here are some representative responses: ---
DOC.HEAD: IRIS BOCK, 14:
DOC.TEXT: I think it's truly good that German unification is coming. You could hardly travel freely and give your opinion in other years. There is naturally also a negative side, for example unemployment, losing your home. In any case, I see Germany as my fatherland, but I think the hatred of foreigners and the drugs are totally bad. There already is hatred of foreigners in the GDR (East Germany). But I am totally for a united Germany. I have truly given no thought about my own future. But I have no fear, because I hope to become a catechism teacher, which is something I could not be before. Up until the fifth grade, I thought the GDR was super. But after I thought about it and talked about it with my parents, I realized it was a bad government. I found it to be sinister and terrible. True, I was content, because we had food and other things, but that's not my opinion now. I hate the Stasi (secret police) and the police. The teachers used to ask us for our opinions, but if we gave our opinions they said that was wrong. ... And (former Communist leader Erich) Honecker gave orders to shoot people who crossed the border. All this was done for the people. ---
DOC.HEAD: JENNY HELIAS, 16:
DOC.TEXT: I think it's right for a united Germany to be created, but not so fast and not in this fashion. The coming unity is bringing many problems for us. My mother lost her job and my father is on shorter hours. Because of that there are a lot of problems in our family. My mother is afraidbecause the jobless pay is so small and she has to go to the unemployment office every day to see if there are jobs. We had a lot of things that were good, such as social things, free kindergarten, work holidays, cheap rent and subsidies for food. My future is very uncertain. I hope to learn languages and later become an interpreter. Perhaps I can also work with computers. We should have reformed the older government, but now it is too late. We brought about a lot with the demonstrations (last year), but the end of the GDR should not have looked like this. Unity came too fast. ---
DOC.HEAD: SUSANNE GOTTSCHLING, 13:
DOC.TEXT: There are ... many problems in my family. My parents were both members of the (Communist Party) and are now in the (reformed Communist Party.) This party is not particularly beloved, but it has many supporters. I don't believe everything was so bad before the revolution. Some things were bad, the Stasi for example, but every country has a secret service. My dream is to be a reporter in Boston and to meet the group New Kids on the Block. But I am afraid that is only a dream. I think it was right the wall was built in 1961, but it should have let more people through. The borders shouldn't have been made absolutely tight. I believe for many people, from a moral standpoint, it was good that the border was opened on Nov. 9, 1989, because my grandma had not seen her brother for 28 years. The end of the GDR is as if my apartment burned down. It was the homeland. ---
DOC.HEAD: JULIA AXMANN, 13:
DOC.TEXT: I don't want any unity. Because I always read in the paper and see on television and hear on the radio that there is so much joblessness and so much fear. The rents rise. How can you pay your rent if you don't have a job? I think it's terrible that the CDU (Christian Democratic Union, the governing party in both Germanys) is getting rid of all the foreigners here. They have been here for years and now what? I am afraid that I won't find a job. I want to be a zookeeper. I find it idiotic that the stores here won't sell East products anymore. Now that the wall fell I don't really feel secure. Now there is robbery and murder. I also find it idiotic that you have to pay for a doctor visit. What happens if you are sick and don't have a job? ---
DOC.HEAD: CORNELIA JACH, 12:
DOC.TEXT: The unity of German brings for our fatherland great changes. Many positive things have come to us, for example, a new range of goods, but also it raises new questions, for example, unemployment. ...The GDR was a highly developed socialist country with many industries. Certainly I can't write about all of that because I am still small. I am only 12 years old and have still not made a plan for the future. Now the GDR will soon end and we will join together with the FRG (West Germany). In case of a war, which we would never hope for, that is a good thing. Because Karl Marx indeed said: ``Unity makes strength.'' ---
DOC.HEAD: PEGGY LIEBETRAU, 13:
DOC.TEXT: Before unification on Oct. 3, I have a lot of fear because I don't know how bad it will be and whether we'll see riots on our streets. Of course, there are things that please me, too. We can buy pretty things and sweets. But we must not think about our futures, but the jobs of our parents and about the rent. My parents cannot afford to pay 1,000 (marks) per month in our building, where the elevator doesn't work and there is no warm water. I don't think it's right that whatever is in the (West Germany) must be given to us. For bread we paid 90 pfennigs, and now we pay three marks. I'm worried about my future. I can't believe that everything our parents produced was bad. ---
DOC.HEAD: RALF OTTFUELING, 16
DOC.TEXT: The coming unity is good because we will live as one country instead of two. I hope my parents have money to keep sending me to school. I don't know anymore which profession to choose. Jobs that I sometimes wanted aren't any good anymore. The GDR had many good sides and not only bad ones, as everyone always says. The old government made a lot of mistakes. I'm not so happy about the end of the GDR because it was my home. We had no contact with crime and drugs, and now we're confronted directly by it.
