DOC.HEAD: Study Shows One-Fifth of Eligible Voters Cast Primary Ballots
DOC.TEXT: Fewer than 20 percent of eligible voters cast ballots in the 1990 primaries, according to a nonpartisan study released on Saturday. Dismal as it might appear, that turnout was about average for a midterm election, reported the Committee for the Study of the American Electorate. The report also cautioned that turnout in primaries is not an indicator of whether voters will be motivated to go to the polls in November. The turnout for states which had primaries in both parties was 19.56 percent, down a fraction of a percent from 1986. There were a few bright spots. Hot contests for the Republican and Democratic nominations for governor of Massachusetts brought out 32 percent of the voters, the highest turnout for such elections there since 1962. In the District of Columbia, nearly 27 percent of the eligible Democrats turned out to choose nominees for mayor, the highest participation since the city gained home rule in 1974. In both Massachusetts and the District of Columbia, the surge of primary election voters resulted in a rejection of political insiders. John Silber won the Democratic nomination for governor of Massachusetts, easily defeating the pre-election favorite, former Attorney General Frank Bellotti. Also campaigning as an outsider, William Weld captured the GOP nomination for governor, defeating legislative Republican leader Steven Pierce. Sharon Pratt Dixon, who has never held elective office, defeated four officeholders to win the Democratic nomination for mayor of Washington. ``Even in this era of cynicism, public disillusionment with politics and declining voter participation, the public will vote if they have something important to vote for or against,'' said Curtis B. Gans, director of the committee. But Gans said it was ``too early to tell whether the anti-incumbent mood that was reflected in some of the primaries will turn activist (in November) and whether it will affect all incumbents or, as is more traditional, the party which occupies the White House.'' He also noted primary election turnout has ``not necessarily been a reliable indicator of general election trends.'' The states with the highest percentage turnout in the primaries were Alaska with 37.9 percent; Wyoming 36.3; Arkansas 32.5; Massachusetts 32.4; Montana 32; Oklahoma 31.3, and Nebraska 30.2. Lowest turnout was in Connecticut with 5.2 percent; New Jersey 5.5; South Carolina 7.4; Wisconsin 9.0; Maine 11.3, and Michigan 12.3.

DOC.HEAD: East Germany's Children Ponder the New World
With AM-Germany-New Voices, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: EDITOR'S NOTE: This report is one of a series on the German countdown to unity on Oct. 3. ---

Ingeborg Knirsch thumbed through the thick stack of essays and shook her head. So many pages of childhood scrawl were laced with fear and anxiety. These were words written by East German children about the end of their nation and the birth of a new one. This was the voice of the next generation. ``I was astounded ... astounded,'' said Mrs. Knirsch, a teacher in East Berlin. ``I'm more optimistic about our future than these children seem to be.'' What these essays reflected were households in turmoil, a nation in transition, a society on the edge of enormous change. No one has a greater stake in the fate of the new German nation than the children of East Germany. The shifting winds of history have profoundly altered their future. They will be the first generation of East Germans to come of age in a free land, but one that faces tremendous social upheaval as it leaves the old ways behind. The Associated Press visited Grammar School No. 18 and asked Mrs. Knirsch to assign some of her German literature students an essay about Wednesday's unification of Germany. She chose an eighth-grade class and a sixth-grade class and told them to write 100-200 words. But each class produced torrents of words, an outpouring that mixed hope for the distant future with a startling bleakness about the coming months. ``I told them `short, short, short,' and they said `No, I must write,''' Mrs. Knirsch said. ``Five hundred, 600 words, one of them wrote 800 words. In 45 minutes!'' She said she was stunned by the content. ``They were worried about keeping their homes, about their parents keeping their jobs, about their rents rising,'' she said. Much, she said, was a reflection of the worries expressed by anxious parents, the grim accounts of furrowed-brow newscasters. ``Everything is getting more expensive ... rents, telephone service and so forth, and many people are jobless,'' wrote Diana Schulz, 12. ``My parents also are already jobless.'' ``The rent is higher and my parents lost their jobs,'' wrote Lohin Lueben, 12. ``The only good thing about Oct. 3 is that it's a school holiday.'' There was support for German unity but, paradoxically, regret the ``GDR'' - German Democratic Republic - would end. These children, like all others, were drilled to be loyal to their nation and Communism, and suspicious of the crime-ridden, greedy West. ``The GDR was my fatherland, and now the GDR really won't be any more. It is incomprehensible,'' wrote 12-year-old Anke Schramm. You can kick a soccer ball from the playground of Grammar School No. 18 to where the Berlin Wall once loomed. Checkpoint Charlie, the former Allied border crossing, stood half a block away. Much of the neighborhood, part of East Berlin's increasingly seedy Leipziger Street, has become a lure for derelicts and criminals. On Tuesday, about 200 leftist radicals from West Berlin, wearing black ski masks and wielding pipes, destroyed the front of a grocery store nearby. Mrs. Knirsch said many children watched the scene from their apartment buildings. Many essays contained worried references to crime. ``Now that the Wall fell I don't really feel secure,'' wrote Julia Axmann, 13.

DOC.HEAD: Dithering Japan Shies Away from World Leadership Role
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet empire crumbles. Germany unites. Iraq invades. America intervenes. Japan, though, mainly talks. And talks. Before the Persian Gulf crisis began, serious questions were raised about whether this Pacific power would soon replace the United States as the leading global force. To some it seemed only a question of time. It will take more than time, Japan analysts now say. It's not likely to happen at all, many agree, because in an era when many commentators are declaring the start of a new world order, the world's No. 2 economic power lacks the vision to be anything more. Japan, whose postwar rise was helped by avoiding the military costs shouldered by the United States and Soviet Union, may see little reason to grasp a greater political or military role worldwide. ``No other country can replace the United States as the leader of the world,'' said Seizaburo Sato, a Tokyo University political scientist and adviser to two former prime ministers. ``The world has become uni-polar in a sense. The U.S. is the only remaining superpower. But the pole is not so high as it once was, so we would like to support the pole and make it higher.'' During the gulf crisis, as in many times past, Japan has been nudged into action by the United States. After 3{ weeks of government haggling, it promised $1 billion and medical aid to the multinational gulf force and Arab nations affected by the U.N. trade embargo on Iraq. Washington criticized the offer as stingy. Japan returned with a promise of $3 billion more. But the belated offer smacked of Japan's old habit of doing the minimum necessary to appease America. ``Japan does not have any idea what to do beyond joining in the economic sanctions,'' the Asahi Shimbun newspaper editorialized. Today, two months after Iraq's seizure of Kuwait, there are about 200,000 U.S., British and French troops in the Middle East. Japan has sent 17 medical personnel. And a debate looms in Parliament over Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu's proposal Thursday - made on the eve of a U.S. visit - to deploy a small number of unarmed troops overseas for the first time since World War II. Some conservative politicans, fearful of a loss of international prestige for Japan, are pushing for more: a reinterpretation of the ban in Japan's postwar constitution on using force overseas. They are quietly backed by commanders of the Self-Defense Forces, Japan's military. But the commanders have little say in a country still bitter over an independent military that broke free of civilian control in the 1930s, leading to war. Japan's political timidity predates the gulf crisis. Wielding economic might beyond her militarist dreams a half-century ago, Japan still dragged its feet in offering aid to newly liberalized Eastern Europe. Officials contended the region was too remote. Tokyo recently became the world's No. 1 source of foreign aid, but only after years of pressure from the United States and other Western nations tired of watching Japan recycle profits back into its blockbuster economy. Most of the aid has been issued in loans, not the typical grants, and the program has been criticized as commercially self-serving and inefficient. ``Japan still doesn't have a concept of itself as a global actor,'' said Sheila Smith, a researcher at the Japan Institute of International Affairs in Tokyo. ``(Japanese believe) the world is not their problem.'' U.S. public opinion polls show Americans overwhelmingly back President Bush's policy of intervening in the gulf. Surveys here, however, indicate most Japanese feel America is only defending its oil interests, even though Japan imports more of its oil - 70 percent - from the Middle East than any other industrialized nation. In one recent poll, 83 percent of Japanese said they opposed sending military personnel to the gulf. Japan's leaders are not being naive. As historian Paul Kennedy argued in his bestselling book ``The Rise And Fall of The Great Powers,'' major nations have declined by overexpanding, straining their economies with military expenditures. Japan has avoided such a role. ``Japan has been able to enjoy all the advantages of evolving into a global economic giant, but without any of the political responsibilities and territorial disadvantages which have, historically, followed from such a growth,'' Kennedy wrote. ``Little wonder that it prefers things to remain as they are.'' Japanese analysts argue that empire-building nations usually focused on pragmatic, self-centered policies. Only the United States, they say, has made its ostensible goal the exportation of democracy and freedom as universal principles. Japan recently made independent diplomatic forays into North Korea and China as part of its strategy of creating a regional power base. Japan's foreign policy has been summed up as: Do whatever is needed to maintain Japan's ``special relationship'' with the United States - a code phrase signifying the U.S.-Japan security arrangement and Japan's huge export stake in the U.S. economy. ``It's been a very successful foreign policy for 40 years,'' said Gerald Curtis, a Japanese politics expert at Columbia University in New York. ``But it's no longer sufficient.''

DOC.HEAD: Crews Work to Contain Slick From Tanker-Barge Collision
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with channel reopened and spill assessment. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: The Houston Ship Channel reopened today after emergency crews determined that only a small amount of cleaning solvent escaped from a barge punctured by a Norwegian tanker in Galveston Bay. ``It looks like it evaporated off,'' said Lynn Garner, president of Garner Environmental Co. of Houston. ``There's no pollution.'' No injuries were reported in the latest accident in the Houston Ship Channel, where 700,000 gallons of oil was spilled from a Greek tanker in July. The 538-foot tanker on Friday evening struck one of two barges pulled by a tugboat about three miles offshore from Texas City, the Coast Guard said. ``The tug was able to push the barges out of the channel and up onto the bank,'' Coast Guard Cmdr. Frank Whipple said. ``They are resting on the bank.'' At least one of the 297-foot barge's eight tanks, each with a capacity of 134,400 gallons, leaked a substance known as reformate, said Michael Lee, a Coast Guard spokesman in Galveston. Reformate is a volatile, colorless petroleum distillate used as a manufacturing solvent, as a dry-cleaning fluid and in blending gasolines. Garner said he did not know how much solvent spilled, but ``it's a small amount.'' In June, the Norwegian tanker Mega Borg was rocked by an explosion about 58 miles offshore from Galveston, spilling more than 3.9 million gallons of oil. In July, about 700,000 gallons of oil spilled into the environmentally sensitive bay when the Greek tanker Shinoussa and two barges collided. About 860 million barrels of oil are shipped into Texas ports each year, according to the state General Land Office, which is in charge of cleaning up oil spills.

DOC.HEAD: Famed French Legionnaires Arrive in Saudi Arabia
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The first units of the famed French Foreign Legion arrived Saturday in Saudi Arabia, joining the largest deployment of French forces overseas since Algeria's war of independence. About 150 men marched silently off the ferry Le Corse, which docked in this Red Sea port at noon after an eight-day trip from Toulon. Docking was delayed more than two hours by thick morning fog. Two cargo ships, the Atlas and the Cap Ferat, docked Saturday with some of the French force's 250 trucks. Five more ships carrying troops and equipment are expected the next two days. The legionnaires are part of France's 4,000-man Rapid Action Force. Most of that contingent is due to arrive Sunday at the vast, new industrial complex in Yanbu. When the deployment is complete, there will be 2,300 legionnaires in their distinctive dark green berets in Saudi Arabia among the growing U.S.-led multinational force confronting Iraq. France, which has 14 warships in the region and is sending three squadrons of combat jets, will have a force of about 13,000 men in the gulf region when the deployment is completed. French Defense Minister Jean-Pierre Chevenement has said the French force will be autonomous and not under U.S. command. ``Heat is our first enemy,'' said Capt. Renard, the officer in charge of the first company of the 2nd Foreign Legion infantry regiment based in Nimes, France. He would not give his first name. Aside from the legionnaires, the ferry carried about 750 other troops - 150 from the 21st Regiment of Marine Infantry from Frejus and about 500 from logistics and medical units. Its hold was full of trucks carting everything from kitchens to generators and ammunition. The ground forces will to head overland for northeastern Saudi Arabia, a three-day trip. They will take up positions among the other foreign troops in the Legion's largest overseas deployment since Algeria's 1954-62 independence war. The position will be about 60 miles from the nearest Iraqi troops across the border in occupied Kuwait. About 150 troops of the Rapid Action Force who arrived Monday are already in place. Gen. Michel Roquejeoffre, the overall French commander and a paratrooper, greeted Col. Gilbert LeGuen, commander of the logistics unit. Most of the legionnaires maintained a stony silence, following orders, as they marched single-file along the quay. Their first stay will be in a warehouse larger than a football field to regroup for the trip across the desert. Their commanding officer said it has been a half-century since the Legion gave refuge to any person off the street. ``We take who we like, not just anybody. The days of anybody are over,'' said Renard, a 10-year veteran of the force. But the Legion is still made up of 90 nationalities and occasionally British-clipped English could be heard from the ranks. The legionnaires themselves would not say where they were originally from, although about half are French. ``Once you join the legion, you're just a legionnaire,'' said an officer who ordered all his men to speak French while reporters were around. Renard, 47, said most of the men under his command had returned from more than four months in the Sahara desert in Chad last February, and he expected conditions in Saudi Arabia to be the same. ``I think it may be a little hotter here. We'll find out,'' the captain said. Renard said the legionnaires had not been briefed on how long they would stay in Saudi Arabia. ``The legionnaires do what is asked of them. A legionnaire is a soldier first,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Soviets Inch Toward World Bank, IMF Membership
DOC.TEXT: After 45 years, the Soviet Union finally got invited to the premier celebration of capitalism, the annual meetings of the World Bank and International Monetary Fund. But the Soviet delegates spent the week sitting in a corner, far away from the action, playing the role of economic wallflowers. They came to the ball but were not asked to dance. Instead, they sat on the sidelines right next to Mongolia. The only difference is that Mongolia has formally applied for membership in the IMF and the World Bank and its application is expected to receive speedy approval. The Soviet Union, uncertain of its chances for success, has yet to apply for membership. The Soviet delegation, however, left no doubt that the country would like to join the institutions Soviet leaders used to deride as bastions of capitalist economics. The IMF and World Bank, with their huge lending resources, look a lot more inviting these days with Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev appealing for massive amounts of Western aid for his faltering economy. Victor V. Geraschenko, the head of the Soviet delegation and the chairman of the country's state bank, the Gosbank, met wit various finance ministers and with top IMF and World Bank officials to present his country's case. He declined to be specific about when the Soviets might submit a formal membership application although he said one could come next year. But even with the desperate situation facing the Soviet economy, IMF and World Bank officials said they did not see any prospect for quick membership for the country. ``The Soviets are obviously interested in integrating their economy into the global economy. But it will take some time for them to go through the process of membership application,'' World Bank President Barber Conable said at the close of last week's meetings. ``We do not anticipate an early membership by the Soviet Union,'' Conable said. Officials give a variety of reasons for hesistance in accepting the Soviets as members in the two institutions. These range from the difficulty in interpreting Soviet economic statistics to the lack of convertibility for the Soviet currency, the ruble. However, the major stumbling block is political. The United States, the country with the largest voting power in both institutions, is at present opposed to Soviet membership. The fear in the Bush administration is that given the turmoil wracking the Soviet economy, massive amounts of Western aid supplied now could well end up being wasted or perhaps even delaying needed movement toward a free-market economy. Treasury Undersecretary David Mulford said the United States is awaiting the results of a study of the Soviet economy before deciding whether to modify its current opposition to direct Western aid. That review, which is being coordinated by the IMF, is scheduled to be completed in December. Top finance officials from the world's seven richest industrial countries - the United States, Japan, West Germany, Britain, France, Canada and Italy - received a closed-door briefing on the study last week. One official, who spoke on condition that he not be named, said IMF Managing Director Michel Camdessus stressed that the Soviet Union needed a strong central bank as a key step in getting control of its serious economic problems. The debate over how much power to give the central government is currently being hotly debated in the Soviet Union with many leaders in the 15 Soviet republics seeking ways to give the central government less, not more, power. In the absence of IMF and World Bank membership, the two agencies did make an offer to provide the Soviets with technical assistance, an approach that also is favored by the United States. ``The Soviets are interested in doing a lot of restructuring and doing it fairly quickly. We are happy to advise them about that because that is our business,'' said Conable, whose agency last year made $20 billion of development loans to Third World countries. Camdessus said there was a precedent for the IMF providing technical advice to non-members. He said the agency was instrumental in helping Namibia set up a central bank before it became a member this year and he said the same help would be available to the Soviets. With the speed of current events, Camdessus said it would be wrong to assume that just because the Soviets did not now qualify for IMF-World Bank membership, that situation would never change. ``At last year's meeting, who could have imagined that we would be on the verge of seeing a unified Germany,'' Camdessus said. ``History is moving very rapidly. To tell you where we will be in a year or two is very difficult.''

DOC.HEAD: Iran Finds Itself Big Winner So Far in Persian Gulf Crisis
An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: Iran's resumption of diplomatic relations with Britain caps two months of nonstop political, military and economic gains for Tehran since its old foe, Iraq, invaded Kuwait. For the past few weeks, everything seems to have been going Iran's way amid the chaos touched off by the Iraqi invasion. In many ways, Iran has won more since Kuwait was overrun Aug. 2 by Iraqi forces than it did in the decade of upheaval and war that followed the 1979 Islamic revolution. The gulf crisis is far from being resolved. But Tehran, courted by both sides, is already looking like one of the winners from the confrontation between two of its old enemies, Iraq and the United States. The irony is that Tehran owes much of what it has gained to Saddam Hussein, whose country it fought from 1980 to 1988 in a war that had no victor, only victims, and caused at least 1 million casualties. Saddam's invasion gave Iranian President Hashemi Rafsanjani a golden opportunity to accelerate his efforts to end the Islamic republic's isolation, improve relations with the West and secure investment and advanced technology to rebuild the economy. Last week, Iran boasted it has taken delivery of advanced MiG-29 interceptors for its badly depleted air force under a $6 billion economic and military agreement with Moscow. Restoring relations with London will likely speed up Rafsanjani's efforts to normalize links with western Europe and could herald the release of British hostages held in Lebanon. Four Britons are among the 13 Westerners missing in Lebanon. Most are believed held by pro-Iranian Shiite Moslem militants. The Tehran Times, which often reflects Rafsanjani's thinking, noted Saturday: ``The complete normalization of Iranian relations with the European Community can lead to extensive cooperation in many areas, particularly the Persian Gulf crisis.'' Tehran severed relations with Britain on March 7, 1989, over Salman Rushdie's novel, ``The Satanic Verses,'' which Iran's late revolutionary leader, Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, deemed had blasphemed Islam. He issued a fatwa, or religious ruling, condemning Rushdie to death. Britain rejected Iranian demands to ban the book and denounce Rushdie. Iran refused to lift the death sentence, even after Khomeini died in June 1989. The 12 EC nations withdrew their ambassadors from Tehran in solidarity with Britain after Khomeini's death decree. Most later sent envoys back, but have withheld full normalization until relations with Britain were restored. Thursday's announcement that relations are being restored did not spell out the agreement beyond saying it was based on ``mutual respect.'' But British Foreign Secretary Douglas Hurd stressed that Iranian leaders had indicated there would be no interference in the ``internal affairs of any other country.'' That was interpreted to mean Iran would quietly drop the death sentence on Rushdie, without publicly revoking it. There have even been slight movements in Iran's stormy relationship with the United States. On Sept. 21, the United States paid a $200 million claim to Iran for undelivered American equipment orders dating from before the 1979 Islamic revolution. It was the largest claim before a tribunal settling billions in Iranian assets frozen by the United States. In the last few days, Iran has also restored relations with Tunisia, severed in 1987 amid allegations Tehran was backing Moslem fundamentalists seeking to topple the government. There are signs, too, of a thaw in the feud with Saudi Arabia. Some analysts and diplomats are talking about including Iran in a new regional defense alliance with Egypt, Turkey, Syria and Saudi Arabia. Whether that ever emerges, Arab strategists even talking about including Iran underlines now how Rafsanjani has led his country toward international acceptance after years as a pariah and how the gulf crisis has redrawn the political map of the Middle East. ``The Islamic Republic has emerged more powerful than ever. It has won everything for which it fought,'' an Asian diplomat in Tehran said in a telephone interview. Saddam, finding himself in a tight corner after the invasion, abruptly gave into Iranian demands Aug. 15 after two years of deadlocked peace negotiations on formally ending the war. He withdrew his army from Iranian territory seized in the conflict, began a prisoner-of-war exchange and agreed to share sovereignty over the Shatt-al-Arab waterway, the strategically important southern border between Iran and Iraq. Baghdad's improved relations with Tehran have allowed Iraq to shift forces toward Kuwait. Iraq also has tried to persuade Iran to break a U.N. Security Council embargo, but Iran has pledged to abide by the sanctions. For the Iranians, Saddam's cave-in meant they had won the gulf war, in a moral sense if not militarily. They felt it vindicated their claim that Iraq was the aggressor and their warnings that Saddam would one day turn on his erstwhile allies like Kuwait and Saudi Arabia. Iran's leaders are now waiting for a possible visit to Tehran by Saddam himself - an event that for them would be the final act of Iraqi submission. --- EDITOR'S NOTE - Ed Blanche, Middle East news editor for The Associated Press, is based in Nicosia and has covered the region since 1985.

DOC.HEAD: Armageddon Prophecy: Persian Gulf Crisis May Herald War To End All Wars
With AM-Gulf-Armageddon-Bible
With LaserGraphic
DOC.TEXT: The gathering of nations to the brink of war in the Middle East is a sign some evangelical leaders believe may herald the most feared and sought-after age in Christianity - Armageddon and the Second Coming. At least one fundamentalist television evangelist believes God may call all born-again Christians up to heaven at any day. That would usher in a seven-year period of destruction that only a third of the world's population would survive before Christ comes to rule over a world in which the lion will lay down with the lamb and swords will be beaten into plowshares. ``Saddam Hussein is just kind of an activator bringing it all together,'' said the Rev. Charles Taylor, host of the syndicated television show ``Today in Bible Prophecy.'' ``It's time to rejoice for the Christians. We're going home.'' What has caused the current revival in speculation of the end time is the resurgence of Babylon in the form of modern-day Iraq. The ruins of the ancient city lie 60 miles south of present-day Baghdad. Several of the Bible's prophetic books, including Isaiah, Revelation and Ezekiel, refer to the rise and fall of Babylon. Some believe Babylon's rise today may be the precursor of the final battle between the Lord and the enemies of Israel, and the coming of the savior to rule over the world. Few evangelicals are ready to don white robes and implore people on street corners to ``Repent, the end is near!'' But some are saying Iraq's invasion of Kuwait and menacing stance toward Israel point toward the the final conflict between good and evil. ``I would not predict we are near the end of the age, although I personally think we are,'' evangelist Billy Graham said. Religious movements built around predictions of Christ's Second Coming have long been a part of U.S. religious history. In the 19th century, the Rev. William Miller caused thousands of Americans to prepare for the Lord's Coming. Even after his predicted dates in the 1840s passed by uneventfully, his work laid the foundation for the Seventh-Day Adventist movement. Later in the century, Jehovah's Witnesses grew into a national movement amid similar predictions. More recently, some thought former President Reagan's foreign policy, particularly his hawkish view of Soviet Union, may have been based on a belief in biblical warnings of Armageddon being started by invaders from the north. Saddam has done little to discourage speculation he may trigger the final conflict. Seeking to exploit his nation's past glories, the Iraqi leader has spent millions to rebuild Babylon. He also has portrayed himself as the new Nebuchadnezzar, the Babylonian warrior-king who sacked Jerusalem in the 6th century B.C. In seeking greater Arab support for his invasion of Kuwait, Saddam also has spoken in increasingly ominous terms about Israel. ``History has gone full circle and we are coming back to these lands,'' Graham said during a recent crusade. ``This is not another Korea, it is not another Vietnam - it is something far more sinister and far more difficult.'' ``The circumstances are such that we see the culmination of God's plan for planet Earth,'' said the Rev. Paul Schenck of New Covenant Tabernacle, a large Assemblies of God church in suburban Buffalo, N.Y. He added that he has mixed feelings about the possibility - ``I will not be disappointed if my children grow up and I see my great-grandchildren.'' Most mainline biblical scholars give little credence to such speculation. They say such analysis takes out of context biblical passages that were written in a specific culture and time for different teaching purposes. Rabbi James Rudin of the American Jewish Committee puts it bluntly: ``I would not give Saddam Hussein any place in a theological end time.'' Such criticism does not bother a fundamentalist such as Taylor, who interprets the Bible literally and believes the bodily ascent of Christians into heaven before Armageddon can happen at any time. ``Wars usually happen in the Middle East in the October period - before the snows come and after the hot weather,'' Taylor said. ``The Lord would really have to put it on hold the way things are going.'' thers are less certain that the decisive battle between the forces of good and evil is at hand. ``Even some of the most intense prophecy preachers are reluctant to say, `This is it','' said the Rev. Richard Buhler, host of a national radio show for evangelicals called ``Table Talk.'' Some factors work against the theories linking Saddam and Armageddon. For one thing, skeptics can cite references to Babylon's being a great power holding the riches of the world at the time of its destruction. The Rev. Chuck Smith, a radio evangelist based in Costa Mesa, Calif., says the Iraqis could fit that description within two years if they gain control of enough oil. ``God is focusing the attention of the world on the Middle East to alert us to the fact time is running out,'' said Smith, whose program, ``The Word for Today,'' is heard on 150 radio stations. Meantime, what does one do? Taylor is urging his listeners to make a final effort to convert friends and relatives to born-again Christianity, while others say Christians should look beyond the initial period of suffering to promises of another paradise beyond Armageddon. ``Rather than forebodings of doom, these things to us are just the prelude to a glorious new day,'' said Smith. ``Personally, I believe the Lord will ... create heaven on Earth.''

DOC.HEAD: Bush's New Ties With U.N. Mark Sharp Turnabout
DOC.TEXT: Three years ago, George Bush complained that the United Nations was ``another light that failed,'' largely ineffective and sometimes counterproductive. On Monday, he will stand before the General Assembly and praise the U.N.'s resolve in opposing Iraq's aggression. There has been a remarkable turnabout in the White House attitude toward the U.N., which not so long ago was viewed as a platform for anti-Americanism and Third World dissent. Now, administration leaders do not hide their delight over the tough stands taken by the U.N. against Iraq, spanning eight Security Council resolutions condemning its invasion of Kuwait and imposing bans on trade and financial dealings. ``It's unbelievable,'' said John Bolton, assistant secretary of State for international relations. ``It's like being in San Francisco in 1945'' when the U.N. was founded amid an air of idealism. ``We are reading articles of the U.N. charter that have not been seriously read in 45 years,' Bolton said. ``A lot of what we're doing, we're doing quite literally for the first time in the history of the United Nations.'' Says Bush: ``We're now in sight of a United Nations that performs as envisioned by its founders. ... The United Nations is backing up its words with action.'' The dramatic change is due in large measure to the warming of relations between the United States and Soviet Union. The superpowers, throughout the Cold War, had used the U.N. as a primary forum for ideological battles. Now, they stand more as allies than adversaries. ``When the U.S. and the Soviets decide the U.N. will be a serious place, it's a serious place,'' said Judith Kipper, a Middle East expert at the Brookings Institution, a Washington think tank. There are other explanations, as well, for the U.N.'s unity in the Persian Gulf crisis. There are Third World nations worried by the specter of a larger nation gobbling up a helpless neighbor; there are countries concerned about oil prices and supplies; there are countries jockeying for position in the Arab world. ``Everyone is acting according to their self-interests,'' said Alan Keyes, former assistant secretary of State for international relations. ``It didn't require much persuasion'' to achieve a U.N. consensus. Charles Lichenstein, who was alternate U.S. representative at the U.N. in the early 1980s, said the Security Council resolutions were a useful way of rallying nations that traditionally feel obliged to be anti-American. ``It provides a number of countries with a marvelous excuse for being on the side of the United States when they might not have leapt to their feet otherwise,'' he said. Bolton said that when Iraq invaded Kuwait, ``it was kind of an automatic decision'' to turn to the U.N. For one thing, Bush had been U.S. ambassador to the world body from 1971 to 1973 and had a feel for the organization. Perhaps more importantly, there was a belief that the U.N., over the past three to four years, had started to act effectively in matters of international peace and security, such as the Iran-Iraq war, the transition of Namibia to independent status and U.N. oversight of Nicaraguan elections. Bush signaled a new attitude toward the U.N. when he picked a highly respected career diplomat, Thomas Pickering, as U.N. ambassador. A skilled trouble shooter, Pickering had served as ambassador both in Israel and in Jordan. ``The fact that he selected Pickering shows very strongly that he (Bush) has a commitment to the institution,'' said James Spiegelman, director of research for Georgetown University's Center for International Business and Trade. ``You can't underestimate the importance of having a guy like Pickering in there as Bush's top man, maneuvering votes and doing his bidding.'' Administration officials say Bush has taken an active role with Secretary of State James A. Baker III in advising Pickering. ``He knows the strengths and weaknesses of the U.N. better than the head of government anywhere in the world,'' said Bolton. ``He just has a very good sense of the institution.'' With a penchant for personal diplomacy, Bush also has used the telephone frequently to sustain the consensus against Iraq. Between Aug. 2 and Sept. 7, Bush talked with foreign leaders on 71 occasions about the gulf, officials said. Yet, some question whether Bush's U.N. experience has been instrumental in dealing with the world body. ``The fact is, it takes you about five minutes to learn what string to pull,'' said Lichenstein. ``He was there for substantially less than two years. You don't learn very much in two years.'' Keyes said that with reduced Soviet tensions and Arab nervousness about Iraq, ``It's not very hard for us to put together the coalition'' at the U.N.

DOC.HEAD: Cape Verde Parliament Approves Proposal for Multiparty System
DOC.TEXT: The parliament of Cape Verde has approved a proposal to revise the West African island nation's constitution to permit a multiparty system and free elections, according to news reports Saturday. The ruling African Party for the Independence of Cape Verde (PAIVV) has announced plans to hold legislative elections in January and presidential elections the following month. Under the current 1980 constitution, the PAICV is the only party permitted in the nation of 360,000 inhabitants, which gained independence from Portugal in 1975. The PAICV has governed since independence. Portuguese newspapers reported Saturday that the government and the leading opposition Movement for Democracy (MPD) had reached agreement on major political reforms after four days of talks. The government agreed to replace top people in state-run media to avoid manipulation of the news preceding the elections. But MPD leaders criticized the government for refusing to recognize the existence of a political police force and promise to disband it. The Popular Assembly, or parliament, also voted Friday to remove from the constitution a reference to the PAICV as the driving force in the state and society. The assembly is expected too to consider proposals to grant the president powers to veto government decisions and dismiss the Cabinet. Cape Verde President Aristides Pereira has vowed to steer the 10-island archipelago 385 miles west of Senegal into a free-market economy.

DOC.HEAD: New England Pins Hopes On Fall Tourist Season
DOC.TEXT: The hills know nothing of Saddam Hussein; they hear no talk of recession. The vibrant reds, oranges and yellows emblazon the countryside in a burst of glory before the long, white silence that lies ahead. Only the people worry, especially those who make money from the annual pilgrimage of millions of ``leaf-peepers'' who come north to view nature's autumn splendor. New England's sagging economy has many in the tourism business eager for a hearty foliage season. ``This is a critical season for the travel industry,'' said Christopher Barbieri, president of the Vermont Chamber of Commerce. ``After a soft summer in the region, we're counting on this as a last blast before ski season.'' But with wild cards such as the Persian Gulf crisis and increased competition from other states, the New England fall season may be weaker than in the past. ``This Middle East crisis could not have come at a worse time,'' Barbieri said. ``We're watching to see how it affects the economic situation, which will in turn affect us. It's a danger signal.'' A slow summer in the northern New England states - Vermont, New Hampshire and Maine - has them looking to the mid-September to mid-October fall foliage season to bolster the travel and retail industries. ``June and July were off by 5 and 15 percent,'' said Dick Hamilton, president of New Hampshire's White Mountain Attractions Association. ``If we can do well and go into a long, cold winter with a good fall season, people will be happy.'' In Maine, where tourism is the state's second largest industry behind paper production, a weak season hurts the whole economy, said John A. Johnson of the Maine Tourism Office. ``Tourism is all we've got. In Massachusetts, people who aren't hired as waiters or chambermaids can get jobs in light industry. We don't have that here,'' he said. ``Oh, do we need a good year.'' The fall season has long been considered the gravy of the tourism year, because little or no promotion was needed to get the people here. But competition from other states that are heavily promoting the colors of their leaves - even Arkansas is jumping for the leaf-peepers with a sophisticated advertising campaign - is hurting the New England states, Barbieri said. ``We've always taken it for granted, but those days of assuming we have a corner on the leaf market are over,'' he said. ``Other places have discovered that they have pretty leaves too.'' New Hampshire, Maine and Vermont officials each estimate about a million people flock to their states in the brief but brilliant season. But some of those people travel by car and may be inclined to stay at home this year because of rising gas prices. ``If there is a fuel shortage scare, then we will see a drop in business,'' Barbieri said. ``And if gas prices rise above the psychological threshold of $2 a gallon, people may think twice.'' One indicator of a slow fall is the hotel and bus tour reservations. Some motor coach operators say the market to New England is softer than it has been in the past. ``Reservations are not where they were four or five years ago,'' said Peter Tauk, owner and general manager for Tauk Tours of Westport, Conn. ``New England this fall is soft for every tour operator.'' The states are not forecasting a poor year, just a year that could leave some general store tills a little less full. Barbieri said he expects the million tourists who will visit Vermont - twice the state's population - to spend more than $16 million. And the tourists in the fall are likely to be a bit freer with their money. Foliage draws the singles, couples and senior citizens, who may have a greater disposable income, Barbieri said. ``These folks are less likely to ride the Alpine Slide, but more likely to buy some things for Christmas,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Faces Possibly Bigger Hurdle in S&L Case
SUBS 16th graf pvs, bgng: Bush's financial, to restore dropped first reference to Vierra
DOC.TEXT: After combatively defending himself at a public hearing against federal conflict-of-interest charges, Neil Bush now faces a potentially more damaging hurdle that could hit his wallet as well as his reputation. In addition to the government's conflict-of-interest case, the president's son faces a new $200 million lawsuit against him and other former directors of a failed Colorado savings and loan. The suit alleges that ``gross negligence'' by the directors contributed to the thrift's collapse. That intensifies the pressure on Neil Bush, 35, who already has become an unwilling symbol of the savings and loan crisis and a potential political liability for his father and the Republican Party. The negligence suit, filed Sept. 21 by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp., ``obviously made it more difficult'' for Neil Bush, his attorney, James Nesland, said in an interview Friday. Bush testified for three hours Thursday before an administrative law judge, insisting that his business dealings with two Denver developers did not conflict with his role as a director of Silverado Banking, Savings and Loan Association. The developers, Kenneth Good and Bill Walters, eventually defaulted on more than $132 million in loans from Silverado. Silverado collapsed in late 1988, leaving U.S. taxpayers with a $1 billion tab for reimbursing depositors of the federally insured institution. Bush was a director of Silverado from August 1985 to August 1988, quitting the post a few days after his father won the Republican presidential nomination. The federal Office of Thrift Supervision is seeking an administrative order against Bush that could lead to barring him from the banking and savings industry. The regulators contend that Bush failed to adequately inform fellow Silverado directors of his business ties with Good and Walters, who invested in Bush's oil company, JNB Exploration. Administrative Law Judge Daniel J. Davidson will examine testimony from last week's hearing before him and is expected to recommend in January to OTS Director Timothy Ryan what sanctions, if any, should be taken against Bush. Ryan is scheduled to make a decision in May, and Bush would have the right to appeal it to a federal court. Just four days before the start of the OTS hearing in a federal courtroom in Denver, the FDIC filed its lawsuit. ``That can't be coincidental,'' Nesland said in an interview in his high-rise office. ``One has to recognize that those (federal) agencies act jointly.'' The timing of the lawsuit, he contended, was ``symptomatic of the concerted effort by the banking agencies'' to prejudice his client's case. The regulators insisted, however, that the suit was filed that day because the FDIC had just finished its review of the matter after about six months of consideration. ``Politics simply are not involved,'' said Alan Whitney, an FDIC spokesman in Washington. Politics or no, the civil lawsuit brings a new dimension to the Bush case by threatening him with financial liability, not just banishment from the banking and savings industry. The liability insurance for Silverado officers and directors lapsed in 1986, and it is unclear whether the defendants would be able to tap a special fund which the thrift had set aside for legal fees. Bush's financial situation also is uncertain. He borrowed $125,000 for his new oil exploration venture, Bush Energy Co., over the past 16 months from a Denver cable television executive, Fred Vierra, according to public records. ``As far as Fred was concerned, the loan was personal,'' John Neal, a spokesman for Vierra, said Friday. ``Fred didn't ask them what they were going to do with the money,'' Neal added, referring to Bush and his wife, Sharon. He said the loans, with an interest rate of around 10 percent, were secured by a second lien on the Bush's $550,000 house in an upscale area of Denver. The first lien, for $440,000, is held by Bank Western. Bush has declined comment on the matter. Neal said Vierra, the president of United Artists Entertainment Co. of Denver, has known Neil and Sharon Bush for about seven years.

DOC.HEAD: One of World's Last Great Gothic Churches Completed After 83 Years
DOC.TEXT: One of the world's last great Gothic churches was formally completed today, with President Bush and thousands of others gathering to see the final stone laid for what Bush called the ``symbol of our Nation's spiritual life.'' Bush said the completion of the Washington National Cathedral recalled to him the words spoken by the late Rev. Martin Luther Kig from its pulpit just days before the civil rights leader was assassinated. ``He said `We will bring about a new day of justice and brotherhood and peace. And on that day, morning stars will sing together, and the sons of God will shout for joy,''' Bush said. He said the cathedral, in use during most of its construction years, has been a place where the nation has come to understand, to grieve, to celebrate and to express concern. ``And so we have constructed here this symbol of our nation's spiritual life, overlooking the center of our nation's secular life,'' the presdient said at the stone-laying ceremony. He said the cathedral ``carries with it a constant reminder of our moral obligations.'' It was a long time coming. It was just 83 years ago to the day that President Theodore Roosevelt rode to Mount St. Albans, the highest point in the capital, to see the foundation stone laid. A crowd of 10,000 braved threatening weather to join him. Cathedral spokeswoman Jean Grigsby said at least that many were expected today. Sunny and warm weather was forecast. On Sept. 29, 1907, it had been raining and the sun burst through the clouds just moments before the ceremony began. The stone reserved to the last is a 1,000-pound piece of Indiana limestone carved in the shape of a folded leaf or flower. It has been on display inside, but was moved onto the grounds of the cathedral and lifted into place by a crane. The stone rests on the southwest pinnacle of the cathedral's St. Paul Tower. The 873,021-square foot building, roughly 14th century English Gothic in style, is the sixth largest cathedral in the world. St. Peter's in Rome is the largest, followed by one in Seville, Spain; the unfinished St. John the Divine in New York and cathedrals in Liverpool, England, and Milan, Italy. Richard T. Feller, the canon clerk of the works at the cathedral, said in a recent interview that he believes it will be the last built in the Gothic style. ``There isn't the craftsmanship available,'' he said. ``There isn't the design ability.'' The 150,000-ton church was built in the traditional stone-on-stone method of the medieval cathedral builders, although with modern equipment. The bearing walls have no steel reinforcement, but are supported by stone buttresses. Construction began at the east end with the laying of the foundation stone beneath what is now the Bethlehem Chapel. The twin towers at the west end, a tenth of a mile away, are named for St. Peter and St. Paul. The cathedral is the headquarters of the Episcopal Diocese of Washington but calls itself a ``house of prayer for all people.'' Funeral services for President Eisenhower were held in the cathedral. President Woodrow Wilson is buried there. As Bush recalled, the Rev. Martin Luther King Jr. preached from its pulpit. So has the Rev. Desmond Tutu. Work on the cathedral was halted during World War I and World War II and stopped again in 1977 because of a shortage of funds. It was resumed in 1980. Today's ceremony will be followed by a service of consecration Sunday.

DOC.HEAD: Student Leader Says D.C. University Protest Likely to Continue Into Monday
DOC.TEXT: Negotiations between students and members of the board of trustees of the University of the District of Columbia began again today but student leaders say the impasse over student protests won't end in time for classes to resume on Monday. ``Honestly, right now we don't anticipate an end by Monday,'' said student spokesman Mark Thomspson. Thompson said the board was undermining the talks through actions taken against the students. ``While negotiations are contiuning, all students here are in imminent danger,'' he said. ``We have been threatened by the board of trustees and by the mayor that police could move in at any given moment.'' University spokesman John Britton denied the allegations, calling them ``hogwash.'' He said the trustees have issued no threats. Thompson also said that the heat had been turned on the buildings they occupy during the day when temperatures are warm. Conversely, Thompson said, the air conditioning was activated in the late night and early morning hours as it became cooler. The cars of students participating in the protest also were being impounded, Thompson said. UDC officials said Friday they would resume classes next week despite a student protest that has kept the school closed since Wednesday. ``We are prepared to move this institution forward,'' the Rev. A. Knighton Stanley, a member of the school's board of trustees, said Friday night. ``This board of trustees is prepared to open this institution on Monday morning.'' Stanley declined to say how the 12,000-student public institution will be reopened if the dozens of students occupying university offices refuse to leave, but he said negotiations would go on over the weekend. Former presidential candidate Jesse Jackson showed up on the campus Friday night and said he was prepared to place himself between the students and police if a confrontation developed. But he said, ``I am convinced that rational and caring minds can arrive at a just and non-violent conclusion.'' The protesters seized control of two university buildings Wednesday and asked fellow students to boycott classes, accusing the board of taking actions that threatened the school's quality of education. They asked for the resignation of the 11 mayoral appointees to the 15-member board of trustees. The students had cut off negotiations Friday after board members refused to quit immediately, Stanley said. ``The only thing they were willing to hear was the resignation of this board,'' he said. ``When I indicated to them that it would put them in a position of negotiating with nobody or with lame ducks or with non-entities, they would not move in that regard and legal counsel did not move them to move beyond (that).'' The UDC Faculty Senate has backed the students, who also want improved academic and athletic programs, compliance with education standards set by a regional accreditation board and an increased emphasis on African-American studies. Sam Carcione, president of the faculty union, said he also wanted trustees to resign. ``The board has been our enemy for a long time,'' he said. Three City Council members also called for the trustees to quit eventually. Trustee Nira H. Long agreed to resign as the board's chairwoman on Friday but said she would remain as a member. The students had Mayor Marion Barry's help and support until Wednesday afternoon, when he bowed out, saying two attorneys advising the students had talked them into refusing to compromise. But Thompson, said the students are in charge of the protest, not the lawyers. Stanley said he and other school officials were willing to make changes. ``We are prepared to admit that perhaps we and our predecessors have been somewhat remiss in governance of this institution,'' he said. ``We are more than willing to review the issues of governance of the University of the District of Columbia with all aspects of the university community.''

DOC.HEAD: French Reactor Flaws Revealed as Pro-Nuclear Forum Ends
DOC.TEXT: Environmentalists challenged the safety of France's big nuclear power network Saturday, a day after the end of an international conference touting nuclear energy as crucial to global development. France has 50 nuclear power plants and obtains a higher portion of its electricity from nuclear power - more than 70 percent - than any country in the world. Leaders of the ecology-oriented Green Party accused energy authorities of lax response to investigations by safety experts, who this week reported finding flaws in the water filtration systems at 17 French reactors. Officials said the flaws posed no immediate danger, and would be fixed during a series of shutdowns at the affected plants. On Friday, as the extent of the defects became known, more than 2,000 scientists, engineers and energy experts from 30 countries ended the week-long European Nuclear Conference in Lyon. Several speakers, asserting the importance of nuclear power, invoked the impact of the Persian Gulf crisis on the world oil market. ``The only existing possibility is nuclear energy, if we don't want to go toward major energy crises,'' said Remy Carle, a deputy director of state-run Electricite de France, which operates the nuclear power system. He said standardized global safety regulations and better technical cooperation would help alleviate worries about nuclear safety. Defects in water filtration circuits were first detected at the Golfech plant near Toulouse in January. Authorities have been criticized for not determining until this month that the same flaws existed at 16 other 1,300-megawatt reactors. Said Michel Laveyrie, head of the safety service that pursued the investigation: ``I'm not shocked that there were anomalies in the system - nothing can be 100 percent perfect. But when you find one, you must treat it rigorously. This wasn't the case.'' Greens leader Antoine Waechter, at a news conference, denounced France's ``nuclear dictatorship'' and said officials ``lied by omission'' by failing to reveal the extent of the problems. Robert Malgras, a regional councilor in Lorraine in eastern France, called Saturday for a meeting between the area's mayors and nuclear safety officials to discuss the flaws found at the area's Cattenom plant. ``We can't be content with an annual report,'' he said. ``We want to know what's going on.''

DOC.HEAD: Californians Face Vote on Curbing, Extending Tax Revolt
DOC.TEXT: California voters will decide Nov. 6 whether the tax revolt they started a dozen years ago with Proposition 13 is dead. The 28 propositions on the statewide ballot include three proposed tax increases and 14 bond issues that would increase state debt by $5.8 billion. But another measure would disallow any tax increase approved by less than a two-thirds majority of voters, substantially strengthening the anti-tax movement. The voters also will decide whether to ban cancer-causing pesticides, take new steps aimed at saving ancient redwoods, throw out veteran lawmakers and put prisoners to work. The $5.8 billion in bond proposals come just five months after voters approved $5.1 billion in state bonds on the June primary ballot. The November bond measures would go for forest preservation, housing loans, universities, schools, prisons, jails, juvenile halls, county courthouses, water and sewer projects, parks and child care centers. Tax measures include proposals to increase the state sales tax by a half-cent and to raise the state tax on alcoholic beverages. But a rival initiative, backed by the alcohol industry, could wipe out those tax increases. Reflecting a growing public disdain for politicians as shown by the recent vote in Oklahoma to limit politicians' time in office, two initiatives would turn out state elected officials after two to six terms, depending on the measure and office. Local ballot propositions range from a measure to roll back rent controls in Berkeley to a $1.2 million bond issue to purchase land for a butterfly habitat in affluent Pacific Grove. A plan to move the San Francisco Giants 40 miles south to suburban Santa Clara depends on a Santa Clara County vote on a utility users tax to finance a proposed stadium for the National League baseball team. Four environmental measures on the statewide ballot pit conservationists and Hollywood celebrities against farmers, chemical manufacturers, loggers and timber companies. One sweeping initiative could affect how much Californians pay for food and energy, how many trees are planted in their neighborhoods and whether their take-out hamburgers keep warm in a foam box. It also could regulate their air conditioning and require cars to average 50 miles per gallon of fuel by 2010. Dubbed ``Big Green'' by its backers, Proposition 128 would phase out pesticides known to cause cancer, ban chemicals that harm the ozone and require a dramatic reduction in emissions of gases that contribute to global warming. It also would authorize $300 million in bonds to preserve old-growth redwood trees, restrict offshore oil drilling and create a new elective office of environmental czar. Opponents call Proposition 128 ``The Hayden Initiative,'' after one of its chief sponsors, Tom Hayden, the student anti-war leader of the 1960s who as a 50-year-old state assemblyman has refocused his activism on environmental issues. Another measure sponsored by environmentalists seeks to save old-growth forests. It would restrict clear-cutting of timber, impose new restrictions on logging and prohibit exports of logs harvested from state forests. It also would provide $742 million in bond financing to preserve old-growth forests and retrain timber workers who might be forced out of work by its harvesting restrictions. Two rival measures backed by industry offer less restrictive regulation of pesticides and logging. If two questions on the same subject pass, they both take effect, except for provisions that conflict. In that case, the courts have ruled, the measure with the highest vote total prevails. Proposition 134, a ``nickel-a-drink'' surtax on wine, beer and liquor, would earmark the extra $760 million a year for drug and alcohol programs, health care and law enforcement. An industry-backed rival, Proposition 126, would raise the tax by a smaller amount, roughly a penny a drink. Proposition 133 would raise the state sales tax by one-half cent per dollar for four years. The $1.5 billion to $2.1 billion in annual revenues would go for anti-drug education, drug treatment, prisons and jails. But Proposition 136, which would take effect election day, could nullify the alcohol and sales tax measures by amending the state constitution to require a two-thirds vote for ballot measures that raise special taxes. The question of whether such a proposition could actually nullify another vote taken the same day, or could be applied only to future propositions, would probably be decided in the courts. Proposition 136 is supported by followers of the late anti-tax crusaders Howard Jarvis and Paul Gann. Opponents say the real backers are alcohol interests who want to defeat the liquor tax. Proposition 131 would limit the governor and other statewide elected officials to two consecutive four-year terms. Legislators would be limited to 12 years in office. It also would set new limits on campaign contributions, establish partial public financing for state campaigns, restrict closed meetings of the Legislature and create a new political corruption prosecutor. Under Proposition 140, the governor and most other state officials down to senator could each serve up to eight years. Assembly members would be limited to six years. It also would eliminate legislative pensions and cut the Legislature's budget by about 40 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Polish Senate Approves Laws on Presidential Election, Amendment
DOC.TEXT: The Senate on Saturday unanimously approved legislation to hold a popular presidential election as early as Nov. 25. The legislation, already passed Thursday by the lower chamber of Parliament - the Sejm - includes a constitutional amendment in which the president is elected in a general vote to a five-year term. It also includes an election law authorizing the Parliament speaker to set a date for the elections. Solidarity leader Lech Walesa has already declared his candidacy in the first popular presidential balloting here in more than 50 years to succeed Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski, who is stepping down early as head of state. Walesa is likely to face Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki, his former adviser, in the presidential race. Mazowiecki is expected to announce his candidacy within days. According to Piotr Nowina-Konopka, a minister of state in the office of the president, Jaruzelski planned to sign the legislation immediately and the Sejm speaker is expected to announce the election date as early as this weekend. ``The first round of presidential elections can be held Nov. 25,'' Konopka told the official PAP news agency, stressing the law requires election dates to be announced 45 days in advance. Jaruzelski asked the parliament Sept. 19 to shorten his six-year term in order to allow a free presidential election following calls for the former Communist Party head to step down. He had been elected president by the two-chamber National Assembly in July 1989. Under this timetable, the new president would be sworn in before Dec. 25.

DOC.HEAD: Hungarian Police Ban Demonstration by the Homeless
DOC.TEXT: Police on Saturday banned a demonstration at Southern Railway Station by Budapest's homeless people. No disturbances were reported following the ban, issued after a meeting Friday of the state railway authority, which says Budapest railway stations have now become overnight havens for the homeless. The number of homeless is increasing rapidly here as an annual inflation rate of 30 percent starts to hurt those living on fixed incomes, such as pensioners, and with the emptying of prisons through government amnesties. Peter Gyeori, a sociologist, told Hungarian radio Saturday the problem is also increasingly a refugee issue. ``Refugees from all over Eastern Europe, many of them with children, sleep in railway stations in Budapest,'' he said. Last winter, several homeless people were found frozen to death. The magnitude of the problem is expected to worsen this winter. The Welfare Ministry this week set up a special office to manage the ``social crisis'' in Hungary. Its head, Zoltan Lackner, told reporters the problem of the homeless will be up to the new local governments to be elected in nationwide balloting Sunday. Lackner told radio Saturday the government has allocated the equivalent of an extra $500,000 to finance soup kitchens and hostels for the growing number of poor until January. Maria Komar, a Budapest City Hall official, earlier told the daily Nepszabadsag that $500,000 already allocated for the poor this year has been used up.

DOC.HEAD: Congressman's Daughter Pleads Guilty to Cocaine Possession
DOC.TEXT: Gayle Rosten, daughter of U.S. Rep. Daniel Rostenkowski, has pleaded guilty to a cocaine possession charge in Lake County. Rosten, 37, pleaded guilty Thursday before Judge Harry Hartel, who delayed sentencing for Oct. 25, said Assistant State's Attorney Dan Kleinhubert. ``Her sentence is to include a period of imprisonment,'' Kleinhubert said. ``She's now being treated at Gateway, an inpatient rehab center in Lake Villa.'' In May, Illinois State Police said troopers found a plastic bag containing cocaine in her car after it was stopped for a traffic violation on the Tri-State Tollway near Gurnee, about 35 miles north of Chicago.

DOC.HEAD: Police in Yugoslavia Clash With Ethnic Protesters; 27 Detained
DOC.TEXT: Ethnic protesters clashed with police reinforcements Saturday after seizing police weapons in two Croatian towns, and at least 27 people were detained, authorities said. One policeman was injured. Croatia's Interior Ministry dispatched special police units to the trouble spots south of the Croatian capital of Zagreb and accused unnamed Serb politicians of encouraging what it called ``terrorist acts.'' Serbs and Croats, Yugoslavia's two largest ethnic groups, have been fierce rivals since the country was formed in 1918. With increasing ethnic, economic and political differences tugging at Yugoslavia's fragile, six-republic federation, the Serb-Croat rivalry is becoming more intense and violent. The center-right coalition that ousted the Communists in free elections in Croatia last spring is pushing for a much looser confederation of sovereign states in Yugoslavia. Serbia wants to maintain a more centralized system and vows to protect the Serbs living in Croatia, if necessary by changing the borders between the two republics. The Croatian Interior Ministry said shots were fired on police Friday in Petrinja, about 25 miles south of Zagreb, when they used tear gas and clubs against about 2,000 minority Serbs protesting seizures of weapons issued to them as police reservists. One policeman was seriously injured and at least 27 of the 90 people identified as responsible for the unrest were detained, the ministry said, according to the state news agency Tanjug. The local police chief was among those detained on suspicion of ``irresponsible work,'' Tanjug said. Tanjug also said about 1,000 angry Serbs from Dvor, 25 miles south of Petrinja, and from nearby Bosanski Novi, in the republic of Bosnia-Hercegovina, attacked Dvor's police station Friday night. The crowd overpowered police, who did not use their firearms. They occupied the building and seized unspecified weapons and ammunition, Tanjug said. The Serbs then barricaded roads leading into the town, Tanjug said. Special police units eventually arrived after midnight, retook the police station and began recovering the confiscated weapons, Tanjug said. It did not say whether force was used, but it said all approaches to the police station and town hall were blocked. Police checked vehicles and passengers on access roads. In addition to the seizure of weapons at the police station, Tanjug said the crowd stole hunting ammunition overnight from a weapons shop in Dvor. ``The developments point to recklessness of gangs of bandits'' trying ``to start an armed uprising in the republic of Croatia,'' the Interior Ministry statement said. Tension is rising throughout Yugoslavia as the quarreling republics and their leaders move toward a showdown over the country's future. November's free elections in Bosnia-Hercegovina, which has strong Serb, Croat and Moslem groups, and elections scheduled Dec. 9 in Serbia, the largest Yugoslav republic, are expected to decide whether the federation stays together or falls apart. Slovenia, which like Croatia elected a center-right government in free elections in spring, also advocates a confederation. Slovenia has threatened full independence if a new arrangement is not found, and its parliament on Friday adopted measures bringing the republic closer to rupture with the others.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Helps Dedicate Final Stone in 83-Year Cathedral Construction
DOC.TEXT: The Washington National Cathedral, begun at the dawn of the century, was formally completed Saturday with President Bush overseeing the laying of the final stone atop what he called ``this symbol of our nation's spiritual life.'' ``The fabric of this Cathedral Church of St. Peter and St. Paul is completed,'' Richard T. Feller, canon of the clerk of the works, announced to Bush and the thousands who gathered at the cathedral. Bush told the crowd, ``We have constructed here this symbol of our nation's spiritual life, overlooking the center of our nation's secular life. A symbol which combines the permanence of stone and of God, both of which will outlast men, and memories.'' The visitors crowded the grounds atop Mount St. Alban - the capital city's highest point - to witness the end of a project begun in 1907. Theodore Roosevelt was president when construction began on what is now the world's sixth largest cathedral. Roosevelt watched the laying of the foundation stone, along with 10,000 people who braved chilly damp weather to join him. Saturday's celebrants gathered under sunny, warm skies on a day that highlighted the grandeur of the Gothic-style cathedral's newly visible facade. For years, the front, flanked by twin towers was obscured from passers by on Wisconsin Avenue by massive construction equipment and scaffolding. Today, the massive limestone church is set back impressively from the broad avenue on 57 acres of landscaped grounds that also house three schools, a college, the offices of the Episcopal Diocese of Washington and St. Alban's Parish Church. Bush told the gathering the nation has come to the cathedral to grieve, to understand, to celebrate and to express concern. He noted the funerals of presidents Harry S. Truman and Dwight Eisenhower and Vice President Hubert H. Humphrey were held there. ``Over a three-day period at the dedication of the Vietnam Veterans' Memorial, the names of 57,939 lost Americans were read in chapels. Other times we listened to Bishop Tutu, Billy Graham and Martin Luther King.'' He also recalled ``when the hostages were freed from our embassy in Iran, there was a service of thanksgiving.'' ``We went to express our concern, to hold a memorial for victims of the American embassy bombing in Beirut, a service of reflection on the 40th anniversary of Hiroshima, and even now prayers for our brave young servicemen and women in the harsh, distant deserts,'' he said, referring to troops in the Persian Gulf region. The final ceremonial stone was a 1,000-pound chunk of Indiana limestone carved in the shape of a folded leaf or flower. It was lifted into place atop the southwest pinnacle of the cathedral's St. Paul Tower. Feller directed the delicate crane operation in a voice broadcast over loudspeaker. The crowd below erupted in cheers when one of the two workmen exclaimed ``bull's eye!'' as the stone was positioned over a mortar bed. Bush said the words spoken from the pulpit by the late Rev. Martin Luther King Jr. in his last Sunday sermon ``should become our new vision.'' ``He said, `We will bring about a new day of justice and brotherhood and peace. And on that day, morning stars will sing together and sons of God will shout for joy.'' The 873,021-square foot cathedral, in 14th century Gothic style, is bested in size only by: St. Peter's in Rome, the world's largest, followed by one in Seville, Spain, the unfinished St. John the Divine in New York and cathedrals in Liverpool, England, and Milan, Italy. It is officially named the Cathedral Church of St. Peter and St. Paul. Feller said in a recent interview that he believes it will be the last built in the Gothic style because that type of craftsmanship is no longer available. He had said ``only the most optimistic person would have bet on the Washington cathedral ever being finished.'' In 1981 the Protestant-Episcopal Foundation had fallen $10.7 million in debt and work on the church stopped. But a fundraising drive revived the project and the final phase of the nearly century-long project began in 1983. The 150,000-ton church was built in the traditional stone-on-stone method of the medieval cathedral builders, although with modern equipment. The bearing walls are supported by stone buttresses. President Woodrow Wilson is buried there. So is Helen Keller, whose memorial is in braille. Work on the cathedral was halted during World War I and World War II and stopped again in 1977 because of a shortage of funds. It was resumed in 1980.

DOC.HEAD: Kuwaiti Businessman: Iraqi Soldiers Executed Eight Men
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A Kuwaiti businessman said Saturday that he saw Iraqi soldiers summarily execute eight men accused of resistance activities in occupied Kuwait. The eight were ``murdered by Iraqi soldiers who shot them with pistols,'' said the businessman, who spoke through a satellite telephone conversation - a rarity in this region since the Aug. 2 takeover of Kuwait by Iraq's forces. ``Each victim was killed with one bullet in the head and another in the heart,'' he said, adding that the killings occurred Sept. 21. The same day, the Iraqis rounded up 17 businessmen and former parliamentarians on charges of refusing to cooperate with the occupation authorities, said the businessman, who spoke on condition his name was not used. The 17 included Faisal al-Sanie, former parliamentarian and member of the opposition group that had been demanding more democracy in Kuwait, along with businessmen brothers Khaled, Adnan and Salah al-Wasmi, he said. ``They were arrested and moved along with their families to unknown places, possibly to Iraq,'' he said. ``Also last week, the Kuwaiti Red Crescent Society was closed and the six members of its board board were seized and taken away.'' The Red Crescent officers were taken to the southern Iraqi Basra region, he said. The report was the latest reaching Bahrain from the estimated 300,000 Kuwaitis living under Iraqi occupation. ``Things are getting real bad here,'' said the businessman. ``Food is scarce and the Iraqis are becoming extremely ferocious. '' He said the Kuwaiti resistance ``is doing a good job, but not good enough.'' ``Our beloved and beautiful Kuwait has been reduced to a shambles. In daytime the city is like a cemetry, oppressive and silent,'' he said. ``After sunset, we hear only the sound of death - the rattle of machine-gun fire, the thud of cannons and blasts of bombs.'' The telephone connection was clear. The businessman sounded tired and shaken, saying, ``It's a big risk making this call. They (Iraqis) kill Kuwaitis in cold blood.'' Regular telephone and Telex links between Kuwait and the rest of the world were cut off in the first days of the invasion. The exiled ruler of the invaded country, Sheik Jaber al-Ahmed al-Sabah, gave President Bush a graphic account of the situation in the country under the Iraqi occupation. As a result of these reports and other accounts of violence and pillaging, Bush is reviewing the possibility of seeking additional United Nations action beyond the existing trade blockade, according to Bush's national security adviser, Brent Scowcroft. Scowcroft said Friday that military action was one possibility. Kuwaitis fleeing since the invasion have been providing frequent accounts of oppression, rape and plunder by the Iraqi occupation forces. The London-based human rights group, Amnesty International, recently sent a team to the gulf to try to investigate the reports. The businessman's report was the first about an Iraqi crackdown on members of the opposition ranks in Kuwait who had been on a collision course with the Emir over the months seeking the return of a Western-style parliament. But they had always affirmed loyalty to the Emir. At the start of the Iraqi invasion there were claims that Kuwait opposition leaders would be asked to form a government to run their country when the Iraqis withdrew. Instead, Baghdad announced the formation of a 9-member ``Provisional Kuwait Free Government'' led by an obscure Col. Alaa Hussein Ali. Other Kuwaiti refugees reaching Bahrain said that they saw Alaa on television with Iraqi President Saddam Hussein, requesting unity between their two countries. The same day, Kuwait was annexed by Iraq and Alaa was never seen again, and was presumed executed, they said.

DOC.HEAD: Vet's Mistake: Boy Watches as Dog in for Rabies Vaccination is Put to Sleep
DOC.TEXT: A teen-age boy who brought his beloved dog in for a rabies vaccination watched as his pet was mistakenly put to sleep. ``It was a real tragedy, very serious,'' said Dr. Keith Sultemeier, the veterinarian who operates the clinic in Azle, northwest of Fort Worth. Fifteen-year-old Tony McCarty and his mother brought the dog, a 2{-year-old pit bull-chow mixbreed named Runt, into the clinic Thursday, about the same time a female pit bull-chow mix was brought in for euthanasia, Sultemeier said. ``The lady and her son came in with a dog for a fairly straightforward vaccination and walked out without the dog. ... We are at fault,'' the veterinarian said. The boy was with Runt when the dog got the lethal injection instead of the rabies shot. To make up for the error, Sultemeier bought McCarty a full-blooded chow puppy. McCarty's mother, Pam Peyton, said she won't sue Sultemeier. ``I don't see any reason to ruin his practice over this,'' she said. ``He's gotten us a new dog and said he will take steps - whatever that means - to make sure it doesn't happen again and I believe he will.''

DOC.HEAD: Musawi: U.S. Should Improve Its Conduct to Win Hostage Releases
DOC.TEXT: A pro-Iranian Shiite Moslem leader on Saturday pointed to renewed ties between Tehran and London and said Washington should ``improve its conduct'' to help win the freedom of six American captives. Te leader, Hussein Musawi, said he does not expect the ``early release'' of any of the U.S. hostages - ``not before Americans improve their conduct like the British started doing.'' Britain and Iran restored diplomatic ties Thursday, 18 months after severing relations following Iran's death decree against author Salman Rushdie, a British citizen. Iran's late Ayatollah Khomeini said Rushdie should be killed because his novel ``The Satanic Verses'' defamed Islam. If any American were freed, Musawi said, it ought to be Terry Anderson, the longest-held foreign captive.
