Maintenance of health care provisions negotiated in 1987 and improvements in the pension plan were two of the big sellers of the 1990 contract, Hasenjager said. Other selling points included a GM promise to pay up to $4 billion to guarantee wages for workers laid off mre than 36 weeks during the next three years. In addition, the contract provides for a 3 percent raise in the first year and lump sum payments in the second and third years of 3 percent. Cost of living adjustments were retained.

DOC.HEAD: Thunderstorms Drench Central U.S.
DOC.TEXT: Thunderstorms rumbled over the nation's midsection Saturday, while much of the West enjoyed sunny skies. Showers and thunderstorms continued over eastern New Mexico and northwest Texas Saturday afternoon. Nearly 3 inches had fallen at Panhandle, Texas, by Saturday morning. A few thunderstorms and showers also dampened parts of western Oklahoma, eastern Colorado, Kansas, eastern Nebraska, southern Iowa and southeastern South Dakota. Scattered showers and thunderstorms developing along a stationary front extended from Ohio to northern Maine. Other showers and thunderstorms were scattered across Florida, southern Georgia and southern Alabama. Dry weather prevailed across the rest of the nation, with sunny skies over much of the West. Heavier rainfall totals for the six hour period ending at 2 p.m. EDT included 1} inches at Apalachicola, Fla., and 1\ inches at Clovis, N.M. Temperatures warmed into the 70s and 80s Saturday afternoon from the southern Plains region to the southern and middle Atlantic Coast and in the desert Southwest and California valleys. Readings were only in the 40s and 50s from the northern and central high Plains to Michigan. Saturday's low for the Lower 48 states was 31 degrees in Montana at Butte and Glendive.

DOC.HEAD: Palestinians Battle Police near Jerusalem; School Principal Killed
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with new violence. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: About 100 Palestinians spilled gasoline onto roads near Jerusalem's Old City on Saturday and battled riot police, who wounded three youths by firing rubber bullets, according to police and Arab witnesses. The clashes broke out just before sundown, which marked the end of Yom Kippur, the Jewish Day of Atonement and holiest day on the Jewish calendar. Earlier Saturday, high school principal Mohammed Mustafa Abu Hassanein, 50, was killed by masked Palestinian gunmen in his office in Gaza City. He reportedly had been accused him of collaborating with Israel. The reports said the attackers entered Saladin Preparatory School and shot Abu Hassanein in the head at close range. Palestinian youths blocked roads in the Arab Silwan neighborhood just south of the walled Old City and then marched toward the Old City's Dung Gate, police spokesman Uzi Sandori said. Near the gate, they spilled gasoline on the road and built roadblocks with stones, Arab witnesses said. They gasoline apparently was aimed at blocking the access of police. Sandori said riot police fired rubber bullets, wounding three youths. Four others were arrested. Clashes were also reported inside the Old City, and police said three Palestinians were arrested. Abu Hassanein was the 269th Palestinian killed by fellow Arabs in the 34-month-old Palestinian uprising against Israeli occupation of the West Bank and Gaza Strip. Most were accused of collaboration or of dealing in drugs or prostitution. At least 730 other Palestinians have been killed by Israeli soldiers or civilians, and 48 Israelis have died in the violence. The army blocked Palestinians from entering Israel from the West Bank and Gaza Strip on the holy day. Bureij refugee camp, where a soldier was killed Sept. 20, remained under curfew, Arab reports said. Curfews also were in force in a half-dozen other Gaza camps and towns.

DOC.HEAD: Barge Spills 30,000 Gallons of Solvent After Collision
DOC.TEXT: A barge spilled nearly 30,000 gallons of a partly refined crude oil solvent after colliding with another ship. Officials said the spill was evaporating quickly Saturday. ``There's very little to clean up,'' U.S. Coast Guard Capt. Thomas Greene said. ``We're letting nature and the effects of the sun and temperature take its course.'' The Norwegian tanker Bow Panther, lost power Friday night and collided with the barges being pulled by a tugboat toward the Port of Houston, he said. There were no reported injuries. A cargo tank on the 297-foot barge cracked, spilling the solvent reformate, a partly refined crude oil that resembles gasoline. Texas Department of Health officials were investigating the effects of the spill on shellfish, but since the solvent will not dissolve in water or sink it was deemed too early to issue warnings. In July, about 700,000 gallons of oil spilled into the environmentally sensitive Galveston Bay when the Greek tanker Shinoussa collided with two barges in the ship channel.

DOC.HEAD: First R & R Center Opening for Troops in Saudi Arabia
DOC.TEXT: U.S. forces are about to open the first ``in-country rest and relaxation center'' for American troops in Saudi Arabia, a U.S. officer said Saturday. Maj. Gen. William G. Pagonis, chief of logistics for the U.S. military command, said the center should open next week with 24-hour movies, swimming, sports, and a medical clinic. The center will serve up to 600 troops a day. Pagonis said the site had been provided by the Saudis, but he refused to reveal the location. U.S. officials had earlier said they were planning a number of centers for troops in the field along with R & facilities outside the country, similar to the system used during the Vietnam war.

DOC.HEAD: Rocket Launch Delayed Again By Bad Weather
DOC.TEXT: Bad weather on Saturday forced a second delay in the Air Force's planned launch of an unmanned Delta rocket with a navigation satellite. Thunderstorms postponed Friday's launch attempt. Air Force officials rescheduled the launch for late Monday afternoon. The $65 million Navstar satellite aboard the Delta 2 rocket will be the ninth advanced Global Positioning System spacecraft to be placed in a 12,532-mile-high orbit. The first in the series was launched in February 1989. The satellites are capable of pinpointing the location of American military units to within 50 feet.

DOC.HEAD: Polish Senate Endorses Law Outlawing Abortion
DOC.TEXT: The Senate on Saturday approved a proposal that would outlaw most abortions in Poland for the first time in 34 years, while setting jail terms for doctors who perform them. The bill passed 50-17 with five abstentions. It must next be considered by the Sejm, Parliament's lower chamber. The bill would allow abortions only when a woman's life is in danger or when pregnancy is a result of a crime. The senators rejected a provision to establish jail terms for woman who have abortions. Feminist groups from around the country protested vociferously during the two-day Senate debate. Abortion has been legal since 1956, when Communist authorities made the decision without public debate. Poland is about 90 percent Roman Catholic but it has one of the world's highest abortion rates. More than 500 people, mostly young women, marched outside the Parliament building Saturday carrying banners and throwing leaflets criticizing the legislation. ``Don't let a small group of men decide about the life of women,'' one female demonstrator called over a loudspeaker. The 100-member Senate has seven women. Sen. Edward Wende, who spoke with a five-member delegation of protesters, said the proposal was still far from becoming law. ``This is only the beginning of the legislative process. We all agree in principle that the mother should not be punished,'' said Wende. ``This is Parliament and further discussion will be held here about the final shape of this law.'' In May 1989, the Sejm proposed a more punitive bill that would have penalized both doctors and the women who undergo abortions. Action on the bill was delayed, but the Senate decision throws the matter back into the Sejm. As Poland and other East Bloc nations move toward democracy, issues such as abortion and religious education in schools have emerged. In some areas of Czechoslovakia, groups have pushed to restrict relatively easy access to abortion. Roman Catholic church leaders in Hungary also are campaigning to restrict abortions. In Romania, on the other hand, nearly 500,000 women have had abortions since a ban by the late President Nicolae Ceausescu was lifted when he was deposed in December. Although the vast majority of Poles consider themselves Roman Catholic, many young couples turn to abortion when they are unable to find larger apartments in the housing-starved nation. Reliable contraceptives are infrequently available in Poland.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. General Says Supplies Enough in Event of War
With AM-Gulf Rdp
DOC.TEXT: The chief of U.S. military logistics in Saudi Arabia said Saturday the supply flow was on schedule and could sustain American forces for more than a month of all-out war with Iraq. Maj. Gen. William G. Pagonis said present American resources could last up to two to three months. He called his supply problems ``peanuts'' compared to those facing President Saddam Hussein of Iraq. ``My goals and objectives are to be able to sustain ourselves for as long as necessary in a defensive posture, or to do anything else that . . . (President Bush) and the king of Saudi Arabia decide for us to do,'' Pagonis said in an interview. He said this meant building up reserve stocks for 30 days. Delivery of ammunition and other fresh supplies would be a top priority even in a brief conflict between Iraq and the United States and its allies. Pagonis, the commander of the U.S. Army Support Command, arrived here Aug. 3, a day after Iraq seized Kuwait. He said he had to use a rented Chevrolet as his office at first and slept one night in the back seat. U.S. forces have the supply edge over Baghdad despite having to import huge amounts of material from the United States, Pagonis said. Iraq would have ``an enormous problem'' in maintaining its supply lines over ``limited road access with a limited number of trucks, that can only carry so much cargo. ``My line of communication is from the port to the soldiers . . . That's peanuts compared to his.'' Iraq's supply problems are sure to grow worse as a result of U.N. economic sanctions, he said. Pagonis said the first sea delivery of supplies was completed within 30 days and that eight fast sealift ships that brought the first loads of armor and other major equipment now are on the way with more. ``We've delivered more soldiers and discharged more ships in a short period of time than any armed forces in the world,'' the general said. Pagonis said logistical troops now arriving would be able to take up the slack should an outbreak of hostilities send the thousands of drivers and other civilian contract workers now employed by the Americans fleeing for safety. Many of the workers are third country foreigners who have no families in Saudi Arabia and would probably remain with the U.S. troops in the event of war, he said. The general estimated overall costs of U.S.-contracted services at $380 million a month. The Saudis are providing free water, fuel and most of the food for U.S. troops other than field rations, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Lebanese President in Syrian
DOC.TEXT: Lebanese President Elias Hrawi held five hours of talks Saturday with President Hafez Assad and received Syria's support for the measures he is taking against a rebel Christian leader, officials said. Hrawi's army closed all crossing points into east Beirut enclave of Gen. Michel Aoun on Friday in a bid to starve him into submission. It was not clear whether Hrawi had asked for military support, although it is generally understood that Syria is willing to provide military assistance if Hrawi asked. ``President Assad expressed Syria's full support to the moves taken by the Lebanese legitimacy to extend its authority, and expressed Syria's readiness to provide every assistance to achieve this purpose,'' presidential spokesman Jibrane Kourieh said. Hrawi's move Friday tightened an economic blockade that his government imposed July 30 against Aoun and his 15,000 soldiers, who control an area of 80 square miles in east Beirut and the neighboring Metn Mountains. Troops stopped all supplies of flour, food and vegetables from entering the zone Friday. Fuel supplies and money transfers had been banned for two months. Hrawi and Aoun are both Maronite Catholics, the sect that has dominated government structures in Lebanon since independence from France in 1943. Hrawi was elected last fall within the framework of a peace plan brokered by the Arab League to resolve Lebanon's 15-year-old civil war between Moslems and Christians. Aoun rejected the plan because it did not include a timetable for the withdrawal of Syrian troops, in Lebanon since 1976.

DOC.HEAD: Second Competitor for Advanced Tactical Fighter Contract Gets Airborne
LaserPhoto LA2
DOC.TEXT: Lockheed Corp.'s prototype of a 21st century fighter jet made its first flight Saturday in a winner-take-all competition for the multibillion-dollar Advanced Tactical Fighter contract. The YF-22 was airborne just 18 minutes, taking off from Air Force Plant 42 in Palmdale and ending 25 mile away at this desert flight test center. The flight was a milestone in a high-stakes contest between an aerospace team headed by Lockheed and a team led by Northrop Corp. for 1,250 ATF jets, to be built at a projected cost of $51 million per plane. The winner must produce a jet that is highly maneuverable, uses radar-evading stealth technology and can fly twice the speed of sound for long periods of time. The Air Force wants 750 of the new planes and the Navy needs 500. Pilot Dave Ferguson said the YF-22 flew as expected although the flight was shortened by 42 minutes because of problems at ground telemetry stations. The jet burned so much fuel while sitting on the runway waiting for takeoff that there wasn't enough left for the scheduled one-hour flight. ``It was a very easy airplane to fly,'' said Ferguson, adding, ``I would be happy to put fuel in it and fly it this afternoon.'' The jet reached an altitude of 12,500 feet and a speed of about 280 mph. The two-tone gray jet with stubby wings and a V-shaped tail touched down smoothly in a light rain. The YF-22 was built by Lockheed, General Dynamics Corp. and Boeing Co. It was unveiled in Palmdale Aug. 29, two days after the YF-23, built by Northrop Corp. and McDonnell Douglas Corp., made its first flight. Lockheed Vice President Sherman Mullin, head of the YF-22 project, said he could not compare the two planes because he didn't have enough information about the YF-23. Each team has spent about $600 million producing two prototype jets each. ``It's obviously an extremely important program to us,'' said Mullin. ``(But) it's not a program that's going to make or break the Lockheed Corp.'' Both planes are built of advanced composite materials. The Lockheed aircraft has stubby wings. The Northrop fighter has a longer, cigarlike fuselage and a wingspread that looks like a kite. ``This is a great day from a technological perspective,'' said Gary L. Denman, who heads an Air Force research division. ``I can assure you, what's out there in the airplane is the best in the world.'' Survival of the advanced fighter program was threatened by Congress until Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. The crisis has enhanced prospects for approval of major defense contracts. If Northrop and McDonnell Douglas win the contract, the YF-23 would be built in California. The Lockheed-General Dynamics-Boeing team plans to build YF-22s in Marietta, Ga., if it wins. The selection is due in 1991. The $51 million cost of each jet is about twice that of the Air Force's present top fighter, the F-15 Eagle.

DOC.HEAD: Trustee Says Some Student Gripes Backed By City Officials
DOC.TEXT: Many city officials agree with the students who forced the University of the District of Columbia to close because of their frustration with the mayoral appointees running the school, a university trustee said Saturday. The protestors seized of a number of university offices Wednesday because they believe the school's programs are being run by a board of trustees made up of pals of Mayor Marion Barry rather than by educators, Alonza Evans said. ``They wanted to know why they didn't have big name trustees who could bring in millions of dollars in donations ... rather than just some of (Barry's) political cronies,'' he told reporters before returning to closed-door negotiations among students, administrators and trustees. Trustees at UDC, a public institution with about 12,000 students, are nominated by the mayor and confirmed by the council members. They cannot be forced to resign. The students have demanded a number of academic improvements in return for leaving one of the campus' main buildings so classes can resume. They also asked the 11 mayoral appointees to the 15-member board to resign immediately, a demand that was rejected Friday. At least three City Council members have said they also would like board members to resign. Council members plan to call a hearing soon to devise a new way of appointing board members, Councilman James Nathanson said. ``We have been very dissatisfied with performance of the board, we are looking for a way to restructure the board,'' Nathanson said last week. The trustees admit the school, which has had five presidents or acting presidents in the last eight years, is in trouble and have offered to make changes, Stanley said. Regardless of the outcome of talks, classes will resume Monday, according to Trustee A. Knighton Stanley. The students say otherwise. ``School will remain closed until this matter is ended,'' student leader Mark Thompson said before talks began Saturday. ``Honestly, right now, we don't anticipate an end by Monday.'' He also said the students will not compromise on their insistence that the board members resign. That stand could backfire on the students, said Evans, a 1978 alumnus who was appointed by the school's alumni organization, not the mayor. ``I have been saying for four days that the students have legitimate concerns,'' he said. ``But we are prepared to resume classes Monday.'' The protest led Trustee Nira Long to resign as the board's chairwoman effective Oct. 16, and that was a significant victory, he said. Students have complained that school officials have threatened to remove them forcibly if they are not out by Monday.

DOC.HEAD: Beirut Hostage's High School Sends Symbolic Balloons Skyward
With AM-Hostages
DOC.TEXT: Beirut hostage Jon Turner's high school sent 1,343 balloons loose at its homecoming football game - one balloon for every day of his captivity. A slip of paper in each balloon carried Turner's name and date of capture from the Beirut university where he taught: Jan. 24, 1987 - 1,343 days before Friday's game. ``I hope God listens and I hope these balloons reach him so that Jon will be back soon,'' said his wife, Badr Turner, a Lebanese native who was watching her first American football game. Turner graduated from Boise High School in 1965 and his mother, Estelle Ronneburg, still lives in town. ``We want people to know that we haven't forgotten Jon,'' said Libby Shivers, who attended Boise High with Turner and organized the launch. Turner is among six U.S. hostages in Lebanon. There are seven other Western captives, four Britons, two West Germans and an Italian.

DOC.HEAD: Abortion Foes Protest Restored Planned Parenthood Funding
DOC.TEXT: Several hundred abortion opponents broke their credit cards into pieces outside a department store Saturday to protest a company's decision to restore funding to Planned Parenthood. Abortion rights advocates got the Dayton Hudson Foundation to reconsider its earlier decision to cut Planned Parenthood funding with similar protests and threats of a holiday season boycott. About 400 abortion foes staged their protest outside a Target store. Minneapolis-based Dayton Hudson Corp. operates Target stores, as well as Dayton's, Marshall Field's, Mervyn's and Hudson's stores in 33 states. Brian Gibson, executive director of Pro-Life Action Ministries Inc., urged protesters to boycott Dayton Hudson stores for at least one year. Some protesters snapped their Dayton Hudson credit cards and collected the pieces to send to company officials. The foundation funded Planned Parenthood for 22 years before deciding in August to suspend the aid in an effort to distance itself from abortion controversy. After abortion rights' groups threatened to start a holiday boycott the day after Thanksgiving and hundreds of customers cut up their Dayton's credit cards, the Foundation last week announced it was restoring its $18,000 grant to Planned Parenthood for a restricted community education fund. Planned Parenthood Executive Director Thomas Webber has said that money from the Foundation never paid for abortion services. The agency provides birth-control add gynecological services, as well as abortions. Gibson told protesters, ``Dayton Hudson's gift to Planned Parenthood is like this organization giving money to the Nazis and saying, `Use this for your super race, just don't use it for your gas chambers.'''

DOC.HEAD: Iraq Foreign Minister in Surprise Visit to Jordan; Int'l Force Grows
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout, UPDATING with Soviet statement on sending Soviet troops to gulf, EC embassies in Kuwait to close, U.S. logistics called adequate, more Indian refugees leave, other. No pickup
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos BRE1, LON2,3, YAN1,2, AMM2,4, DHA4
DOC.TEXT: Iraq's foreign minister made a surprise appearance in Jordan on Saturday, giving rise to speculation that Saddam Hussein might be seeking to circumvent the economic embargo or open new diplomatic maneuvers. President Bush meanwhile sought to solidify the international condemnation of Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait in a series of meetings with other world leaders in New York beginning Saturday. In the gulf region, the multinational force took on a more multinational character. Britain launched a deployment that was to include thousands of ground troops, Egyptian reinforcements were on their way, and the first French Foreign Legionnaires arrived in Saudi Arabia. Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze said Saturday the Soviet Union also would be willing to send troops into military action in the Persian Gulf if it is sanctioned by the United Nations. ``We will comply with any decision, with any resolution of the Security Council. . . . And that would include anything regarding the involvement of the Soviet troops under the flag, under the auspices, of the United Nations,'' he said in a taped interview for broadcast Sunday on NBC News' ``Meet the Press.'' France warned Saturday it would retaliate if it turns out Iraq was behind a grenade attack that killed a French child and injured 17 people Thursday night in Djibouti. The small Red Sea country provides support bases for French forces deployed in the gulf region. If Iraq is found responsible, Foreign Minister Roland Dumas said, ``there will be a response from France and - you better believe it - it will be appropriate to the hateful nature of this attack.'' Belgian Foreign Minister Mark Eyskens said Saturday most European Community embassies in Kuwait City, including Belgium's, will probably close next week because the situation is becoming unbearable. The Iraqis have cut off water and energy supplies to the embassies. At the same time, Iraq backed off a threat to deprive non-Arab foreigners of food under new rationing beginning Monday. The threat came last week in a Foreign Ministry memorandum sent to non-Arab embassies, Western diplomats said. The official Iraqi News Agency quoted Trade and Finance Minister Mohammed Mehdi Saleh as saying Saturday that rationed food would be provided equally to all, and calling earlier reports part of a ``rabid campaign against Iraq.'' An estimated 650,000 foreigners remain in Iraq and Kuwait, of the more than 2 million there before the invasion. It was the second time in two weeks Iraq made a drastic threat against foreigners and then rescinded it. Last week, Baghdad told Western diplomats that harboring foreigners was a crime punishable by death - a threat Western governments interpreted as directed at their envoys. A day later, Iraqi officials said the decree applied only to Iraqi citizens. In an interview over Belgian TV from New York, where he was attending the U.N. General Assembly, Eyskens said water and electricity to the Belgian Embassy were cut, ``food has practically run out and psychological pressure is enormous,'' with Iraqi troops ringing the embassy. Eyskens said Britain may continue to hold out, but almost all other EC countries probably will close their embassies, too. The U.S. Embassy still defies Iraqi closure demands. Bush was in New York to attend the World Summit for Children at the United Nations. But the gulf crisis was high on his agenda. He set weekend and Monday meetings with leaders including Shevardnadze and prime ministers Margaret Thatcher of Britain and Toshiki Kaifu of Japan. On Monday, Bush was to make a major speech on the gulf to the General Assembly. Iraqi Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz visited Amman on Saturday, meeting with King Hussein and then returning to Baghdad. Jordan was a principal trading partner of Iraq before the invasion, and even after the United Nations approved the trade embargo, some supplies continued to flow through Jordan. Iraq imported three-quarters of its food before the sanctions started. It imposed rationing of some staples as a result of the embargo. New nationwide rationing on Monday is to cover rice, flour, sugar, tea and cooking oil. Jordan has been battered economically by the sanctions, and agreed only reluctantly to abide by them. It was not known whether Aziz specifically sought a loosening of the embargo in Saturday's talks, but Baghdad is believed to have made similar overtures to Iran, with which it recently patched up relations. Jordan's difficult position was underlined Saturday when the king postponed for 48 days convening of the regular session of Parliament, which had been set for Monday. The monarch gave no reason, but some lawmakers saw it as an attempt to muzzle strong pro-Iraqi sentiment in the legislature. Although Jordan condemned the Iraqi invasion, it has spoken out strongly against the U.S.-led foreign military deployment in the region. The U.S. contingent stood almost alone early in the crisis, but allies have been contributing larger and larger shares of troops and equipment. The first desert-hardened units of the French Foreign Legion arrived Saturday in Saudi Arabia, joining the largest deployment of French forces overseas since Algeria's 1954-62 war of independence. The bulk of French ground forces - 4,000 troops - are expected to arrive Sunday. France will have about 13,000 troops in and around Saudi Arabia when the deployment is completed. A monthlong British deployment of up to 9,000 ground forces was under way, British officials said. The logistical landing ship Sir Tristram sailed Friday night from England, and hundreds of troops left by air from bases in England and Germany. Egyptian military sources said Saturday about 1,000 Egyptian soldiers had left the port of Alexandria for Saudi Arabia. Gen. Mohammed Ali Bilal, commander of Egyptian forces in Saudi Arabia, said he expected the number of his troops in the kingdom to reach 20,000 within the next 15 days. The United States has sent about 165,000 soldiers to the gulf region, most of them in Saudi Arabia. The Pentagon said Iraq had boosted its forces to 430,000 in and around Kuwait. In other developments Saturday: -Maj. Gen. William G. Pagonis, commander of U.S. military logistics in Saudi Arabia, said the supply flow was on schedule and could sustain U.S. forces for more than a month in an all-out war with Iraq. He called his supply problems ``peanuts'' compared to those facing Iraq. -The Indian passenger ship Akbar moved out of Iraqi waters with 1,700 Indian refugees as the Tipu Sultan approached the southern gulf port of Dubai with 700 others. The Al-Safeer, also Indian, brought out 725 refugees earlier this month. -Iranian and Iraqi newspapers carried editorials warning of a flood of refugees in case war broke out and cautioning Moscow not to play into Washington's hands. The English-language Baghdad Observer said, ``It is paramount that Moscow should not miss the historic opportunity of playing a positive role which it can do without risking its fundamental economic, political and financial interests.''

DOC.HEAD: Nicaraguan President Gives Bush Disabled AK-47 Assault Rifle
With AM-Bush-UN
DOC.TEXT: Nicaraguan President Violeta Chamorro gave President Bush a souvenir Saturday of her country's shift toward democracy: a confiscated AK-47 rifle cut in half by a blowtorch. Mrs. Chamorro said the Soviet-made weapon was seized from a civilian as part of her government's efforts to pacify the country after a decade of rule under the Sandinistas. The two presidents met in advance of Sunday's World Summit for Children at the United Nations. Speaking in Spanish, Mrs. Chamorro said, ``This is a souvenir of the peace that I am bringing about in my country. I want to give it to you as a sign of the end of the war and the beginning of our democracy.'' Mrs. Chamorro, a newspaper publisher, defeated Sandinista President Daniel Ortega in free elections last February and took office two months later. ``I don't know if you really like the gift,'' said Mrs. Chamorro. ``I do, I do like the gift,'' Bush assured her. Aides said later he planned to display the disabled weapon in a special trophy room at Camp David, the presidential retreat in Maryland. The Sandinistas distributed rifles to the populace in their closing weeks in power, and Mrs. Chamorro's government has since been rounding up the weapons. Bush assured Mrs. Chamorro he would make a special effort to ensure that Nicaragua gets the full $200 million in aid for fiscal 1991 that Bush has asked for, notwithstanding the United States' current budget difficulties. ``The president and the secretary (Secretary of State James Baker III) made it clear that Nicaragua was a priority ... and we'll do everything we can to provide as much of that amount as possible,'' a senior administration official said. The official, who asked not to be identified, said Mrs. Chamorro also told Bush that a new passed law against arms trafficking in Nicaragua will help ``strengthen her ability to crack down on any continuing arms to the FMLN,'' the leftist rebels in El Salvador. Mrs. Chamorro, speaking with reporters after her meeting with Bush, stressed her country's need for humanitarian aid as it struggled to rebuild. Speaking through an interpreter, she said she is ``not going to allow that 50 years of struggle for democracy in Nicaragua, which is now only five months old, should fail because of economic need.''

DOC.HEAD: Goverment Seeks to Revoke Lockheed Retirement Policy for Test Pilots
DOC.TEXT: The government is suing Lockheed Corp. over its mandatory retirement age for test pilots. The lawsuit filed Friday by the Equal Employent Opportunity Commission seeks to allow Kenneth Wier, 59, to keep his job as a chief test pilot past his birthday on Oct. 20. Lockheed requires mandatory retirement at age 60. Lockheed has warned Wier he will face retirement if he does not give up his pilot's job and accept a ground position by Monday. The suit filed in U.S. District Court seeks to overturn the age limit, plus back pay and possible reinstatement for test pilots forced to retire under the policy. U.S. District Judge Terry Hatter Jr. denied an EEOC motion to temporarily block the retirement policy while the suit is pending. Lockheed officials expressed surprise at the federal agency's action. ``We don't know why they decided to do this now, with this pilot,'' company spokesman Jim Ragsdale said. Lockheed says its retirement policy is based on commercial airline policy, which also mandates retirement at age 60. ``The physical and psychological demands on Lockheed pilots are significantly greater than those placed on pilots in commercial aviation,'' Lockheed lawyers argued in court documents. ``Certainly no lesser standard can be applied.'' Wier, of Santa Ana is currently chief test pilot for the U2 and TR1 reconnaissance plane programs, a job he has held for 18 years, Ragsdale said. Wier's record is excellent and his performance has shown no deterioration in the past few years, Ragsdale said. Court documents say Wier has flown more than 235 types of planes in his 35 years as a pilot. He has flown for Lockheed for 24 years.

DOC.HEAD: Counsel Recommends Sens. Glenn, McCain Be Cleared, Sources Say
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Karolyn with a K is cq
DOC.TEXT: A special Senate counsel recommended more than two weeks ago that the Ethics Committee clear two of the five senators under investigation for their ties to savings and loan operator Charles H. Keating Jr., sources confirmed Saturday. The confidential Sept. 10 report of Robert S. Bennett said there was inadequate evidence to pursue the case against Sens. John Glenn, D-Ohio, and John McCain, R-Ariz., but advised the panel to look further in the case of the three others - Democratic Sens. Donald W. Riegle Jr. of Michigan, Dennis DeConcini of Arizona and Alan Cranston of California, the sources said. Neither Bennett nor any of the six members of the ethics panel, led by Chairman Howell Heflin, D-Ala., would comment on the disclosure, originally made late Friday, about the special counsel's recommendations or why the committee has yet to act upon them despite three interim meetings. And none of the senators targeted by the probe said he had any formal word about Bennett's findings, though McCain's spokesman, Scott Celley, said: ``We presume it's true, since there's been no denial. The senator is pleased to hear this ... and hopes the Ethics Committee will vote these recommendations soon. Certainly he hopes it will have acted before the election. There is an old saying, `Justice delayed is justice denied.''' None of the five is up for re-election this year, but some sources, talking on condition of anonymity, said they believed Heflin and other members of the ethics panel are reluctant to take any definitive action in the heated political atmosphere, particularly at a time when the Senate is burdened with crucial floor business over the budget and other issues. ``I wouldn't look for a thing until after election day,'' said one aide close to the case. ``Believe me a lot of senators on both sides of the aisle feel that way. I can't count the number of them who have told me, `There, but for the grace of God, go I,' and want to move the issue off center stage.'' If Glenn and McCain were cleared, Republicans could point to the fact that those remaining under scrutiny in Congress are all Democrats, and some GOP aides suggested that may have something to do with the delay. But Republicans still would have no monopoly on finger-pointing in the S & L debacle, with President Bush's son, Neil, facing serious allegations over his dealings in a Colorado case. And conservative Republican Sen. Jesse Helms, R-N.C., an Ethic Committee member and close political ally of McCain, said earlier in the week the committee is moving as fast as it can. ``Do you suggest we don't work every angle?'' he asked. ``We just have a heavy load.'' All five senators subject to the investigation have acknowledged intervening with banking regulators on behalf of Keating, but say they did so in a proper manner consistent with their duties toward any constituent seeking help. Collectively, they received $1.3 million in campaign contributions from Keating and his associates. The three senators who, under Bennett's recommendation, would remain under investigation declined direct comment on that prospect. Riegle's spokeswoman, Karolyn Wallace, said ``The committee is in stage one of a possible three-stage process. Senator Riegle is confident its review will find his conduct to have been proper.'' Keating controlled Lincoln Savings and Loan of Irvine, Calif., whose failure has been estimated to cost the taxpayers $2 billion. His family is from Ohio; he had a hotel project in Michigan and his principal corporation operated in Arizona, where his enterprises once pumped an estimated $100 million annually into the economy and had a payroll of 50,000. Keating, charged with fraud in the sale of more than $200 million in risky junk bonds, is in jail in Los Angeles, unable to make $5 million bail.

DOC.HEAD: Spanish Director Pleased With Movie Ratings Change
DOC.TEXT: An award-winning Spanish director whose latest film received an X rating in the United States said he hopes a change in classifying adult-oriented movies will bring his work to a wider American audience. ``I'm very pleased because this means there will be a new market for the film,'' Pedro Almodovar told El Pais newspaper in a story published Saturday. ``Tie Me Up! Tie Me Down!'' the 38-year-old director's seventh feature film, was rated X earlier this year by the Motion Picture Association of America because of the movie's explicit sexual scenes. The film tells the story of a former mental patient who kidnaps a pornographic film star and ex-drug addict, who eventually falls in love with him. Almodovar and the film's distributor, Miramax Films, sued in May to get the film's rating changed to R, which prohibits minors unless accompanied by a parent. The film was finally distributed without a rating. Many U.S. movie houses shied away from X-rated films because of the perceived link to hard-core sexual films, which often use the X rating in advertisements. The X rating, the only category not copyrighted by the film association, prohibits viewers under 18 years old. The X rating was eliminated Wednesday in favor of a new NC-17. The R rating remains intact, as does the PG-13, PG and G ratings. The first beneficiary of the new rating system is Philip Kaufman's formerly X-rated film on the life of author Henry Miller, ``Henry and June,'' from Universal Pictures, scheduled for release Oct. 5. ``We all feel that Universal's protest over the rating (of Kaufman's film) was the determining factor,'' said film producer Agustin Almodovar, the director's brother. Agustin Almodovar said he and his brother would seek a new rating for ``Tie Me Up! Tie Me Down!'' The new rating ``would open the possibility of showing the film in at least 100 theaters of the most conservative states where it was refused because it had no rating.'' Pedro Almodovar's ``Women on the Verge of a Nervous Breakdown'' has grossed nearly $30 million in worldwide sales and is the biggest box office hit in Spanish history. Actress Jane Fonda has bought the rights for a U.S. production. Almodovar, who worked for the telephone company in central Spain before getting involved in underground productions, has based many of his films on confusion over sexual roles, unrequitted love and the hassles of life in modern Spain. He said recently he would like to change the tenor of his work and has purchased the rights to ``Time for Friendship,'' a short story set in North Africa by American author Paul Bowles. The director added that he felt the movie association's decisions seemed biased against foreign films. Another Miramax-distributed film, British director Peter Greenaway's ``The Cook, The Thief, His Wife and Her Lover,'' also was rated X. ``I don't think I would be overly modest in saying that it was we Europeans, or my brother and I if you like, who put our necks on the line for a principle,'' he said. Other X-rated films of high artistic quality have included 1969's ``Midnight Cowboy,'' 1973's ``Last Tango in Paris,'' 1969's ``if...'' and 1971's ``A Clockwork Orange.'' There is no rating system for films in Spain, which emerged 14 years ago from the rigid censorship of the 36-year dictatorship of Gen. Francisco Franco. Spanish state television features striptease acts on prime time shows, and two of the three new private TV channels compete for audience with parades of topless - and sometimes bottomless - young women.

DOC.HEAD: Five U.S. Soldiers Hurt in Helicopter Accident
DOC.TEXT: Five U.S. soldiers were injured Saturday in a helicopter crash during a night training mission in the Saudi desert, according to a U.S. military statement. It said the UH-60 Blackhawk helicopter belonged to the 17th Cavalry Regiment, 101st Airborne Division. No details on the crash or the condition of the soldiers were immediately available. The names of the soldiers were withheld pending notification of relatives. It was the fourth crash of a U.S. military helicopter since the deployment to the Persian Gulf region following Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. There have been no deaths reported in the crashes. Two U.S. soldiers were killed and three injured in vehicle accidents in the gulf. A Saudi man was killed in a collision between taxi and a Marine Corps pickup truck. Saturday's crash came shortly after the release of a statement by the U.S. Command Center saying the number of injuries during Operation Desert Shield had been ``surprisingly low.'' A report from Fort Rucker, Ala., found the number of accident-related injuries lower than when troops are at bases in the United States.

DOC.HEAD: Supply Craft Docks with Soviet Space Station
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf to add description of crystals
DOC.TEXT: A Soviet Progress M-5 cargo space craft carrying fuel, supplies and mail docked Saturday afternoon with the orbiting Mir space station, Tass reported. The official news agency said cosmonauts Gennady Manakov and Gennady Strelakov were shown on Soviet television with items that the supply craft was to carry back to Earth, including canisters containing crystals grown in space. The crystals are used in manufacturing computer chips. Manakov and Strekalov boarded the space station in early August, replacing Anatoly Solovyev and Alexander Balandin. Solovyev and Balandin, using a furnace in the special ``Krystall'' module docked to the Mir, produced 23 pure crystals from February to August. Authorities said the crystals were worth about $1 million each, and could make the current project the first profitable space mission.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Promises to Seek Special Trade Benefits for Colombia
DOC.TEXT: President Bush promised Colombian President Cesar Gaviria on Saturday that he will seek special trade benefits for Colombia in recognition of that nation's efforts to curb international drug trafficking. Gaviria told a news conference after a meeting between the two presidents here that Bush's plan includes eased tariffs on Colombian flowers, the Latin country's second biggest export after coffee. The White House confirmed that Bush would seek benefits for Colombia under a Caribbean Basin proposal that will be sent to Congress next week. The president's proposal, if approved by Congress, would make Colombian flowers duty free, White House deputy press secretary Roman Popadiuk said. Gaviria met with reporters after conferring with Bush and aides to both presidents in the Waldorf Astoria. He said the United States was ``very satisfied'' with Colombia's efforts in the drug wars. Gaviria said that Bush ``indicated we deserve special treatment ... They are announcing that the Caribbean Basin Initiative will be extended for some Colombian products.'' That will include flowers, he said. His country exports 80 percent of its flower crop to the United States. The administration, responding to complaints from American growers, had accused Colombia of ``dumping'' cut flowers in this country at unreasonably low prices. As a result, the United States had sharply increased tariffs on Colombian flowers. Gaviria said Bush also thanked him for Colombia's support in the United Nations Security Council for the international embargo and other moves to pressure Iraqi President Saddam Hussein to withdraw his troops from Kuwait. Bush also expressed gratitude for Colombia's increase in oil production in the crisis. The White House said Bush told Gaviria of concerns that market speculators were driving up the price of oil. The Colombian president was asked if Bush seemed optimistic or pessimistic about the chances of avoiding war. ``I only can say that he is realistic,'' Gaviria said. ``He knows all the limitations he has in the Middle East.'' ``He has the hope that we will not have a war there,'' he added. Discussing the war against drugs, Bush expressed concern over a new wave of terrorism in Colombia ``and the need for both countries to deal forthrightly with the drug situation,'' a White House statement said. It said that Bush raised the idea of ``consensual'' boarding of ships suspected of carrying drugs. Gaviria said he would look into the process of getting approval for the U.S. Coast Guard to inspect ships at sea.

DOC.HEAD: Mormon Church Gets Recognition For First Soviet Branch
DOC.TEXT: The Mormon Church has gained recognition for its first branch in the Soviet Union, the church said Saturday. The Soviet Union's Council on Religious Affairs has registered the Leningrad Branch of the Mormon Church, the Utah-based church said. Mormon officials said efforts to obtain official recognition of the church in the Soviet Union go back to June 1987. The Soviet parliament last week adopted a new freedom of religion law, easing decades of strict prohibitions on religious instruction at home and in private schools. The law also forbids the government from interfering with religious activities and improves the legal status of religious organizations. Mormon missionary work in the Soviet Union is proceeding on a limited basis, conducted in members' homes. Church services also are held in members' homes, said church spokesman Don LeFevre. Under Soviet law, each congregation of a religious organization must be registered separately. When 20 or more members reside in any one political district, they may apply for recognition, the church said in a news release. The 7.5-million-member church provided no estimates of membership in the Soviet Union except to say it was small. The Leningrad Branch will be administered as a unit of the Baltic District of the Finland Helsinki East Mission. There is no mission in the Soviet Union. Representatives of The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints were notified of the branch recognition during a Sept. 19 meeting in Moscow with Evgenii Chernetsov, head of the nation's religious affairs section for non-Russian Orthodox religions, LeFevre said.

DOC.HEAD: Arkansas Volunteers Make Care Packages for U.S. Troops in Gulf
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Volunteers trying to bring a little cheer to U.S. troops in the Persian Gulf loaded care packages with books, magazines, chewing gum and other goodies Saturday - including letters from school children. People from all over Arkansas traveled to Little Rock to make contributions. Paul Howell, vice president of the state Council of Vietnam Veterans of America, and fellow veteran C.D. Smith, both of Little Rock, spearheaded the care package effort. ``We know how valuable, both of us being combat veterans, this is to the troops,'' Howell said, adding that besides providing support for the troops, the effort gave worried families and friends left behind a chance to help. ``We give them a sudden burst of energy in a positive direction, to take their frustrations in not knowing what to do, and put them into this project,'' Howell said. Boxes were packed with gifts including shaving lotion, lip balm, toilet paper and dozens of other items. Howell said response to the project dubbed Operation Desert Relief has been overwhelming and the most touching gifts were the children's letters. ``That's pretty heavy - children that don't know these people and they're writing in support, showing their love for these strangers,'' he said. ``We're talking children that don't even know what the price of freedom is, but they're growing up fast in this situation.'' Organizers don't know how the goods will be distributed, but they worked with military authorities to make sure the boxes met regulations. Perhaps the most-prized donation was an autographed football from University of Arkansas head coach Jack Crowe and the Razorback team, accompanied by a letter of support. ``That's very warming to our hearts,'' Howell said. ``That's something we're very proud of.''

DOC.HEAD: Principal at Nationally Recognized School Demoted Over Altered Documents
DOC.TEXT: An elementary school principal recently honored by the White House has been demoted after investigators concluded the school faked report cards, doctored achievement tests and inflated attendance records. Michael Kesselman, who two weeks ago received a White House award for excellence at his school, was transferred Friday to another school where he will teach social studies. Dade County School Superintendent Paul Bell said the school board's investigation did not turn up any evidence that Kesselman altered school documents. ``In none of the interviews conducted by the investigators was there anyone who said they saw him change anything,'' Bell said. ``The substantiated facts lead to the conclusion that at best Dr. Kesselman is guilty of administrative incompetence.'' ``Errors were made,'' Kesselman said, but pointed out that investigators cleared him of intentional wrongdoing. ``I've had nine years of exemplary evaluations as an administrator, so I must have been doing something right.'' Kesselman made $66,530 a year as principal at North Beach Elementary School. As a teacher, he'll receive $49,400. His departure was met by protests from supporters and PTA leaders who credit him with gaining recognition from President Bush and the U.S. Education Department as a National School of Excellence. Investigators checked a selection of achievement test answer sheets and found clear evidence that they had been altered to improve scores. Evidence of doctoring was found on 53 of 62 tests. In some cases, wrong answers were erased and changed to correct answers. ``No one saw anyone change the test scores, but Kesselman was responsible for securing the scores,'' Bell said. The investigation also found that 75 students who were on the school rolls during the 1989-90 school year did not attend the school. Some phantom students even got report cards.

DOC.HEAD: Government Bans Export Of All Goods From Romania
DOC.TEXT: Cracking down on black market smugling, the government Saturday ordered travelers to take only minimum amounts of goods when they leave the country on trips this winter. The government also barred Romanians and foreign travelers from taking more than a day's supply of food across borders from Oct. 1 through April 30. ``This decision is a reaction to confront the hemorrhage of Romanian goods across the border, which is squeezing the Romanian market, which is so poor anyway,'' government spokesman Adrian Sirbu said. Romanians seeking foreign currency or scarce foods like meat and sugar are selling items such as carpets, clothing and tents in Turkey, Hungary and Bulgaria. The government also restricted imports of foreign cars. Sirbu said Romanians were buying second-hand gas guzzlers in Austria, West Germany and Holland. ``Most of these western cars have powerful engines, so they eat more gasoline,'' Sirbu said. Gasoline is also scarce in Romania.

DOC.HEAD: India, Pakistan in Abrasive U.N. Debate
DOC.TEXT: India and Pakistan are trading ever harsher accusations before the U.N. General Assembly, even as other speakers welcome the easing of tension and rivalries in some other parts of the world. In speeches Friday, Pakistan's foreign minister, Sahabzada Yaqub Khan, accused India of reneging on a 40-year-old pledge of self-determination for the Kashmir. He urged the international community to ``exert its moral and political influence to support the struggle of the people of Kashmir.'' External Affairs Minister Inder Kumar Gujral of India charged in his speech that Pakistan armed and assisted terrorists for more than eight years in the Indian Punjab. Recently Pakistan ``has chosen to extend these practices'' to the northern territory of Kashmir, he said, where thousands have died since Indian military forces began a crackdown in mid-January. Gujral said Pakistan ``characteristically denied responsibility and involvement in these acts'' and now tries ``to justify them on the pretext of support to religious fundamentalism'' in violation of international law and good neighborliness. Yaqub Khan described the upheaval in Kashmir as a ``spontaneous uprising'' that 300,000 Indian security forces people are trying to crush. The two countries have twice gone to war over the Kashmir, in 1947-48 and in 1965. The wars have left Kashmir divided into Pakistani and Indian sectors. Both foreign ministers accused the other of rejecting proposals for resolving their disputes and building confidence. Yaqub Khan said that at two high-level meetings in July and August, ``the Indian side evaded the core issues, namely discussion of the Kashmir dispute and redeployment of forces to peacetime locations'' in the region. Gujral said India and Pakistan ``can have a great future if we respect each other's integrity and unity and once Pakistan desists from the temptation of interfering in our internal affairs.'' He said that in that spirit, ``I will not refer to the gross flouting of human rights in Pakistan,'' and the dismissal of Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto. ``That is Pakistan's internal matter, even though democrats everywhere feel concerned,'' he said. Ms. Bhutto, elected in 1988, was thrown out of office by President Ghulam Ishaq Khan last month. Sunday she was to appear before a court that will decide whether she can participate in politics in the future.

DOC.HEAD: Highest German Court Scraps United Germany Election Plan
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERT 3 grafs after 9th graf, Although it . . . UPDATING with East German violence. Picks up 10th graf, West German . . .
DOC.TEXT: West Germany's highest court ruled in favor of East Germany's former Communists on Saturday and threw out a plan for holding united German elections on Dec. 2. The Federal Constitutional Court said the election format would deny small parties a fair chance at power in the united Germany that will be created on Wednesday. Although the ruling will not halt the historic merger, it is a victory for the now-reformed Communists who once ruled East Germany and increases the chances they will win seats in a ew Parliament. The decision also will force lawmakers to scramble this week to come up with an alternative election plan and avoid postponing the first united German elections in 60 years. Meanwhile, the top lawman in West Berlin warned of an ``alarming security situation in East Berlin,'' where leftist radicals have been reported to be planning riots to protest Germany unity. West Berlin Interior Minister Erich Paetzold, in a letter to police officials in both Berlins, called on officers to work together next week to contain violence as their departments merge. About 5,000 people marched Saturday from West Berlin to East Berlin to protest what they called ``the annexation'' of East Germany by West Germany. The protest was called by a women's group demanding greater rights in a united Germany. Although it is popularly called German unification, in fact East Germany is essentially dissolving itself and acceding to the larger nation, whose laws will supplant East Germany's. East Germany braced for growing unrest in its final days as a nation. Inmates seized prison rooftops in Dresden, Buetzow and Leipzig on Saturday to protest a prisoner amnesty plan that would exempt those convicted of violent crimes. Many claim they were falsely imprisoned under the Communists. In East Berlin, authorities made 15 arrests after hundreds of young people rampaged Friday night through the city's main square, Alexanderplatz, following a soccer match. East Berlin has become increasingly violent since borders to the West were opened. West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl will be in charge of a united Germany after Wednesday. Kohl plans to add four East Germans to his Cabinet. West Germany's Parliament also will add 144 lawmakers chosen late Friday from the 400-member East German Parliament. Among those East German lawmakers are 24 members of the reformed Communists, who are the third-largest party in East Germany but would be only a small political voice in a greater Germany. West German government spokesman Dieter Vogel said he hoped the combined Parliament this week would come up with a new election plan quickly enough to still hold elections on Dec. 2. The constitutional court's decision was based on a complaint brought by the former Communists, the environmental Greens coalition, and the far-right Republicans. Hans Christian Stroebele, spokesman for the Greens, hailed the decision as ``sweet success against the arrogance of the cocky dominant parties.'' The rejected election plan was the result of a compromise in August between the conservative Christian Democrats, the top party in both German lands; and the main opposition; the left-leaning Social Democrats. Under the election plan, parties would need to win 5 percent of the vote across a united Germany to get a seat in Parliament. The election treaty also would have allowed smaller parties to form alliances with larger parties and share ballots, allowing small parties to get the necessary 5 percent. But the former Communists and the rightist Republicans have virtually no chance of winning 5 percent of the total German vote, nor of finding mainstream parties willing to share a ballot. Ernst Gottfried Mahrenholz, vice president of the constitutional court, said it was unfair to require small East German parties to get 5 percent of the vote nationwide. The court also struck down the mechanism that would allow smaller parties to be listed with larger, allied parties. The Social Democrats wanted the 5 percent limit to keep small, left-leaning parties from getting in Parliament and diluting the Social Democrats' clout in a united Germany. The Chrstian Democrats wanted the agreement that would allow bigger parties to form alliances with smaller parties because Kohl's power base is comprised of coalitions with other conservative and centrist parties.

DOC.HEAD: Atheists Angry After United Way Chapter Reverses Boy Scout Funding Cut
DOC.TEXT: A United Way chapter, fearing a fund-raising backlash, reversed its decision to cut funding to a Boy Scouts group because of protests from atheists over the scout oath, officials said Saturday. Atheists blasted the decision and said they'd continue the fight. They oppose a scout's oath to do his duty ``to God and my country.'' The Genoa-Kingston United Way chapter reversed itself by an 8-1 vote late Friday and will resume its $1,250 contribution to the Boy Scouts of America-Two Rivers Council. ``There was an overwhelming response from our donor base that they wanted the Boy Scouts funded,'' United Way board chairman Jim Ferris said at a news conference. ``There was some concern that our ability to collect may be hurt by the previous board decision.'' Robert Sherman, a spokesman for the northern Illinois chapter of American Atheists Inc., based in Austin, Texas, said the United Way group violated its promise not to support an organization that practices religious discrimination. ``They are soliciting money from atheists and others under a promise that these funds would be used for human care services without discrimination,'' Sherman said at a news conference. ``There is an impression that society will tolerate the violation of atheists' rights,'' he said. The Genoa-Kingston United Way group, based about 60 miles northwest of Chicago, voted to halt the Boy Scout funding Aug. 29. The Boy Scout council is based in the small north Chicago suburb of St. Charles. A pending federal lawsuit filed in Chicago challenges the requirement that Boy Scouts take the oath. ``The charge of discrimination that the atheists are raising is in the courts right now for a decision,'' United Way of America spokesman Tony De Christofaro said in an interview from Alexander, Va. ``That is why (local officials) reinstated the allocation,'' he said. The Boy Scouts receive more than $80 million a year from United Way agencies across the country, Christofaro said. The local chapter's original decision to withhold 1991 funding made it the first of 1,400 United Way groups nationwide to take such action. The atheists' group will ask the Illinois attorney general to investigate the United Way chapter, Sherman said. Atheists also hope to block any future United Way grants to the scouts with legal action and plan a federal lawsuit seeking to revoke the Boy Scouts' national charter, granted by Congress, he said.

DOC.HEAD: China Supplied Rare Chemical to Iraq, Newspaper Says
DOC.TEXT: China sold Iraq large quantities of a rare chemical used to make missile fuel, poison gas - and possibly nuclear weapons - in violation of the U.N. trade embargo, a newspaper reported. The Independent in its Sunday editions said it had documents showing that around Sept. 20, a subsidiary of North China Industries Corp. agreed to supply about seven tons of lithium hydride to Iraq for about $1.5 million. The deal was struck ``in great secrecy,'' the newspaper said. Britain's Foreign Office said it was studying the report. China, a permanent member of the U.N. Security Council, voted for a resolution banning trade with Iraq following its Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. The Independent reported the U.S. Embassy in Beijing told the Chinese Foreign Ministry it was concerned about the activities of the Chinese firm, known as Norinco. It was not known if the embassy's statement was related to the lithium hydride deal, it said. Iraqi President Saddam Hussein has previously tried to obtain lithium hydride, but the three Western manufacturers of the chemical are suspicious of large orders. The chemical is used in minute quantities in the pharmaceutical and computer industries, the newspaper said. Just before the U.N. trade embargo vote, the Norinco subsidiary sent sales material about lithium hydride to five international arms dealers, the newspaper said. The company offered 10 tons of the chemical at about $210,000 a ton. The offer was open ``to any purchaser'' and Iraq agreed to buy seven tons. ``Sources suspect that they planned to fly it to Tehran, and then forward it as `pharmaceuticals' to Baghdad,'' the newspaper said. The Independent said it had copies of some of the original documents and had seen others. The Iraqis are most likely to use the chemical to make missile fuel, but it could be used to make poison gas, the newspaper said. Iraq's failure to obtain the chemical has held back Saddam's ballistic missile program, it said. The newspaper said the chemical can be used in the manufacture of hydrogen bombs, but Western experts do not believe Iraq has adequate nuclear technology. Julian Perry-Robinson, an authority on the science of chemical weapons, was quoted as saying the chemical is also needed for lithium aluminum hydride, which can be used to produce nerve gases. Saddam has used chemical weapons against Iranians during the seven-year Gulf War and on ethnic Kurds fighting for independence in northern Iraq.

DOC.HEAD: Appeals Court Rules Religion Not a Murder Defense
DOC.TEXT: A state appeals court has upheld the murder and child abuse convictions of a Christian Scientist couple who withheld medical treatment from their 7-year-old diabetic daughter. William and Christine Hermanson should never have been allowed to argue at trial that constitutional religious freedom exempted them from prosecution, the 2nd District Court of Appeal ruled Friday. ``The right to practice religion freely does not include liberty to expose the community or the child to communicable disease or the latter to ill health or death,'' the appeals court said, quoting a 1944 U.S. Supreme Court decision. Hermanson, 43, a former Sarasota banker, and his 39-year-old wife were convicted last year of felony child abuse and third-degree murder in the 1986 death of their daughter Amy from untreated diabetes. In accordance with their Christian Science beliefs, the Hermansons shunned modern medicine to treat Amy and instead relied on prayer. ``As the jury could and did determine, the Hermansons' acknowledged absolute right to hold their religious beliefs did not permit them to exercise that right at the price of Amy's life,'' the appeals court said in its 32-page decision. ``I think they covered the whole ballpark with it,'' said Assistant State Attorney Deno Economou, the lead trial prosecutor. ``I'm extremely pleased.'' Defense attorney Thomas Dart said he would have to study the decision further to determine whether to appeal. Regardless of further legal proceedings, spokesman Nathan Talbot said the Boston-based church must maintain its efforts to make people understand Christian Scientists' reliance on prayer. ``We'll just have to continue to let people know that there's an alternative method of healing that doesn't have a perfect track record but has been so successful that a large segment of society relies on it,'' Talbot said. The Hermansons were given suspended four-year prison sentences, placed on probation for 15 years and ordered to seek medical treatment for their surviving children. They have moved to St. Louis since their convictions and could not be reached for comment Saturday. A message was left on their answering machine. Courts in various states have delivered split decisions in similar cases in which parents who shun traditional medicine for religious reasons have been charged in the deaths of their children. In a case in July, a Christian Science couple in Boston was convicted of manslaughter in the death of their 2{-year-old son.

DOC.HEAD: Explosion in Somalia Kills 15
DOC.TEXT: An explosion killed 15 people on Saturday at National Custodial Police headquarters as soldiers were removing ammunition from a warehouse to be transferred elsewhere, sources said. A source close to the president's office said the explosion, on the southern outskirts of Mogadishu, appeared to be accidental. The custodial police, a branch of the army, are in charge of Somali prisons.

DOC.HEAD: New York Welcomes Leaders With Silence
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 6 grafs to UPDATE with some events taking place, others didn't. Picks up 5th graf, `President Bush...'. SUBS last graf with planned protest held.
DOC.HEAD: With AM-UN-Children
DOC.TEXT: Lights went out in some of the Big Apple's tallest buildings Saturday in tribute to the World Summit for Children at the United Nations. The Empire State Building, the Chrysler building, the Pan Am building, the Times Tower in Times Square, the Pepsi-Cola sign over the East River and other spots went dark at 8 p.m. for one minute. However, not everything went as planned. St. Patrick's Cathedral and many other churches that had been asked to ring bells at 8 p.m. in honor of the summit did not. Broadway theaters failed to turn off their marquees; and the World Trade Center was supposed to dim one tower and did not. Happily, the Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles concert at Radio City Music Hall came through with a moment of silence. And earlier in the day, a moment of silence was observed at Shea Stadium during a New York Mets baseball game. Taxi drivers were also supposed to honk their horns at 8 p.m. But, as Bob Bosch, who organized the tribute, said, ``I don't know how one would tell the difference between tonight's horns and every other night.'' The display was to honor the 70 world leaders participating in the historic World Summit for Children at the United Nations. President Bush came to town on Saturday, bringing along what he always does - massive traffic tie-ups. The path the president takes uptown after helicoptering in from New Jersey is always cleared of vehicles and pedestrians. Most of the VIP guests were in meetings Saturday, as opposed to a day earlier when they were bopping around town. President Patricio Aylwin of Chile spoke at a foreign affairs forum; Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu picked up an honorary degree at New York University; Queen Fabiola of Belgium visited the Covenant House shelter for young runaways. More visible than the heads of state are those angered by their presence. On Friday, there were three demonstrations outside the United Nations. Things were a little slower Saturday. A group of U.S. veterans demonstrated outside the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel to protest the meeting between Nguyen Co Thach, foreign minister of the Socialist Republic of Vietnam, and Secretary of State James Baker. Later Saturday, the United Ukrainian American Organizations of Greater New York held a protest against the signing of a new treaty between the Ukraine and Moscow.

DOC.HEAD: Gulf Crisis High on Bush Agenda During Round of U.N. Meetings
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 5th graf prv, ``The president ... afterward, with two grafs to include Bush request for more funds for U.S. troops in Japan. NO FURTHER LEADS PLANNED
DOC.TEXT: President Bush, weighing new steps against Iraq, consulted with world leaders on the Persian Gulf crisis Saturday as a top Soviet official pledged Moscow would send troops into military action if it were sanctioned by the United Nations. White House officials said Bush's blitz of personal diplomacy with more than two dozen leaders was aimed at shoring up the consensus of global outrage over Iraq's invasion of neighboring Kuwait. The president will address the U.N. General Assembly on Monday. Bush's appointment list over three days included Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze, British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, Japanese Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu, Canadian Prime Minister Brian Mulroney, NATO Secretary General Manfred Woerner and U.N. Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar. He conducted the first six of the meetings Saturday, concluding with an evening session with Kaifu, whose government has pledged $4 billion to support the multinational force in the gulf and to aid the front-line states of Jordan, Egypt and Turkey. Bush asked Kaifu to ensure that the money is disbursed quickly, and the Japanese leader pledged that it would be, officials from both sides said. Bush also urged that Tokyo increase the money it contributes to underwrite the cost of keeping U.S. forces in Japan. ``It goes without saying that Japan should continue to increase'' spending for that purpose, said Taizo Watanabe, the spokesman for Kaifu. Kaifu invited Bush to make a state visit to Japan early next year and Bush readily accepted. Solomon said the dates still must be worked out. Shevardnadze, meanwhile, made a commitment to involve Soviet forces in any action against Iraq authorized by the United Nations. The Soviet official said ``we will comply with any decision, with any resolution of the Security Council. ... And that would include anything regarding the involvement of the Soviet troops under the flag, under the auspices, of the United Nations.'' He made his comments in a taped interview for broadcast Sunday on NBC News' ``Meet the Press.'' The White House applauded Shevardnadze's comment. ``If the U.N. should move in this direction, we would, of course, welcome Soviet participation,'' said Roman Popadiuk, a deputy presidential press secretary. Bush's diplomatic meetings are interspersed around three major speeches he is making in New York. On Sunday, Bush will address the United Nations Children's Summit, a meeting that brings together more than 70 world leaders to plan a battle against the scourges of hunger, disease, poverty and illiteracy. An estimated 40,000 children die every day around the world from disease, malnutrition, crime and war. On Monday, Bush will address the General Assembly on the Persian Gulf crisis, hailing the world body for its resolve against Iraqi aggression. Also, before returning to Washington, he will address a meeting of foreign ministers of 35 nations trying to conclude an agreement to slash non-nuclear weapons in Europe. The group, the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe, is struggling to produce a treatyin time for a mid-November summit in Paris. The meetings with world leaders occur at a dramatic moment in global affairs, with many nations moving toward the brink of war in the Middle East. Upwards of 150,000 U.S. combat troops have been moved into the Persian Gulf to join the forces of Arab countries, Britain, France and other nations aligned against Iraq. White House officials say the systematic dismantling of Kuwait by Iraq since the Aug. 2 invasion has caused a reassessment of how long the world can wait to see if U.N. sanctions will work against Baghdad. Brent Scowcroft, the president's national security adviser, said Friday that the United States was considering making a new request for action to the United Nations. The U.N. already has adopted eight resolutions condemning Iraq's aggression and imposing trade and economic penalties, backed up by naval and air blockades. ``The atrocities, the devastation inside Kuwait, really are worthy of world attention and a U.N. resolution is one way to bring that kind of attention,'' Scowcroft said at a briefing on Bush's trip. Scowcroft said it was possible the United States might seek action that mentions the military option available under Article 42, which authorizes the use of ``all appropriate measures,'' including force, to enforce sanctions. Scowcroft said the gulf crisis would be discussed in most of Bush's meetings with leaders. In addition to Kaifu, Bush's schedule on Saturday included talks with Mulroney, President Cesar Gaviria of Colombia, Prime Minister Salim Al-Huss of Lebanon, President Violeta Chamorro of Nicaragua and Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki of Poland. In his meeting with Salim, Bush pledged that U.S. contacts with Syria concerning the Persian Gulf crisis ``would in no way be detrimental to Lebanon,'' a White House statement said. Bush reassured Salim that the United States seeks the withdrawal of all foreign forces from Lebanon. That would include Syrian troops who occupy the country. On Sunday, Bush will meet with Woerner and leaders of El Salvador, Mexico, Spain, Bangladesh, Brazil, Venezuela, Czechoslovakia and Britain. Monday's schedule includes meetings with leaders of Argentina, Uruguay and Malta. He also will see Shevardnadze, Perez de Cuellar, Organization of African Unity Chairman Yowery Museveni of Uganda and other African heads of state.

DOC.HEAD: Report British Ready with Nuclear Shells if Iraqis Use Gas
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The Observer newspaper reported Sunday that British forces will retaliate with battlefield nuclear weapons if Iraqi troops attack them with chemical gas. It cited as its source an unidentified senior officer attached to the British 7th Armored Brigade, which began leaving for the Persian Gulf on Saturday from Bremerhaven, West Germany. ``We do not comment on any aspect of our nuclear capability,'' said a Defense Ministry spokesman, who in line with British practice would not allow use of his name. The ministry refused to say if the brigade, normally stationed in Germany, was taking along its 155mm self-propelled howitzers, which can fire W48 nuclear shells or conventional high explosive. The newspaper said the nuclear shells are normally held by the British in dual custody with American troops. W48 shells are equivalent to 100 metric tons of high explosive, which is 100 times smaller than the atomic bomb dropped on Hiroshima at the end of World War II, the report added.

DOC.HEAD: Disaster Declaration Asked Two Weeks after Soviet Toxic Blast
DOC.TEXT: The president of Soviet Kazakhstan asked the Kremlin to declare an ecological disaster in part of his republic after an explosion at a nuclear fuel factory on Sept. 12 released a cloud of toxic gas, Tass reported. The official news agency said Saturday that the blast and fire at the Ulbinsky metallurgical plant in a workshop using beryllium spewed toxic gas that affected ``a considerable part of the population of Ust-Kamenogorsk.'' Ust-Kamenogorsk, a city of about 20,000 people, lies near the border with China and Mongolia in the Altai mountains. ``The public of Kazhakstan and population of the city demand urgent measures to improve the situation and they demand compensation for damage to their health,'' said a telegram sent on Friday by Nursultan Nazarbayev, president of the republic, to Soviet Prime Minister Nikolai Ryzhkov. Nazarbayev also asked that Soviet experts be sent to Ust-Kamenogorsk to decide on continued operation of the plant, and he requested an investigation by independent, international ecological experts, Tass reported. He was quoted as saying in the telegram that local authorities had already declared the region an ecological disaster zone. Several people were injured in the blast. There was no report of any radiation release. The plant is one of the largest producers of fuel for nuclear power plants in the Soviet Union and lies in a densely populated part of Ust-Kamenogorsk, Tass said. After the explosion and fire, toxic gas filled the streets and dissipated slowly because of there was little wind. Preliminary tests showed twice the permitted levels of beryllium in air and water samples. Beryllium is a very light metal that can catch fire easily and burn like a magnesium flash, vaporizing and releasing a deadly smoke of beryllium oxide. Ust-Kamenogorsk is about 105 miles east of Semipalatinsk, where the Soviet Union conducts its nuclear weapons tests. Residents have campaigned against the nuclear tests, and none have taken place for months. Izvestia reported shortly after the blast that officials involved in the accident were hiding documents to avoid blame.

DOC.HEAD: Troops Move Into Kiev as Ukrainian Nationalists Prepare Demonstration
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 11 grafs with troops moved around Kiev; picks up 6th graf pvs, `The Ukrainian ...
DOC.TEXT: Reinforcements for local police began arriving in the Ukrainian capital, Kiev, as nationalists prepared for a rally Sunday and a one-day strike to press demands for greater autonomy from the Kremlin. Stephen Gura, a strike committee member, said as many as 500,000 people were expected to take part in the demonstration. Large numbers of Interior Ministry tanks and troops were reportedly moved to the Kiev area, and one demonstration organizer quoted local authorities as saying they were prepared to use tanks to ``promote safety and order.'' Peter Barsuk, secretary of the Ukrainian Republican Party, quoted Kiev police chief V. Shaposhnikov as saying that his forces had been issued a non-lethal gas to disperse any unruly groups. Police also were ordered to check cars to prevent arms from entering the city, he said. ``They also received orders to arrest anyone who looks suspicious or who looks like someone with psychiatric problems,'' Barsuk quoted Shaposhnikov as saying. Ukrainian-Americans in the United States said they were receiving telephone calls from Kiev reporting the city had been cordoned off by troops. Those reports could not be confirmed independently. The Soviet Interior Ministry runs the national police force, and also has its own troops and tank units. The Tass news agency said that local police had requested help to control Ukrainians arriving for Sunday's rally, which was approved by the city council.
