The local Communist Party opposed the rally and the one-day strike that was to follow Monday. Organizers are demanding the resignation of the national government, additional benefits for miners and rejection of a new national union treaty, which they say exploits Ukrainians. Furthermore, Gura said protesters are demanding a halt to operations at the Chernobyl nuclear plant, site of the 1986 nuclear disaster, and the nationalization of property controled by the Communist Party. The legislature of the Ukraine, the second largest Soviet republic, already has declared sovereignty from the Soviet Union, giving it greater control of its economic and political life. Some Ukrainians, particularly in Western regions that were taken over by the Soviet Union during World War II, are pressing for full independence. The Ukrainian Communist Party Central Committee met on Friday and denounced plans for the demonstration and strike, the independent news agency Interfax reported. ``They have geared their efforts to seizing political power and they don't stop at using violent methods,'' the agency quoted Stanislav Gurenko, the party's first secretary, as saying. Gurenko said leaders of the Ukrainian Republican Party and Rukh, both nationalist movements, had organized the demonstration in an effort to destabilize the republic. Kiev officials, meanwhile, declared Saturday a day of mourning for the victims of the Babi Yar massacre by Nazi occupiers 49 years ago, the Tass news agency reported. Bari Yar was a ravine on the outskirts of Kiev where Nazis killed about 35,000 Jews on Sept. 29-30, 1941. The victims had been ordered to report to the area for resettlement, but were machine-gunned when they arrived. Over the next two years, Babi Yar became a Nazi burial ground and the remains at least 100,000 bodies, mostly Jews, were found after the war.

Iraqi atrocities in occupied Kuwait could prompt the United States to return to the United Nations to seek tougher sanctions against Saddam Hussein, possibly even military action, the White House says. On Friday, Kuwait's exiled emir, Sheik Jabir al-Ahmed al-Sabah, gave President Bush a harrowing account of what the president called a ``population assaulted, incarcerated, intimidated and even murdered.'' The narrative included tales of babies being removed from incubators and critically ill patients being taken off life-support systems so that the hospital machinery could be sent back to Iraq, said national security adviser Brent Scowcroft. ``It was a pretty devastating account, especially in the face of Saddam Hussein saying he is the defender of the Arabs against the outside,'' Scowcroft said. ---= WASHINGTON (AP) - The Bush administration is moving ahead with a test sale of 5 million barrels of stockpiled oil, despite contentions by lawmakers and its own energy secretary that the amount is too small. The Energy Department sent out formal notices of the sale Friday as the House voted to give President Bush authority to triple its size, as recommended a day earlier by Energy Secretary James Watkins. The White House stopped short of disavowing Watkins' suggestion that the 5-million-barrel sale announced by Bush on Wednesday was too small to even test how the 590-million-barrel Strategic Petroleum Reserve might work in an oil emergency. ``We'd have to look at'' any proposal to expand it, said Steven Hart, a White House spokesman. --- WASHINGTON (AP) - One of the world's last great Gothic churches was to be formally completed today, with President Bush and thousands of others gathering on the grounds of Washington National Cathedral to see the final stone put in place. It was a long time coming. It was just 83 years ago to the day that President Theodore Roosevelt rode to Mount St. Albans, the highest point in the capital, to see the foundation stone laid. A crowd of 10,000 braved threatening weather to join him. The stone reserved to the last is a 1,000-pound piece of Indiana limestone carved in the shape of a folded leaf or flower. It has been on display inside, but was moved onto the grounds of the cathedral to be lifted into place by a crane. The stone will rest on the southwest pinnacle of the catheral's St. Paul Tower. --- UNITED NATIONS (AP) - President Bush has a plan to combat measles and AIDS in the young but still opposes a children's rights treaty endorsed by scores of other nations, say U.S. officials at a conference examining those issues. Bush was expected to unveil the program to more than 70 other world leaders at the two-day World Summit for Children, scheduled to begin today. The Convention on the Rights of the Child, which went into effect this month, requires nations to guarantee the survival of children and their development. It sets new standards for fighting child neglect, sexual exploitation and other abuse. But U.S. officials say they are not yet ready to support the treaty, though it already has been ratified by 43 nations and endorsed by more than 100 others.

DOC.HEAD: Scottish Teacher in ``Head of the Class'' A Hoot
DOC.TEXT: There's a lot of babble about unconventional TV shows nowadays, mainly by people who talk about but don't watch ``Twin Peaks.'' But there are some truly unconventional shows about. Case in point: ABC's veteran Tuesday series about high school life, ``Head of the Class,'' which began its fifth season last month. It's well-crafted, literate - and even funny. This can't be said of the newer high school sitcoms, NBC's ``Ferris Bueller'' and Fox's ``Parker Lewis Can't Lose.'' They're so conventional that the students are smarter than their teachers and high school principals. ABC's ``Class,'' on the other hand, is set in an honors program class, its students are there to learn, and, as in the earlier era of ABC's long-running ``Welcome Back, Kotter,'' the teacher knows more than they do. If you haven't yet seen this season's ``Class,'' you might take a look tonight, because it has yet another unconventional touch - a new history teacher from Scotland played by comedian Billy Connolly. Connolly, who even is from Scotland, brings a wonderful warmth and exuberance to the show. Full of good will, with a musical lilt to his voice, he belies the rumor that all Scots are dour (the rumor started in 1746 after the Scots and the English had a frank exchange of views at a place called Culloden). As Oxford-educated Billy MacGregor, Connolly succeeds Howard Hesseman, who played the original, more laid-back teacher, Charlie Moore, but left to pursue ``various non-series projects.'' In the ``Class'' premiere, Moore's departure was explained as a sudden exit to take a shot at acting. As one student jokingly put it, he left to be in ``a low-budget musical - `Seven Brides for One Brother.' '' There is some resentment of the newcomer with the strange accent and obvious eyes for the lovely vice principal (Jeannetta Arnett). Most of the resentment is by Dennis (Dan Schneider), the rotund chemistry whiz who berates the class nerd, Arvid (Dan Frischman), for taking such an immediate liking to the new teacher. But it's hard not to like a guy who not only knows his history, but also describes the first westward rush of East Germans after the Berlin Wall came down as ``a tangled wave of bad denim.'' In tonight's episode, Connolly, who greets his young charges each morning with a cheery ``Good morning, geniuses,'' has to cope with the impact of a flu epidemic on a citywide high school Shakespeare competition. There might not be an epidemic at his school were it not for Arvid. Obsessed with maintaining a perfect attendance record, he insists on coming to class, even though he's so stricken by flu he faints at the start of the show. This prompts MacGregor to tell him, ``You look like smmething the cat dragged in, changed its mind, dragged back out again, came back in, threw up, went back out, dragged it farther away, and diiiiiiiied.'' It's not said meanly, though, but in the caring tradition and gentle humor of yesteryear's Kotter - who like MacGregor taught in a New York school, albeit to a class that was, er, of a lower I.Q. There also are nice bits of byplay in ``Class'' between the lovely vice principal and the new teacher, as when he agrees to help out in the flu-ravaged Shakespeare competition. Assuming a Shakespearean look, he intones: `I would sooner mine eyes be plucked from my head than deny thy lip's request.'' She smiles sweetly: ``That's beautiful. But it's not Shakespeare.'' Yep, this is unconventional television. Don't know if it'll survive. Why, the kids don't even say ``Surf's up.'' But take a look at this ``Class'' tonight. You may enroll in it. --- Elsewhere in television ...
